Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the <vocabulary>lately</vocabulary> period of time. It's <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>近い</jp> and <jp>頃</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: Recently I’ve been working the graveyard shift in a confectionery factory.
Context 1-JP: <jp>近頃は製菓工場で夜勤の仕事をしているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local <jp>お寺</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Apparently, the body of someone who died accidentally was found at the temple last night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨夜、あのお寺で変死体が発見されたらしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I lived next to a temple when I was a child and it was really convenient for studying Buddhism.
Context 2-JP: <jp>子どものころ、寺のとなりに住んでいたので、仏教の勉強には大変都合が良かったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I held a birthday party at one of the local temples in Japan. We got kicked out pretty quickly. I should have known that a temple wasn’t a good place to have a rock concert.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の地元のお寺で誕生日会を開いたんだけど、すぐに追い出されちゃった。お寺ってロック・コンサートをやる場所じゃないってこと、知っておけばよかったんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>prefecture</kanji> with lots of <kanji>horse chestnut</kanji> <kanji>tree</kanji>s is <vocabulary>Tochigi prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for <jp>栃</jp> and <jp>木</jp> and the on'yomi for <jp>県</jp>, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that <jp>き</jp> is changed to <jp>ぎ</jp> here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!
Context 1-EN: Are you from Tochigi Prefecture?
Context 1-JP: <jp>栃木県の出身なんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is your older sister, by the way. Not somebody else's.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet,  so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Picture your <vocabulary>older sister</vocabulary> (even if you don't have one), her birthday is coming up and there's only one thing she wants from you. <reading>A ne</reading>cklace (<jp>あね</jp>). She's wanted a necklace for years and you're finally going to give her one. She'll be so happy.
Context 1-EN: I’m just about to go to my older sister’s house.
Context 1-JP: <jp>姉のいえに行くところです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have five times as many books as my older sister does.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは、姉の五ばいのりょうの本をもっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My big sister works as a stewardess.
Context 3-JP: <jp>姉はスチュワーデスをしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Nothing</kanji> but <kanji>burdensome</kanji>. That's all you get out of doing this task. The <vocabulary>futility</vocabulary> of it is ridiculous. The <vocabulary>uselessness</vocabulary> is huge.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Just saying it is useless. Fugu never listens to advice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>言うだけ無駄だよ。フグは決して忠告には耳を貸さないんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>far</kanji> <kanji>distance</kanji> <kanji>detach</kanji>ment is a distance that is far. It is <vocabulary>long distance</vocabulary>. Also remember that <jp>距離</jp> is a "distance" so a far distance is a <vocabulary>long distance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In Japan, having a long distance commute to school or work is pretty common.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、遠距離通学や遠距離通勤はよくあることです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A thing that gives you <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>measurement</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>clock</vocabulary>. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is pretty weird. <jp>計</jp> is all nice and normal, but <jp>時</jp> is <jp>と</jp> for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word <jp>時</jp> (<jp>とき</jp>), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> is a walky <reading>talky</reading> (<jp>とけい</jp>) and run with that?
Context 1-EN: Koichi dropped the clock Viet had given him from the ship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはビエトにもらった時計を船から落としてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We're gonna meet at the clock tower at 3 p.m., okay?
Context 2-JP: <jp>時計台の下で、三時に待ち合わせね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, isn’t that spit on your watch?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねぇ、あなたの時計に唾が着いてない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>one time</vocabulary>. How many times? Just one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that <jp>一</jp> is shortened (as it often is) to <jp>いっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Please say it once more.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう一回、言ってください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I take a shower once a day during the week, but not at all over the weekend.
Context 2-JP: <jp>平日は一日に一回シャワーをあびますが、休日はぜんぜんあびません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you want it one more time, honey?
Context 3-JP: <jp>もう一回欲しいのかい、ハニー？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sew</kanji> so well that people will <kanji>judge</kanji> you to be the best and you'll be a champion at <vocabulary>sewing</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Sewing really isn’t my strong point.
Context 1-JP: <jp>裁縫はあまり得意ではありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>run</kanji> so now you know the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to run</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <jp>はし</jp> portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into <reading>hash</reading> (<jp>はし</jp>) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.
Context 1-EN: I ran because I was almost late for the movie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>えいがにおくれそうだったので、走りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi can run faster than a turtle.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはカメよりもはやく走れる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve come to the conclusion that having my head cut off by a samurai would be much worse than running for my life.
Context 3-JP: <jp>人生走り続けるより、侍に首をはねられる方がずっとましだという結論に達しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>place</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> on someone you're giving them <vocabulary>jurisdiction</vocabulary> over whatever that thing is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Anyway, let’s get in contact with the police station with jurisdiction first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とにかく、まずは所轄の警察署に連絡をいれましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who <kanji>differ</kanji>s in <kanji>gender</kanji> from you is of a <vocabulary>different gender</vocabulary>. This is often used to mean the <vocabulary>opposite sex</vocabulary> in the sense of men as viewed by women and vice versa.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When I first learned about share houses, I thought it would be impossible for strangers of different genders to live together.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シェアハウスについて初めて知った時、知らない異性同士が暮らすなんてありえないと思いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Today, I talked to a person of the opposite sex for longer than usual.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は異性といつもより長く話しをしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mika, you are too conscious of boys' muscles.
Context 3-JP: <jp>美果は、異性の筋肉を意識しすぎてるんだって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a <reading>sockeye</reading> (<jp>さかい</jp>) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.
Context 1-EN: This river forms the boundary between the two states.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この川がちょうど両州の境となっているんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You thought you <kanji>memorize</kanji>d what this picture looked like, but suddenly everything looks <kanji>confused</kanji> and different. That's because it's an <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was assailed by an illusion that looked just like me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それがまるで自分のもののような錯覚に襲われたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>confused</kanji> all of the ingredients to your cake by <kanji>mix</kanji>ing them together into one weird <vocabulary>mixture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Various emotions were mixed and we weren’t able to reach a conclusion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>色々な感情が交錯し、結論を出せずにいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>編集</jp> is <kanji>edit</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to edit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m editing a document summary in the office right now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今オフィスで資料の要約を編集しているところよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>効果</jp> is "effect," so the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of said effect is the <vocabulary>opposite effect</vocabulary>. Whoops!
Reading: <reading><jp>ぎゃくこうか</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>ぎゃっこうか</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: ぎゃくこうか,ぎゃっこうか
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as  well. Will help to know <jp>効果</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: I kissed that other girl to make my girlfriend jealous, but it really backfired.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女に焼き餅を妬かせようとして他の女にキスをしたら、全く逆効果になってしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>believe</kanji> in your <kanji>self</kanji> you have plenty of <vocabulary>confidence</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>self confidence</vocabulary>). This is a good thing to have!
Reading Mnemonic: How much <jp>自信</jp> do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi is quite the self-confident person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは大変な自信家です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should have more confidence in yourself.

Context 3-EN: Viet said he was sure he could draw Koichi’s face better than anyone else because he knew him better than anyone else.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトは、誰よりもコウイチのことをよく知っているので、誰よりもうまくコウイチの顔を描ける自信があると言っていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an <kanji>English</kanji> and <kanji>Japanese</kanji> (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is <vocabulary>English Japanese</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I work as an English-Japanese translator.
Context 1-JP: <jp>英和ほんやくの仕事をしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A new English Japanese parallel translation book came out.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新しい英和対やくの本が出ました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Uh-oh, Cameron's about to cry! Can you go find the English-Japanese dictionary and hand it to him?
Context 3-JP: <jp>おっと、キャメロンが泣きそうだ！ちょっとあの英和辞典を探して来て、キャメロンに渡してあげてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The one true <kanji>sovereign</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Japanese Emperor</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Emperor of Japan</vocabulary>. All other emperors aren't simply <jp>帝</jp> on its own.
Reading Mnemonic: To remember the reading, think about how the <vocabulary>Japanese Emperor</vocabulary>, can always pull out his "<reading>me card</reading>" (<jp>みかど</jp>) when he's in trouble. It's kind of like how a "trump card" is the one that's above all the others, but with the emperor he's always up there, so it's a "me card" to him. And who's gonna argue with the emperor? Not me.
Context 1-EN: People hung the national flag for the Japanese Emperor’s visit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人々は、帝がお出でになるということで、国旗を掲げました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>sponsor</kanji> an <kanji>announce</kanji>ment, you're allowing those you're sponsoring to create some kind of <vocabulary>notification</vocabulary> for all those they want to get in contact with.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: A consumer credit company has been sending me notification letters over and over, demanding that I pay back my debt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サラ金から、借金の返済を求める催告状が何度も何度も届いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Well, I locked myself out of my car and am waiting for a locksmith to come.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いや〜鍵を中に置いたまま車に鍵をかけちゃってさ、今鍵屋さんが来るのを待ってるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dull</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dull</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: To remember the reading, think about how when you're i<reading>neb</reading>riated (<jp>にぶ</jp>) you need to use a <vocabulary>dull</vocabulary> knife. The <jp>にぶい</jp> reading talks about a thing that is dull. For <jp>のろい</jp>, which refers to a dull mind (someone who's <vocabulary>thickheaded</vocabulary>). Think about a <reading>Nor</reading>se (<jp>のろ</jp>) God, the God of dullbrains.
Context 1-EN: I’m pregnant and sometimes I feel a dull pain in my stomach. Is this normal?
Context 1-JP: <jp>現在妊娠中で、お腹に時々鈍い痛みを感じるんですが、これは普通ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is the <vocabulary>next month</vocabulary>! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I am having a birthday party next month, so please come too, Kanae.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来月たん生日会をするので、かなえさんも来てください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What day next month is the day of the fireworks display?
Context 2-JP: <jp>花火大会の日は来月の何日でしたっけ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Next month I’ll start scuba diving to find the glasses I lost at sea today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日海に落とした眼鏡を探すために、来月スキューバダイビングを始めることにしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>文字</jp> means "letters". So, what are "small letters"? That would be <vocabulary>lowercase letters</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>小</jp> is an exceptional reading. You know it means "small," so think about what else is small: a child. How do you say "child" in Japanese? <jp>こ</jp>. You also know how to say the <jp>文字</jp> portion from the previous level, so combine those together and you have <reading><jp>こもじ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: How do you switch from lowercase to uppercase?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうやって小文字と大文字を切りかえますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Passwords must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter and a number.
Context 2-JP: <jp>パスワードには、かならず大文字、小文字、すう字を一つい上つかってください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Is your email address in all lowercase letters? Is it really? Are you crazy?
Context 3-JP: <jp>君のEメールアドレスって、全部小文字なの？本当に？ちょっとおかしいんじゃないの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji> is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the <vocabulary>English language</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>English</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I think English pronunciation is more difficult than Japanese pronunciation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>英語の発音は日本語の発音よりむずかしいと思う。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If this restaurant's workers turn out to be able to speak English, we won't have to go all the way to the other one any more.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もしこのレストランの店員も英語が話せるようだったら、今後わざわざあの店まで行かなくてすむようになるね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "All of us hate our English and Math classes." "Hey, speak for yourself. I like both of them."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「僕たちは皆、英語と数学の授業が嫌いだ。」「ちょっと、一緒にしないでよ。私は両方共好きだし。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sticky</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be sticky</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to persevere</vocabulary>, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.
Reading Mnemonic: Will I give up? I'll <reading>nevah</reading> (<jp>ねば</jp>) give up! I'll also <reading>nevah</reading> unstick from you.
Context 1-EN: Wow! That salesman is still talking to my mom. How persistent!
Context 1-JP: <jp>ええっ！あのセールスマンまだうちの母ちゃんと話をしてるよ。粘るね〜！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: With <kanji>paint</kanji> I want to <kanji>attire</kanji> the wall. Let's put a <vocabulary>coating</vocabulary> of <vocabulary>painting</vocabulary> up on the wall.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I am so sorry for being late. Painting my bathroom walls took me longer than I thought.
Context 1-JP: <jp>遅くなって、本当にすみません。トイレの壁の塗装が思ったよりも長引いてしまって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>closed</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You need <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary> the door or the <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>) will come in. Not just one sheep, or two, but hundreds of sheep. They'll see you didn't manage <vocabulary>to shut</vocabulary> that door properly, and when you turn around your house will be covered floor to ceiling with fat squishy sheep.
Context 1-EN: I hate when my husband twists the caps back on plastic bottles really tightly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>旦那がペットボトルのキャップを閉める時、キツく締めすぎるのが嫌です。</jp>

Meaning: To Replace,To Substitute,To Exchange,To Replace Something,To Substitute Something,To Exchange Something
Meaning Mnemonic: You know the kanji is <kanji>substitute</kanji>, and you know this is a verb. There are other similar ones, but this one means <vocabulary>to replace</vocabulary>. In order to remember that this particular word means "to replace" focus in on the <jp>え</jp>. You have an egg in your hands that you notice isn't any good (it's black and moldy). So, you replace it with another egg (or substitute it with another egg, or exchange it with another egg, etc).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is the same as <jp>代わる</jp> which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.
Context 1-EN: The coach is replacing the pitcher, I think.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かんとくは、ピッチャーを代えるだろう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I usually substitute yogurt for sour cream.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ふだんは、ヨーグルトをサワークリームに代えてつかっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t exchange this ring for money.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この指輪をお金に代えることはできません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You don't <kanji>servant</kanji> something... but what do servants do? You are their god, so they have <vocabulary>to make an offering</vocabulary> to you every day.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It shares its reading with the word <jp>備える</jp>, which you learned a level ago, but in case you need a reminder, here it is:

What's the best way for your servants <vocabulary>to make an offering</vocabulary>? When they <vocabulary>offer</vocabulary> up their sauna (<jp>そな</jp>)! You really value a warm and relaxing sauna session at the end of the day.
Context 1-EN: Can you buy some flowers to place on the graves tomorrow on your way home?
Context 1-JP: <jp>明日お墓に供える花を、帰りに買ってきてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> get <kanji>ridiculed</kanji> a lot, but it makes me have really strong <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary>. If you get picked on a lot, just say, "I have <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary>, and I can make it through this."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Holding your pee is bad for your health.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おしっこを我慢するのは体に悪い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>measure</kanji> and then <kanji>calculate</kanji> something, you are making a <vocabulary>calculation</vocabulary>. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Viet is calculating the cost of the all you can drink party now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトは今、飲み放題のパーティーにかかるひ用を計算しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is very quick at calculations, though he doesn't look it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ああ見えて、コウイチは計算がものすごく速いんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mom! If I do all of these calculations, instead of becoming a math genius, I’ll just lose my mind.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お母さん！こんなに沢山の計算をしたら、数学の天才になるかわりに逆に頭がおかしくなっちゃうよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>rent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>house rent</vocabulary>, though it can be your apartment rent too.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>家</jp> is an exceptional one. It is <jp>や</jp>, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say <reading>yah</reading> (<jp>や</jp>), whether you did or not.
Context 1-EN: If the rent is this much, I might be able to manage living on a small salary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>安月給だけど、この家賃だったら何とか暮らしていけそうかな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I renewed my contract for the apartment yesterday, but I didn't understand why the rent was $500 more than last year. I thought about moving out for a second.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨日、アパートの契約こう新したんだけど、去年から家賃が500ドルも上がったってどういうこと？一しゅん引っ越そうかと思ったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I think about the way Fugu treated me, I realized that he was a real jerk. I paid his rent, phone bills, groceries, and everything, but he ended up cheating on me!
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグが私にどんな扱いをしてたか考えてみると、彼がどれだけ最低男だったかが分かるわ。私は彼の家賃から電話代から食費から何から何まで払ってあげていたのに、あの男は他の女と浮気してたのよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something is <kanji>steam</kanji>ing, it makes the room all humid, making this word <vocabulary>to be humid</vocabulary> (because you're not doing the humiding).
Reading Mnemonic: What is making things <vocabulary>to be humid</vocabulary>? That would be that cow. Every time he says, "<reading>Moo</reading>" (<jp>む</jp>) he spurts out a ton of steam making the room all humid.
Context 1-EN: These shoes look cute, but they make my feet sweaty and stinky.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この靴、可愛いんだけど、足が蒸れて臭うんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You use your <kanji>daring</kanji> and just <kanji>go</kanji>! You made a <vocabulary>decisive action</vocabulary> by just going like that! It was go or not go and you chose go!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you really intend to carry out this strategy?
Context 1-JP: <jp>本当にこの作戦を敢行するつもりですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>blind</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blind person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A man lives in that house who was born blind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その家には、生まれつき盲人の男が住んでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>prefecture</kanji> in Japan where they <kanji>love</kanji> <kanji>princess</kanji>es is <vocabulary>Ehime Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This reading is a little messy. This reading for <jp>愛</jp> is an exception, <jp>媛</jp> uses the kun'yomi reading <jp>ひめ</jp>, and <jp>県</jp> uses the on'yomi reading <jp>けん</jp>. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for <jp>愛</jp>:

If you ask anyone outside of <vocabulary>Ehime Prefecture</vocabulary> what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "<reading>Eh</reading>" (<jp>え</jp>). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"
Context 1-EN: I am from Ehime Prefecture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は愛媛県の出身です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is the <kanji>color</kanji> of <kanji>tea</kanji>? You'd think it would be green, assuming it's Japanese... but this word came from China. What color is Chinese tea? It tends to be more <vocabulary>brown</vocabulary>. Think Oolong tea, for example.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.
Context 1-EN: Please color the number that best matches the ★ with brown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>★に入るばんごうを、茶色にぬります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'd like to dye my hair light brown, please.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明るい茶色にカラーリングしてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: All of my white t-shirts have brown armpit stains on them.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の白いTシャツ全ての脇のところに、茶色のシミがある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>nostalgia</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>nostalgic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Do you remember doing that? Oh man, those were the days. How <jp>懐かしい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: A nostalgic song was echoing out of the speakers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>懐かしい曲がスピーカーから鳴り響いていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>window</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of <vocabulary>ticket window</vocabulary> I'm talking about.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings for <jp>窓</jp> and the reading for <jp>口</jp>.
Context 1-EN: She really aced the job interview even though it was just for a ticket window position.
Context 1-JP: <jp>窓口の仕事ではあったが、彼女はその面接をとてもうまくこなした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>perfume</kanji>? <vocabulary>Sweet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fragrant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want to smell a <vocabulary>sweet</vocabulary> fragrance, just open some potpourri. But be careful if it's a can. Fragrant <reading>can</reading>s will <reading>baa</reading> (<jp>かんば</jp>) like a sheep at you when you open them. That can baa is just a sweet smell side effect.
Context 1-EN: The plums’ aroma is really fragrant during this season.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この季節は、梅の香りがとても芳しいですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>leader</kanji> is the <vocabulary>company president</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>manager</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>director</vocabulary>. Be sure to greet your <jp>社長</jp> with a hearty good morning when s/he stumbles in!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The company president is in a meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社長は会ぎ中です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The president of Tofugu is insane to lower the price of that popular service.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの人気サービスのねだんを下げるなんて、トーフグの社長はどうかしてるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: All my coworkers hate my boss, but I just think he’s a little mean.
Context 3-JP: <jp>全社員は社長のことを嫌っているが、私は単に彼は少し意地悪なだけだと思っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: All the art, music, or books that come out <kanji>after</kanji> a person <kanji>die</kanji>s are considered to be released <vocabulary>after death</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>posthumously</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A commemoration exhibition is planned 50 years after their death.
Context 1-JP: <jp>没後50年を記念した展覧会を予定しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>replace</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to replace</vocabulary>. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the <reading>air</reading> (<jp>える</jp>). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I already asked dad to change the bulb.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お父さんに電球を替えるようにもう頼んだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>certain</kanji>ly <kanji>necessary</kanji> is something you can't live without. It's <vocabulary>indispensable</vocabulary>. And it's <vocabulary>required</vocabulary> by you to keep on living.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: By default, you’re required to input your name, birthdate, and email address.
Context 1-JP: <jp>デフォルトでは、名前と生年月日、メールアドレスの入力が必須になっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>latitude</kanji> <kanji>line</kanji> can also be called a <vocabulary>parallel</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The 0 degree parallel is called the equator.
Context 1-JP: <jp>緯度0度の緯線のことを、赤道と呼びます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> you have more than enough <vocabulary>energy</vocabulary> for everyone to start noticing. They come up to you and compliment you on your amazing <vocabulary>liveliness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because <jp>かつ</jp> is being shortened here to <jp>かっ</jp>. It's a pretty common change for on'yomi ending in <jp>つ</jp>, so keep your eyes open for more that do this!
Context 1-EN: This city is very lively.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この町は、とても活気があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Nikka is always full of energy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ニッカはいつも活気にあふれている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The market was overflowing with energy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>市場は活気にあふれていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>orphan</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> is one that's all alone, without any other island friends or family. That's what makes it a <vocabulary>solitary island</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>島</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There are a few <vocabulary>solitary island</vocabulary>s off the coast of Japan that are actually considered to be a part of <reading>To</reading>kyo (<jp>とう</jp>). Usually people think Tokyo is just the big city on the mainland, but it includes these little, lonely islands too!
Context 1-EN: I’m writing a novel set on a solitary island.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今は孤島を舞台とした小説を書いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>time</kanji>'s <kanji>climate</kanji> is the current <vocabulary>season</vocabulary>. Each season has a different climate and exists in a different <vocabulary>time of year</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: People usually begin letters with a seasonal greeting in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、通常手紙は時候の挨拶から書き始められる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Hunting</kanji> where you <kanji>hunt</kanji> is still <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>狩</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The most importing thing when <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary> is not to forget your hunting <reading>shoe</reading>s (<jp>しゅ</jp>). Without your special shoes all the animals will hear your stomping feet and run away before you can get them.
Context 1-EN: Hunting of this bird is prohibited.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この鳥の狩猟は禁じられています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>scarlet</kanji> colored <kanji>carp</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>red carp</vocabulary> and sometimes a <vocabulary>golden carp</vocabulary> because sometimes people don't understand colors.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: The colored carp was an improvement on the red and golden carp.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ニシキゴイは緋鯉をもとに改良されたものです。</jp>

Meaning: With All One's Might,With All Your Might
Meaning Mnemonic: You put <kanji>one cup of liquid</kanji>... no, one full cup of liquid <kanji>spirit</kanji> into what you're doing. None of this half-cup garbage. A full one. That means you're going at it <vocabulary>with all one's might</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you've seen <jp>一杯</jp> before.
Context 1-EN: Getting rid of old pictures is the best I can do for now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今は古い写真を捨てることが私にできる精一杯です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>draft</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>manuscript</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I spilled coffee on the manuscript.
Context 1-JP: <jp>原稿に珈琲を零してしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>catch</kanji> so the intransitive verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be caught</vocabulary>. This is a literal, physical catch. So, for example, you can catch a criminal using this verb but not catch the drift of an idea, which would be <jp>捕える</jp>, coming up in level 27.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>つか</jp>, so to remember that with <vocabulary>to be caught</vocabulary>, think about how you're a police officer trying to catch some criminals. Unfortunately, they have split up into <reading>two ca</reading>rs (<jp>つか</jp>) meaning you won't catch both of them, since you only have one car.
Context 1-EN: At first I was just stopped for speeding, but I ended up being caught for drunk driving.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最初スピード違反で止められたんだけど、その後飲酒運転で捕まっちゃったんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cleaning</kanji> (<jp>掃除</jp>) <kanji>machine</kanji> is a <vocabulary>vacuum cleaner</vocabulary>. Suck that dirt up!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Scientists say that space is one giant vacuum, right? So why don’t we just use that to clean our carpets?
Context 1-JP: <jp>科学者は、宇宙はある巨大な掃除機だと言うでしょ？だったら、それをカーペットを掃除するのに使ったらいいんじゃない？？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>grave</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a place where there are graves. It is a <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>cemetery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji, which is fairly unusual, but then graveyards are unusual and special places. You've learned both of these readings before, so you should be able to read this on your own, but here's a reminder for <jp>墓</jp> just in case:

When you're finally dead and buried in a <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary>, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the <reading>Haka</reading> (<jp>はか</jp>) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.
Context 1-EN: If you live next to a cemetery, ghosts might knock on your door.
Context 1-JP: <jp>墓場の隣に住んだら、お化けがドアをノックすることもあるかもしれない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>eye</kanji> is on what's <kanji>next</kanji>. How is this possible to see what's coming up? That's because you're looking at a <vocabulary>table of contents</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, but you learned the kun'yomi reading for <jp>目</jp> before. So, you have to remember that this word uses <jp>もく</jp> instead of <jp>め</jp>. To do that, imagine yourself looking at a <vocabulary>table of contents</vocabulary>. Instead of being a normal table of contents there, it's just line after line of text trying to <reading>mock</reading> (<jp>もく</jp>) you. Come up with what those lines are and think about how you're being mocked.
Context 1-EN: The table of contents page was torn out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>目次のページがやぶれています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: First, I would like to explain the table of contents.
Context 2-JP: <jp>先ずはじめに、目次をごせつ明いたします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do I have to read this whole book? Can’t I just read the table of contents?
Context 3-JP: <jp>この本全部読まないとだめ？目次だけ読むってことは無理かな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine a <vocabulary>sheep</vocabulary> fighting with Jesus. The first thing it does is <reading>hits Je</reading>sus (<jp>ひつじ</jp>) in the stomach with its fists, then hits Jesus again with its horns. Try to imagine this playing out, with an announcer calling the shots as well.
Context 1-EN: I got to feed the sheep at the zoo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうぶつえんで、羊にえさをやりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Anything can happen at any moment, so if you want a sheep, get it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつ何がおこるか分からないんだから、羊がかいたいなら、かいたいと思ったときにかった方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you think sheep feel embarrassed when they have their wool sheared off?
Context 3-JP: <jp>毛を刈られた時、羊も恥ずかしい思いをしていると思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>constant</kanji> <kanji>normal</kanji> things in your life are also <vocabulary>constant</vocabulary>. If you normally always do them, then they're also probably a part of your everyday <vocabulary>routine</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: With this system we can consistently keep it at room temperature.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このシステムで部屋の温度を恒常に保っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>board</kanji> a plane or a car to take a <kanji>ride</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>boarding</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>embarkation</vocabulary>. You have to get on the right way or you can't ride.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>乗</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know one person who always has a hard time <vocabulary>boarding</vocabulary> a plane, and it's <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<jp>じょう</jp>), the simple farmhand. Jourm is what you'd call a very big boy. He doesn't fit in the tube thing you normally walk through when boarding a plane, so he has to climb up the side. It's a whole thing.
Context 1-EN: Please watch your feet while boarding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ご搭乗の際は、足元にお気をつけください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>believe</kanji> in the <kanji>number</kanji>s, there will be no traffic because the <vocabulary>traffic light</vocabulary> will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You stop at a red light and cross the street at a green light, okay?
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤信号で止まって、青信号でわたるのよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's dangerous to ignore traffic lights, so don't do that okay?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あぶないから、信号をむししてはいけませんよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Listen carefully. Turn left at the sixth traffic light, walk another eight blocks, turn right and shake your butt toward someone you will meet there. That’s the secret sign, okay? Then, he will take you to our hideout.
Context 3-JP: <jp>いいか、よく聞けよ。六つ目の信号で左折した後、八つ目の角まで歩いて右折したら、そこで会った人に向かってお尻を振るんだ。それが秘密のサインだからな。そしたら、奴はお前を俺たちのアジトまで連れて行ってくれるさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You end up writing your rough <kanji>draft</kanji> on some <kanji>grass</kanji> leaves because you forgot your <vocabulary>notes</vocabulary>. This grass will serve as your notes now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m writing up a draft of the speech.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スピーチの草稿を作成しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>aviation</kanji> (<jp>航空</jp>) <kanji>ticket</kanji> is the kind of ticket you need to fly on an airplane. That's an <vocabulary>airplane ticket</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Could you arrange a flight for me to Hakata?
Context 1-JP: <jp>博多までの航空券を手配してもらえますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of <jp>染</jp>. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary> on your shirt, all because you were trying to dye some <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>) and they didn't like it. So now you have a big dye and sheep poo stain. How were you supposed to know sheep don't like being dyed?!
Context 1-EN: Couldn’t you find some way to remove this stain?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この染みなんとか取れないかなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Throw</kanji> your <kanji>draft</kanji> at people to <vocabulary>post</vocabulary> it on their Facebook wall! Wait, that's not how it works? Hush, yes it does, just throw it harder.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I posted pictures of my dog to Facebook.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フェイスブックに犬の写真を投稿しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While <jp>後で</jp> (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: <vocabulary>behind</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>back</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>rear</vocabulary>. Think of the <jp>ろ</jp> as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (<jp>ろ</jp>) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind."
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Continue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look <vocabulary>behind</vocabulary> you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? It's <jp>うし</jp>, which is also the reading for this word.
Context 1-EN: Please close the door behind you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの後ろのドアをしめてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You must install the child carseat on the rear seat of the car.
Context 2-JP: <jp>チャイルドシートは、かならず後ろのざせきにせっちしてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you turn around to look behind you and then do it again, you’ll see me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>振り返って後ろを見た後、さらにもう一度振り返ったら、僕のことが見えるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>South</kanji> <kanji>East</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Southeast</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The car continued heading southeast.
Context 1-JP: <jp>車は、南東に向かってすすみました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I totally thought the sun would set in the southeast today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>てっきり今日は日が南東にしずむもんだとおもっていたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I saw a shooting star in the southeast.
Context 3-JP: <jp>南東の方角に、流れ星を見た。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>クモ</jp> is a spider. Add a <kanji>nest</kanji> to it, and you have a spider nest. What do spider's call their nests? They call it a <vocabulary>spiderweb</vocabulary> (that is, if they can talk).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I found my grandpa’s unfinished painting covered in cobwebs in the attic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>屋根裏部屋で、クモの巣が掛かった祖父の未完成の絵を見つけたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>constant</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the kind that stays in one place. It's just a regular <vocabulary>star</vocabulary>, like the north star or our sun, not a comet or an asteroid.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Apparently, there are times the black hole tears stars into pieces.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ブラックホールが、恒星をばらばらに引き裂くことがあるらしい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Sometimes volcanoes <kanji>erupt</kanji> with just <kanji>smoke</kanji> instead of lava or fire. That's called an <vocabulary>volcanic smoke</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I took a picture of the volcanic smoke rising over Sakurajima.
Context 1-JP: <jp>噴煙を上げる桜島の写真を撮りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Bite into a <vocabulary>melon</vocabulary> and what do you taste? <reading>Uni ree</reading>se's pieces (<jp>うり</jp>)! Did you know that? The next time you eat a melon see if you can taste the difference!
Context 1-EN: This is pickled melon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは瓜の漬物です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you do a <kanji>drawing</kanji> of a <kanji>measurement</kanji> you want to do on the chalkboard, you're drawing up a <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary> for doing something. All things require some kind of measurement, so drawing that measurement up is your plan.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for <jp>画</jp> is the secondary reading though (<jp>かく</jp>), so take note of that.
Context 1-EN: We are planning to go to the beach during summer vacation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夏休みに海に行こうと計画しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like to plan but I don't like to carry out what I've planned.
Context 2-JP: <jp>計画を立てるのは大好きなんですけど、計画したことを実行するのはきらいなんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If we’re going to steal the Eiffel Tower, we need to have a really good plan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし俺たちがエッフェル塔を盗むというなら、かなりしっかりした計画を練る必要がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji>... who could that be? Let's think about it. Who invented kanji and therefore probably thinks they're the middle of the world? Who also is just a huge country that ruled much of Asia? That would be none other than <vocabulary>China</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Next month I’m traveling to China on business.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来月は、出ちょうで中国に行きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: During winter break, I watched the meteor shower in China.
Context 2-JP: <jp>冬休みに、中国でりゅう星ぐんを見ました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why did Japanese people stop calling China "Shina" and start calling it "Chuugoku?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして日本人は中国を支那と呼ぶことをやめて中国と呼び始めたんだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>copy</kanji>, but what is a copy? It is basically a photograph, which is why this word means <vocabulary>to be photographed</vocabulary>. You know this one is "to be photographed" because it ends with a <jp>る</jp>. Someone thinks you're "<reading>ru</reading>de" so they're photographing you.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <jp>うつ</jp> part. You're being rude, right? That's why you got photographed. Why are you rude? You're doing beatboxing, constantly saying <jp>うつうつうつ</jp> over and over again. Say it out loud, too.
Context 1-EN: Is your brother in these pictures?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたのお兄さんは、このしゃしんに写っていますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Among the 500 pictures I took this year, 103 of them had my father who had died last year in them.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今年とった五百まいの写しんの内、なんと百三まいの写しんに去年しんだ父のすがたが写っていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The guy in this picture was my first kiss.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この写真に写っている男の人は、私のファーストキスです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Freight</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s is <vocabulary>freight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cargo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>物</jp> reading that's <jp>もつ</jp>. You can know this because you have to carry the freight and cargo (<jp>持つ</jp> it!).
Context 1-EN: There is a freight train that runs between Sapporo cargo terminal and Fukuoka cargo terminal every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日札幌貨物ターミナルと福岡貨物ターミナル間を走行する貨物列車があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>land</kanji> <kanji>army</kanji> is the <vocabulary>land army</vocabulary>, also known as the plain old <vocabulary>army</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We’re just here to observe the army training.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達は陸軍訓練を見に来たただの見学です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>South</kanji> <kanji>latitude</kanji> is <vocabulary>south latitude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>southern latitude</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Theoretically, 45 degrees south is considered to be middle point between the South Pole and the equator.
Context 1-JP: <jp>理論上は、南緯45度が南極点から赤道までの距離の中間地点であるとされる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's the 2011 <kanji>year</kanji>. I think the meaning is pretty obvious. This just means <vocabulary>year 2011</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>2011</vocabulary>.
Reading Whitelist: にせんじゅういちねん
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a little trickier. You start with two thousand (<jp>二千／にせん</jp>), then you need to add eleven to it (<jp>十一／じゅういち</jp>). Then, you simply add the reading for <jp>年</jp> which you already know. You can assume it's the on'yomi reading because it's attached to something else, like a jukugo. From there, you get the entire reading.
Context 1-EN: I went to Japan in 2011.
Context 1-JP: <jp>２０１１年に、日本にいきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My husband has been working on Mars since 2011.
Context 2-JP: <jp>主人は、２０１１年から火せいではたらいています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My father finally admitted to drug use in 2011.
Context 3-JP: <jp>父は、２０１１年にようやくドラッグの使用を認めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>貧乏</jp> is <kanji>poor</kanji>, so a poor <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>poor person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know <jp>貧乏</jp> already.
Context 1-EN: You think you’re so great, but bear in mind, you are just a poor person from a poor family!
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前は自分のことを素晴らしいと思っているみたいだけどな、ただの貧乏家族の貧乏人だってことを、よ〜く肝に銘じておくんだな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>革</jp> is <kanji>leather</kanji> and <jp>ジャン</jp> is short for <jp>ジャンパー</jp> (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a <vocabulary>leather jacket</vocabulary>.
Reading Whitelist: かわじゃん,かわジャン
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the vocab word <jp>革</jp>, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).
Context 1-EN: I’m not buying such an expensive leather jacket just because a fashionista told me to.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お洒落大好き人間にアドバイスされたってだけで、あんな高い革ジャンは買うわけないじゃん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A person who lives in a revolution (<jp>革命</jp>) <kanji>house</kanji> is <vocabulary>a revolutionary</vocabulary>. They want government change! They want to take down the people in power!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know <jp>革命</jp> already as well.
Context 1-EN: That revolutionary is only hot-tempered on the Internet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの革命家は、ネット弁けいだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you want to be a revolutionary, first you need to be able to speak effectively.
Context 2-JP: <jp>革命家になりたければ、まずは効果的な話し方を身につけないといけないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She fell in love with a passionate French revolutionary.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女は情熱的なフランス人革命家と恋に落ちた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something with a <kanji>beauty</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is something that is really <vocabulary>tasty</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>good tasting</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. Mmmm, yum!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word <jp>おいしい</jp> already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "<reading>OI</reading> (<jp>おい</jp>). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"
Context 1-EN: Koichi and Viet secretly keep some good-tasting whiskey in the office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチとビエトは、オフィスに美味しいウィスキーをかくし持っている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like trying little bits of many different tasty dishes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>少しずつ、色んなしゅるいの美味しいものが食べたいんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Recently, a lot of pubs with delicious food have been opening in the Tofugu office.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近、Tofuguのオフィス内に、料理の美味しいパブがたくさん開店してるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: A thin film forms when I warm milk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>牛乳を温めると薄い膜が張ることがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Barbarian</kanji>s have <kanji>melon</kanji>s too, but they're long and funny looking. Wait, those aren't melons, they're <vocabulary>cucumber</vocabulary>s! Barbarians must have mixed them up.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

<vocabulary>Cucumber</vocabulary>s have <reading>cu</reading>te <reading>ri</reading>bs (<jp>きゅうり</jp>)! I mean just look at them. Cute little green ribs. Adorable!
Context 1-EN: Occasionally, I’ll want to eat pickled cucumbers so badly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たまに胡瓜の糠漬けが無性に食べたくなるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When people <kanji>gather</kanji> and <kanji>decide</kanji> things, they decide together, usually by <vocabulary>voting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: OK, let’s take a vote. Who wants Fugu-nabe for dinner?
Context 1-JP: <jp>じゃあ、多数決で採決しよう。夕食にてっちり（ふぐ鍋）が食べたい人は？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>method</kanji> of <kanji>writing</kanji> is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be <vocabulary>grammar</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>ほう</jp> changes to <jp>ぽう</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I'm looking for a Japanese grammar book.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語の文法の本をさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The more grammar you learn, the better your writing will become.
Context 2-JP: <jp>文法を学べば学ぶほど、文章をかくのが上手になりますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My boss looks like a smart person, so it’s too bad that he always makes grammar mistakes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の上司、見た目はできる男なのに、いつも間違った文法を使うのが残念すぎるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

As a human (we think), you have a lot of <vocabulary>skin</vocabulary>. But sometimes a normal shower isn't enough to wash all that skin. What do you do when you can't fit all your skin in the shower or the tub? You get your skin cleaned at the <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh, of course!
Context 1-EN: There were orange peels laying in the garden.
Context 1-JP: <jp>にわに、みかんの皮がおちていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I bought a small natural cowhide rug on Rakuten.
Context 2-JP: <jp>らく天で、天ねんの牛の皮でできた小さいラグをかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My jacket is made of 100% dragon skin.
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺のジャケットは、100%竜の皮でできているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I bought a kimono made from luxury brocade.
Context 1-JP: <jp>高級錦織で作られた着物を買いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is just a little more technical than <jp>目</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word "eye" (<jp>目</jp>), so use that to remember this!
Context 1-EN: Using computers to work can easily overwork your eyes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コンピュータを使う仕事は眼を酷使しやすい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji>s are <vocabulary>everywhere</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can feel the beauty of Japan everywhere in this sushi restaurant from the way the interior is decorated.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この寿司屋には、店の随所に、日本の美を感じさせるインテリアが飾られています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> is a really <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary> event. 

Also, in more recent history this has come to mean <vocabulary>very</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Acquiring Japanese is difficult, but do your best!
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語を習とくするのは大変ですが、がんばってくださいね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They had a very healthy child.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大変丈夫な子供が生まれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When there's a disaster, the phone and Internet circuits are overloaded and it gets hard to connect to them, so it's difficult to upload new blog posts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>災害時は、電話回線もネット回線も混み合って、繋がりづらくなるので、ブログの更新が大変です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fiber</kanji> you use to <kanji>maintain</kanji> your own health is the <vocabulary>fiber</vocabulary> you eat!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I eat a salad everyday and consume the perfect amount of dietary fiber.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日サラダを食べて、ちゃんと食物繊維を摂るようにしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I have an <kanji>interest</kanji> in the <kanji>flavor</kanji>... You do? Yes, I have a very deep <vocabulary>interest</vocabulary> in it.
Reading Mnemonic: As a jukugo kanji, you can guess the reading is the on'yomi kanji readings, which it is, so you should be able to read it.
Context 1-EN: I’m pretending that I have no interest in hentai games.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺はエロゲに全く興味が無いふりをしている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fee</kanji> you charge to produce your <kanji>draft</kanji> is called an <vocabulary>advance for manuscript</vocabulary>. Also known as <vocabulary>copy money</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It wasn’t much, but I got an advance for the manuscript.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わずかですが、稿料をもらいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you put <kanji>all</kanji> your <kanji>power</kanji> into something, you're putting your <vocabulary>full effort</vocabulary> into it. Hopefully that's what you put into your kanji learning as well!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I ran with all my might to the station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>えきまで、全力で走りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That Chinese woman tried her best to persuade the prince to marry her, but she failed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その中国人の女は、王子が自分とけっこんしてくれるよう全力でせっとくしたが、しっぱいにおわった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That zombie is using up all its strength trying to come back from the dead.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そのゾンビは、死から蘇ろうと全力を尽くしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you manage to make <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s of something work together you worked <vocabulary>very</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>considerably</vocabulary> hard to do it. Doing all of anything is hard so lots of work had to happen.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You did a very bold thing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>随分大胆なことをしたんですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>new</kanji>ly <kanji>construct</kanji>ed is something that's <vocabulary>newly built</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Buying a newly built house will cheer you up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新築の家でも買えば、気分が晴れるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't want to live anywhere other than a new apartment building.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新築のマンション以外には住みたくありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sad. My husband left me even though we just bought a newly built house. I need someone to talk to.
Context 3-JP: <jp>悲しいことに夫に捨てられちゃいました。新築の一軒家を買ったばっかりなのに。話を聞いてほしいんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>politics</kanji> <kanji>party</kanji> is a <vocabulary>political party</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Could you tell me what the requirements are for establishing a political party in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本での政党の成立要件を教えてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>have</kanji> a <kanji>name</kanji> (that is known to people) or you <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>famous</kanji>ness, you are probably someone who is <vocabulary>famous</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There is a famous sushi restaurant near my house.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いえの近くに、有名なすしやがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This article suddenly made Tofugu super popular.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このきじはトーフグを一やくちょう有名にした。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺は有名だけど、お前はどうよ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that has <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>private</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Think about that really <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>private</vocabulary> dude. <reading>He so</reading> (<jp>ひそ</jp>) secret...
Context 1-EN: We entered the family registry in secret, without even letting the whole family know.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕たちは、お互いの家族にも知らせず、密かに入籍をしたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Descend</kanji> off the (train) <kanji>car</kanji>. You are <vocabulary>getting off</vocabulary> a train, or a bus, or anything else with wheels.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "What did you think of that roller coaster?" "It was so intense that I threw up right after getting off."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「あのジェットコースター、どうだった？」「すっごく良かったから、降車した瞬間にゲロっちゃったよ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Be Fried Up,To Be Deep Fried,To Be Up
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. The kanji means <kanji>hoist</kanji>, but the verb most commonly means <vocabulary>to be fried up</vocabulary>, ready to eat. Imagine something being hoisted up onto the table because it's fried and ready to eat. The verb can also mean, more logically, <vocabulary>to be up</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <jp>揚げる</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The fried chicken (karaage) is fried up!
Context 1-JP: <jp>唐揚げ揚がったよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: We waited quietly until the tempura was deep fried.
Context 2-JP: <jp>天ぷらが揚がるまで静かに待っていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We'll head out once the flag is up.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>England</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is <vocabulary>English Writing</vocabulary> (or if you want to be fancy, <vocabulary>English Composition</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please write the sentence in Japanese here and add its English translation below it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここに日本語で文をかいて、その下に英文でやくを付けてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that my mother graduated from the Department of English Compositions in college in order to become a high school English teacher.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの母は高校の英語の先生になるために、大学で英文科をそつ業したそうです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, sorry to bother you, but I am kind of stuck on these English sentence translations. Could you help me?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねぇ、忙しいところ悪いんだけどさ、この英文の翻訳にちょっと手こずっちゃってるんだよね。手伝ってもらえないかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>secrecy</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji> is a <vocabulary>secret meeting</vocabulary>. You know the password?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that <jp>みつ</jp> changes to <jp>みっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: We often make use of this room for secret meetings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達は密会によくこの部屋を利用しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>meat</kanji> <kanji>want</kanji>s are your deepest desires, your <vocabulary>carnal desires</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do some Christians and Buddhists deny their carnal desires like they’re something sinful?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてキリスト教徒と仏教徒の中には、肉欲を罪深いものだとして否定する人がいるのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some <kanji>dude</kanji> who is a <kanji>slave</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>slave</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Don’t lose your cool. Don’t worry. We are still slaves now, but things will work out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そう取り乱すなよ。心配ないって。俺らはまだ奴隷だけど、そのうち何とかなるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is making one thing the <kanji>same</kanji> as another <kanji>inside</kanji> a <kanji>period of time</kanji>. You'll see this word on computer-ish things a lot. This is <vocabulary>syncing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When I was syncing my iPhone, it turned off and I was a little freaked out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>iPhone同期中に電源が切れて軽くあせった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wonder why Dropbox always freezes while syncing photos.
Context 2-JP: <jp>Dropbox、いつも写しん同期中にフリーズしてしまうのはなぜ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It will probably show up soon. My Evernote is syncing right now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>たぶんもうすぐ反映されると思う。私のエバーノート今同期中だし。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>life</kanji> and are <kanji>lively</kanji> that right there is true <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>. What is your <jp>生活</jp> like? Do you live?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please tell me the difference between American and Japanese life?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカと日本の生活のちがいをおしえてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to get back together and live with you again.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたとの生活をもう一どやり直したいんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I would be very happy if I could watch cartoons and eat marshmallows every day of my life.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎日の生活でアニメを見ながらマシュマロを食べることができたら、とても幸せです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>endure</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who can endure. Who endures everything better than anyone? A <vocabulary>ninja</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Koichi beat the ninja fair and square!
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは忍者に、正々堂々と勝負で勝った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In <kanji>reality</kanji>, <kanji>carp</kanji> are usually <vocabulary>black carp</vocabulary>. The colored ones aren't as common, people just wish they were.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I got a black carp tattoo done on my back.
Context 1-JP: <jp>真鯉の刺青を背中に彫りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who <kanji>translate</kanji>s things is a <vocabulary>translator</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you know how to read the name of this book’s translator?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この本の訳者の名前、何て読むか知ってる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It has <kanji>simplicity</kanji> and is <kanji>easy</kanji>. Whatever it is, it is <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>easy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you want to sleep over at our place, we have a cot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしうちに泊まりたいなら、簡易ベッドがあるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The things you <kanji>pass through</kanji> on your way to <kanji>work</kanji> are the things you see and run into during your <vocabulary>commute</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Commuting can eat up a lot of time, so I prefer to live near my office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>通勤は時間を浪費するので、私は職場の近くに住む方がいいですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>letters</kanji>. What do you think these are? THAT WOULD HAVE TO BE <vocabulary>UPPERCASE LETTERS</vocabulary>, RIGHT? Whoops, sorry, caps lock was on for a moment, there.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for the kanji in this word are a bit strange. The 大 portion is actually read using the kun'yomi, the same reading as you learned with 大きい (おおきい). Everything else is just on'yomi. So, you'll need to remember the one exception with 大. If you do, you should be okay.
Context 1-EN: Please capitalize the first letter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>さいしょの字は、大文字でかいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please rewrite the title in uppercase letters.
Context 2-JP: <jp>タイトルを大文字でかき直してください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: For some reason I like uppercase more than lowercase.
Context 3-JP: <jp>何故だかわからないけど、小文字より大文字の方が好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Alright, so it's not quite the same, but something that is <kanji>fresh</kanji> is also <vocabulary>vivid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. I know those are a couple things I'd associate with freshness. Try to make the connection here before moving on.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This <vocabulary>vivid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary> fresh fish is MINE! You grab the <reading>other</reading> (<jp>あざ</jp>) one that's not as vivid and splendid. This one is mine.
Context 1-EN: The new personnel manager brilliantly solved the problem regarding mandatory overtime without pay.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しい人事部長は、強制的なサービス残業に関する問題を鮮やかに解決してのけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>admonish</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to admonish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to warn</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your mom started <vocabulary>to admonish</vocabulary> you so you instantly <reading>sat</reading> (<jp>さと</jp>) down. Maybe if she sees you sat down right in front of her, looking guilty and feeling remorseful, she won't yell as hard.
Context 1-EN: Even though he scolds me, my father thinks admonishing is the solution.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの父は俺のことを叱るけど、本当は諭すのが正解だと思う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Mercury</vocabulary>. That's where we hid all of our secret moon water. Mercury looks enough like our moon, so we put it there so no one could find it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Mercury does not have an atmosphere.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水星には大気がありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This isn't what I asked for, but I've been homeless for 10 years on Mercury.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こんなはずじゃなかったんですが、もう十年も水星でホームレスをしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can only see Mercury just before sunrise and right after sunset.
Context 3-JP: <jp>水星は、日の出直前、または日没直後しか見ることができない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fat</kanji> on an animal's <kanji>body</kanji> is called <vocabulary>fatty meat</vocabulary>. Some people really like to eat it and others really like to hate it.
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>脂</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Mmm, all that <vocabulary>fatty meat</vocabulary>. Think about fatty meat on your own body. If you have a lot of fatty meat, then you need a way to support said fatty meat. To do that, you would use <reading>a bra</reading> (<jp>あぶら</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I don’t like the fatty meat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お肉の脂身って苦手なんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
Context 1-EN: My uncle works at the ward office of Chuo-ku.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私のおじは、中央区の区役所で働いています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You cannot park here because this is a no-parking district.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ここはちゅう車きん止区なので、車は止められませんよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Recently, the foreign quarter of Yokohama has suffered from an unprecedented level of violence.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ここ最近、横浜の外国人居留区では、暴力行為がかつてないほど横行している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>muscle</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> is your <vocabulary>muscle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I leave work at 7 p.m. every day and then stop by the gym on my way home to develop my muscles.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日七時に仕事を終え、筋肉を鍛えるために帰り道にジムに寄ります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>director</kanji> who is <kanji>above</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>boss</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>superior</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That boss' coat was made of very durable material.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その上司のコートは、とても丈夫な生地で出来ていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It seems that my superior is very interested in Japanese history.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの上司は、日本のれきしに大変きょう味があるようです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Shark said you are the boss in name only.
Context 3-JP: <jp>シャークがあなたのこと、名ばかりの上司だと言ってましたよ。</jp>
