Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>al</kanji> is <vocabulary>dramatic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Three months after starting my diet, my body had changed dramatically.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ダイエットを始めて三ヶ月で体型が劇的に変化しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: While it's not a dramatic increase, it does seem that they received quite a bit of revenue.
Context 2-JP: <jp>劇的とまではいかないけれど、売り上げが上がったことは間違いないようです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I got tears in my eyes when my favorite team won the game with a dramatic home run.
Context 3-JP: <jp>応援してるチームが劇的なさよならホームランで勝利を納めた時、思わずウルッときてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It is a <kanji>delight</kanji> that you come so I <kanji>welcome</kanji> you. This delight welcome is <vocabulary>a welcome</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I saw a box on the counter that had "tips welcome" written on it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カウンターの上に「チップ大歓迎」と書かれた箱がありましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If someone asks you <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> or <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>degrees</kanji> they're really trying to ask you <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary> something happened. Sometimes they're asking <vocabulary>what temperature</vocabulary> it is too.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: We all have really important moments, a few times in our lives.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人生には本当に大切なしゅん間が何度かおとずれる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu has almost been eaten by the hungry shark many times.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグは、おなかが空いたサメに食べられそうになったことが何度もある。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How many times do I have to say the same thing before you understand?
Context 3-JP: <jp>何度同じことを言えば分かるんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>one hundred</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji>s is how much? Multiply the two together and you get a <vocabulary>million</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I heard that this CD sold a million copies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このCDは、百万まいうれたそうです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are planning to make a Tofugu ornament made of gold with the million dollars we profited from WaniKani.
Context 2-JP: <jp>WaniKaniで百万ドルもうけたので、きんでできたトーフグのおきものをつくるつもりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A million people attended the AKB48 court case.
Context 3-JP: <jp>AKB48の裁判を見に、百万人の人々が法廷に出席した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>throw</kanji> and <kanji>throw away</kanji> something. That's why this means <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>投げる</jp> and <jp>捨てる</jp>, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.
Context 1-EN: I threw my alarm clock away when it went off at six this morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝、六時に目覚ましがなった時に、その時計を投げ捨ててしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You have your <kanji>home village</kanji> and your <kanji>heart</kanji>. Your heart always resides in your home village, so when you leave you feel <vocabulary>homesick</vocabulary>.

Young people don't really use this word anymore. It's more for the oldies. If you're an oldie, go right ahead. If you're a youngie, then talk to more oldies!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are double kun'yomi. The kun'yomi reading is what you learned with <jp>里</jp> already, though you'll have to pull out the <jp>心</jp> vocab reading to remember it all. Not only that, the <jp>心</jp> gets rendaku'd here making it <jp>ごころ</jp>. Make sure you watch out for that.
Context 1-EN: I’m a bit homesick.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっと里心がついちゃったんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The nostalgic melody made me homesick.
Context 2-JP: <jp>なつかしいメロディーに、里心がわいた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This puppy may be crying because he is homesick, but who cares?
Context 3-JP: <jp>この仔犬は里心がついて泣いているのかもしれないけど、そんなのかまうもんか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>詰める</jp> is "<kanji>to stuff in</kanji>" and <jp>込む</jp> is "<kanji>to be crowded</kanji>." So when you stuff something and crowd it up, you are going <vocabulary>to stuff</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cram</vocabulary> it in.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be fine here.
Context 1-EN: I managed to cram all my clothes into my suitcase.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なんとか洋服を全部スーツケースに詰め込めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>blood</kanji> <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>type</kanji> is your <vocabulary>blood type</vocabulary>. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, at least the <jp>血液</jp> part. The <jp>型</jp> uses the kun'yomi reading, probably because it's an add-on word.
Context 1-EN: I don’t like people whose blood type is B.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は血液型がB型の人が苦手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>write</kanji> something on this paper but it is <kanji>crowded</kanji>. Why is it crowded? Because there are little boxes for you to write things in. You are filling out a form, which makes this verb <vocabulary>to fill out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to write in</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>書く</jp> and <jp>込む</jp> combined into one.
Context 1-EN: You better hurry up and fill out an application. The office will close in ten minutes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>急いで申込書に書き込んだ方がいいよ。あと十分で事務所は閉まっちゃうんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return home</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return home</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word! 

This word has a pair verb though, so you'll want to remember the <jp>る</jp> ending. Just imagine how <reading>ru</reading>de (<jp>る</jp>) it is when someone goes home without saying goodbye. The nerve!
Context 1-EN: Kanae distributed souvenirs to her colleagues after she had come back from Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カナエちゃんは、日本から帰ってきて、オフィスの人におみやげを配りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I couldn't figure out the answer to the question asking to put the word "to like" in the past tense, so I just went home.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「好む」という単語をか去形にしなさい、という問題の答えが分からないまま、家に帰りました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m hungry and my legs are sore," Bilbo said, just before turning to return home to the Shire.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「お腹が空いたし足が痛いよ」と、ホビット庄に帰るちょっと前にビルボーは言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is <kanji>real</kanji> is <kanji>right</kanji>. It is the <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. It is also the <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary>. Don't believe anything that is not real and right.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Is that true?
Context 1-JP: <jp>それは本当ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that these days university students write essays on their smart phones, but I wonder if that's true.
Context 2-JP: <jp>さいきんの大学生はスマホでレポートをかくってきいたけど、本当かなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I am going to <kanji>descend</kanji> my <kanji>participat</kanji>ion in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to <vocabulary>surrender</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I haven’t given up yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はまだ降参していません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>召す</jp> can mean "to respectfully eat," so adding <jp>上がる</jp>, "to rise," means you're lifting the other person up. In polite language you use this when you're talking to someone higher up than you so you have to raise the humbly eating up. So it still means <vocabulary>to respectfully eat</vocabulary>, but raising it makes it a higher politeness level.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>召す</jp> and <jp>上がる</jp> that you learned already. <jp>召す</jp> becomes <jp>召し</jp> and then you add that to <jp>上がる</jp>. Pretty straightforward, right?
Context 1-EN: Please eat if you’d like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしよければお召し上がり下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in <kanji>letter</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>typo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: For now, all you have to do is find typos.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とりあえず今は誤字脱字を見つけてくれればそれでいいから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>brocade</kanji> <kanji>carp</kanji> is a fancy way of saying it's a carp that has a lot of pretty colors on it. It's a <vocabulary>colored carp</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>colored koi</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I released the colored carp into the garden pond.
Context 1-JP: <jp>庭の池に錦鯉を放ちました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know the word <jp>足りる</jp> from Level 4. What is this one? it's the opposite (negative form on a verb is <jp>ない</jp>). So, what is the opposite of <jp>足りる</jp> (To be sufficient)? The opposite is <vocabulary>to not be sufficient</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>not enough</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>足りる</jp> (<jp>たりる</jp>) which you should have seen in Level 4.
Context 1-EN: I’m ten yen short.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お金が十円足りないんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If there is insufficient space, attach a separate sheet with additional information.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もしスペースが足りなければ、べつの用しについきして、それをてんぷしてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Bill Gates is my son, but there isn’t enough evidence to prove it yet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビル・ゲイツは私の息子なのだが、それを証明するための証拠がまだ足りない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Describe</kanji> someone's <kanji>merit</kanji> at a ceremony for the <vocabulary>conferring of decorations</vocabulary>. That's when medals are given out to people who deserve them. Usually in the military or something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Every year, in spring and fall, the spring and fall conferring of decorations is carried out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎年、春と秋に春秋叙勲が実施されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>pure</kanji> <kanji>fur</kanji> is pure fur... but what kind of fur? In this case it's wool, making this mean <vocabulary>all wool</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My new all-wool sweater prickles and makes me itchy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しい純毛のセーター、チクチクして痒いんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji> out a <kanji>song</kanji> makes it an even longer, more confusing <vocabulary>song</vocabulary>. But it's still a song nonetheless!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Let’s tie up today’s karaoke with a Noh song from the Showa era.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日のカラオケは、昭和歌謡縛りにしよう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>God</kanji> is <kanji>holy</kanji>. Everything about a holy god is full of <vocabulary>holiness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The villagers have a holy respect for nature.
Context 1-JP: <jp>村人たちは、自然に対し神聖な敬意を持っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>込む</jp> means "to be crowded" so when you are crowded with people... well... you have a <vocabulary>crowd of people</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>人</jp> and <jp>込む</jp> combined together into one. Just keep in mind that the <jp>こ</jp> from <jp>込み</jp> changes to <jp>ご</jp> and you'll be fine.
Context 1-EN: I can't go into the middle of a crowd of people because I'm scared.
Context 1-JP: <jp>怖くて人込みの中に行けません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I walk inside Shinjuku Station, I always get frustrated with the crowds of people.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新宿駅構内を歩く時は、人込みでいつもイライラする。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>あいつら、人込みに紛れて俺に浣腸しようとしてやがるんだ。お前らは俺を守ってくれるよなあ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Okay... so before I get into this, you can't get mad at me. I didn't make this word up. I didn't make the Japanese language and I have nothing to do with this. And don't blame Japanese people for it either.

So apparently a <kanji>stupid</kanji> <kanji>Chinese</kanji> person is a <vocabulary>molester</vocabulary>. Our theory is, that in China "Chinese" just meant "person" so a molester was just a stupid person. But in Japanese we think of <jp>漢</jp> as Chinese, so there you go. Either way, you'll probably never ever forget this one. You're welcome!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The molester was arrested this morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝、痴漢を逮捕しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If your <kanji>neglect</kanji> of family members goes too <kanji>far</kanji> you'll end up with <vocabulary>estrangement</vocabulary> in your relationships with them. And they'll probably <vocabulary>neglect</vocabulary> you as much as you neglect them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: With that, I became estranged from my older sister.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それっきり、姉とは疎遠になっているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>垂らす</jp> is "to dangle something" then this is <vocabulary>to dangle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drip</vocabulary>. You're not doing the dangling, which is rare (<jp>れる</jp>), because usually it's you who's doing the dangling.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>垂らす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Say! Isn’t it said that breastfeeding causes saggy breasts?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ほら！母乳だと乳が垂れるって言うじゃない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>宣言</jp> is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be <vocabulary>to proclaim</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Don’t you think that the Japanese government should have declared a state of emergency at the time?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの時、日本政府は非常事態を宣言するべきだったと思わないかい。</jp>

Meaning: To Heap Up,To Pile Up,To Liven Up,To Stir Up
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>盛る</jp> is "to heap up." If you "raise" (<jp>上げる</jp>) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word <vocabulary>to heap up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pile up</vocabulary>. This word is also used when you want <vocabulary>to liven up</vocabulary> some things. Heap up that energy and stir things up!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>盛る</jp> and <jp>上げる</jp>. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: My buddy is ridiculously interesting and he’s great at livening up parties.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の友達はメチャクチャ面白くて、パーティーを盛り上げるのが得意なんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>collect</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to collect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you only have one thing, there's only one thing. Nothing is collected. But when you have two... "<reading>ah two</reading>!" (<jp>あつ</jp>). Now you're starting <vocabulary>to collect</vocabulary> things.
Context 1-EN: Please assemble the people wearing blue shirts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>青いシャツをきている人を集めてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We've been gathering feedback from users.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ユーザーからのフィードバックを集めています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am collecting pictures of foreign food.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は外国の食べ物の写真を集めている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Remember <jp>広い</jp>? Well this is like that, except a verb. When something does the action of getting <kanji>wide</kanji>, it means <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to extend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to stretch</vocabulary>.

You already learned <jp>広げる</jp>, which is used when YOU spread something. <jp>広がる</jp>, on the other hand, means that something spreads out all on its own. It's worth mentioning that lots of intransitive verbs end in <jp>がる</jp>, and this is no exception. Just think how about a girl (<jp>がる</jp>) you know can do everything all by herself. She never needs help from anyone else.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>広い</jp>, too, so as long as you knew that you knew this reading as well.
Context 1-EN: Sorry, my jeans won’t allow my legs to spread any further.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ごめんなさい。ジーンズのせいで私の足はこれ以上広がりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This wildfire might spread to the state of Oregon by the end of this week.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この山火じは、今しゅうまつにもオレゴンしゅうまで広がってしまうかもしれない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The lavender field stretched out as far as the eye could see.
Context 3-JP: <jp>見わたす限りラベンダ畑が広がっていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>大学</jp> means "college?" Well the <kanji>institution</kanji> you go to after college is <vocabulary>graduate school</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I graduated from grad school, but I can’t find a job.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学院をそつぎょうしたんだけど、仕事が見つからないんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You can only buy cold drinks from the vending machines at this grad school.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この大学院の自どうはん売きは、つめたい飲み物しか売っていません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m thinking about going to graduate school.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は大学院進学を考えております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>government office</kanji> <kanji>cottage</kanji> is the place where the government office is stored. That's the <vocabulary>government office building</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I heard that the government office building was struck by lightning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>庁舎に雷が落ちたみたいだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Isn't that fencetastic?
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Just think about the <reading>sack</reading> (<jp>さく</jp>) hanging on the <vocabulary>fence</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: My leg got stuck in the fence and I can't get it out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>柵に足がはさまって抜けない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll paint the fence this afternoon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日の午後は柵をペンキでぬります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That dog jumped over the fence so easily.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その犬は柵を軽々と跳び越えてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Bake</kanji>d <kanji>potato</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>baked sweet potato</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>roast sweet potato</vocabulary>). Although it's literally just potato, most Japanese speakers will automatically think of sweet potato when they hear this word. Yum! 🍠
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings from <jp>焼く</jp> and <jp>芋</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: My boyfriend is such a jerk! He ate my roasted sweet potato that I’d been really, really looking forward to eating.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の彼氏、本当にムカつくんだけど！私がすっごくすっごく楽しみしてた焼き芋、食べちゃったの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Who has a <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>? Only one person that I know of, and that's a <vocabulary>student</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Which parts will students study at home today?
Context 1-JP: <jp>学生は今日、うちでどこをべんきょうしますか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>学生わり引ってありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "We are all students of life," my dad said while farting.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「我々はみな人生の学生だ。」と言いながら、父はおならをした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>solemn</kanji> by your<kanji>self</kanji>, you have a lot of <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary>. You don't need anyone to tell you to be that way, you have your own <vocabulary>self discipline</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: With the staff scandal coming to light, all employees are to restrain themselves from doing business activities today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>役員の不祥事発覚を受け、本日は全社員が営業活動を自粛致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you get someone to <kanji>transmit</kanji> information, they're a type of <vocabulary>intermediary</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>go-between</vocabulary>, if you will.
Reading Mnemonic:
When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

When the <vocabulary>go-between</vocabulary> gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him <reading>two ta</reading>kes (<jp>つて</jp>) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second.

Little side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in <jp>ツテ</jp>, or hiragana, as in <jp>つて</jp>. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!
Context 1-EN: I want to tell my uncle that my mom passed away, but I don't have a way to get in touch with him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母が亡くなったことを伝えたいんですが、おじさんにはれんらくする伝がないんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got a job at Tofugu through my connections.
Context 2-JP: <jp>伝をたよって、トーフグにしゅうしょくしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: But I think some kind of intermediary would be good.
Context 3-JP: <jp>誰かの伝があるといいんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is <kanji>flat</kanji> and <kanji>relax</kanji>ed. That is you. What words does that describe? To me, that would be <vocabulary>peace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tranquility</vocabulary>. Just imagine something that is flat and relaxed, like a field of grass with happy people in it. It's so <vocabulary>peaceful</vocabulary>! It's so <vocabulary>tranquil</vocabulary>! This is also the way you write the <vocabulary>Heian</vocabulary> period of Japanese history.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When was the Heian period?
Context 1-JP: <jp>平安じだいはいつですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The WaniKani forums don't have any trolls, so it gives me peace of mind.
Context 2-JP: <jp>平安をみだす人がいないワニカニフォーラムは、わたしの心に平安をあたえてくれる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Walking through the old growth forests in British Columbia was so peaceful.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ブリティッシュコロンビアの古の森を歩く時、心に平安を感じる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Restore</kanji> to the <kanji>former</kanji> self. This is <vocabulary>restoration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Viet is working his hardest to restore the Tofugu system right now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトがTofuguのシステム復旧のために今一生懸命頑張っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>勤める</jp> is "to be employed at," then the noun version of this is <vocabulary>work</vocabulary>. I mean, I really hope you're doing work at the place that employed you... if not you'll probably be fired.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>勤める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Who do you work for?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お勤め先はどちらですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We are of the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>alliance</kanji>. We are in an <vocabulary>alliance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Oh, now I see what happened. Tofugu formed an alliance with its closest competitor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ああ、そういうことか。Tofuguは一番のライバル会社と同盟を組んだんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>star</kanji> named after the <kanji>king</kanji> of the <kanji>ocean</kanji> is <vocabulary>Neptune</vocabulary>! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Neptune is the eighth planet from the sun.
Context 1-JP: <jp>海王星は、太ようから八ばん目のわく星です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've always dreamed of going to Neptune.
Context 2-JP: <jp>海王星に行くことをずっとゆめ見てきたんです。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>海王星は1846年9月23日に発見されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>ご</jp> just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (<kanji>meal</kanji>) making it <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>, but it also refers to <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary> as well. So, "Come eat your <jp>ご飯</jp>" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "<reading>han</reading>d" me another bowl of rice?
Context 1-EN: Recently we haven't been able to get our meal timing right, have we?
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近わたしたち、ご飯を食べるタイミングが合わなくてすれちがってばかりだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Damn it! I just spilled my rice.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しまった！ご飯こぼしちゃった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why is there a big ball of dried-up, cooked rice in Koichi's desk drawer?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうしてコウイチのデスクの引き出しには乾いたご飯の塊が入っているの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>映る</jp> is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is <vocabulary>to project</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>映る</jp>. So long as you know the reading of <jp>映る</jp> you should be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: Can you start projecting slides onto the screen for me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>スクリーンにスライドを映し始めてもらえますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why don't we use this white wall as a screen to project the movie?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この白いかべをスクリーン代わりにして映画を映すのはどうでしょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Only Viet knows that Koichi really likes seeing himself reflected full-length in the mirror.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトだけが、コウイチが鏡に全身を映すのが好きだということを知っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Present</kanji> and <kanji>expose</kanji> wrongdoing to get proper <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>. The world needs <vocabulary>disclosure</vocabulary> and so do you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Their cheating was completely exposed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつがしていたインチキが全部露呈したんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You only hold someone in <kanji>high</kanji> <kanji>esteem</kanji> if they are really <vocabulary>high</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>noble</vocabulary> people. They have to be <vocabulary>refined</vocabulary> to be held so highly by you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You have such refined tastes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>高尚な趣味をお持ちなんですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I will <kanji>determine</kanji> what you are <kanji>infer</kanji>ring via an <vocabulary>estimate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The guy, who is a savant, estimated the scope of the crowd to have 534 people and he was exactly right.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのサバンの男は群衆の規模を534人と推定したのだが、実際の数とピッタリ当っていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>alert</kanji> is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. That is pretty <vocabulary>quick</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary>. Machines can move and think so much faster than us, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Waitresses are supposed to move quickly, but she is ridiculously slow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ウェイトレスってのは機敏に動くものなのに、彼女はとんでもなく鈍いんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: When you read books do you use a bookmark?
Context 1-JP: <jp>本を読む時に栞は使いますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>candidate</kanji> is <kanji>someone</kanji> who's a <kanji>supplement</kanji> to the entire political system. Despite being a supplement, they're still a <vocabulary>candidate</vocabulary> nonetheless, unless they can win!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Academically speaking, the candidate would be very useful, but he has such a bad personality.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学歴的には、候補者として十分通用するはずが、彼は性格に難があるからね。</jp>

Meaning: To Ask For,To Request,To Entrust,To Rely On
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>trust</kanji>, but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to ask for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rely on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>. When you trust someone you can <jp>頼む</jp> them, but only when you trust them. You put it in their hands. You trust them, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: But, you're entrusting this task to your friend not because you are busy, but because you want to go have a <reading><jp>楽</jp></reading> time at the waterpark. Sucker!
Context 1-EN: "When do you need boiled crabigator by?" "I need it as soon as possible."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「茹でたワニカニ、いつまでに必要ですか？」「できるだけ早く頼むよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A ____<kanji>pot</kanji> is any kind of food that's made inside the pot, put together, and cooked. This refers to a type of <vocabulary>pot</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>stew</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotpot</vocabulary>, and is attached onto the names of said pots, stews, and hotpots.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Have you ever tried soy milk hotpot?
Context 1-JP: <jp>豆乳鍋を食べてみたことはありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned the <jp>どん</jp> reading for this kanji. This reading is just an extension of that, coming out to <jp>どんぶり</jp>. You can remember the <jp>ぶり</jp> part because you know what your favorite rice bowl is... it's a <reading>brie</reading> (<jp>ぶり</jp>) cheese rice bowl. So delicious, yum.
Context 1-EN: I'd like to buy some tableware in America, like Japanese rice bowls, but I can't find the right size!
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカで日本の丼みたいな食器を買いたいんですが、ちょうどいいサイズのがないんですよね〜。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hey, there was dried-up natto in that rice bowl!
Context 2-JP: <jp>ねえ、あの丼の中に干からびた納豆が入ってたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You're eating a crab bowl in the morning? You're a real morning person, aren't you?
Context 3-JP: <jp>朝から蟹丼なんて食べてるの？あんたって、本当に朝型人間ね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're <kanji>sing</kanji>ing and you're <kanji>chant</kanji>ing. It's a gay ol' time. You're <vocabulary>singing</vocabulary> and singing and singing!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>North</kanji> area of Japan is called <vocabulary>Tohoku</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>Tohoku region</vocabulary>. It was the region hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake. This can also mean <vocabulary>northeast region</vocabulary> when talking about China or Japan, but for other countries (and for the direction) we'd use <jp>北東</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Tray</kanji> <kanji>planting</kanji> is <vocabulary>bonsai</vocabulary>. It makes sense because that is exactly what you're doing: planting a tree in a tray!

Meaning Mnemonic: On the <kanji>second day</kanji>, you experience your <kanji>drunk</kanji>enness a different way... in the form of a <vocabulary>hangover</vocabulary>.

Context 1-JP: <jp>二日酔いだし、足もつるし今日は最悪だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A one's self (<jp>自己</jp>) introduction (<jp>紹介</jp>) is a <vocabulary>self introduction</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>praise</kanji> you for your <kanji>beauty</kanji>. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a <vocabulary>reward</vocabulary>... a <vocabulary>prize</vocabulary>, basically.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning: To Fire,To Hit,To Break Wind,To Let Loose,To Set Free
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned the verbs <jp>放す</jp> and <jp>放れる</jp> but this one is a little different. This is a specific kind of releasing. It means <vocabulary>to fire</vocabulary> an arrow, or <vocabulary>to hit</vocabulary> a baseball. It even works when you're releasing a fart. Yes, it means <vocabulary>to break wind</vocabulary> too. What a great word!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: Koichi is known for being a volleyball player that can serve a very sharp curveball.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、するどく変化するサーブを放つバレーボール選手として知られている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That player let out a stinky fart as soon as he hit a home run.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その選手は、ホームランを放ったしゅん間、くさいオナラも放った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When are you thinking of letting this bird out of the cage?
Context 3-JP: <jp>この鳥をいつか籠から放つつもりですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>industry</kanji> is the <vocabulary>fishing industry</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fishery</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Until the <kanji>end</kanji> of <kanji>somebody</kanji>, you will be <kanji>punish</kanji>ed. If you are punished to your end, you are being given a <vocabulary>life sentence</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is <kanji>dilute</kanji>d to the point of <kanji>weak</kanji>ness. It has much <vocabulary>weakness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>feebleness</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>carve</kanji> is very <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>甲状腺異常のある日本の子どもたちの数が増えているのは、深刻な問題です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Famous</kanji> <kanji>music</kanji> that you know the <kanji>name</kanji> of is <vocabulary>famous music</vocabulary>.

Meaning: To Shake Something,To Wave Something,To Swing Something,To Break Up With Someone
Meaning Mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> and this verb is transitive, meaning that you're shaking something. So this verb means <vocabulary>to shake something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to wave something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to swing something</vocabulary>. You'll often see it paired with <jp>手</jp>, as in <jp>手を振る</jp>, meaning "to wave one's hand" or, as we'd usually say in English, simply "to wave".

This word can also be used when you shake someone off in the less physical way, as in <vocabulary>to break up with someone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Someone is trying <vocabulary>to shake something</vocabulary>. And unfortunately, that something is you. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally <reading>full</reading> (<jp>ふる</jp>), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).
Context 1-EN: Please shake it well before drinking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>よく振ってから飲んでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi nodded his head, but Viet shook his head.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは首をたてに振ったが、ビエトは首を横に振った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I can’t believe he broke up with me." "You cheated on him. You had it coming."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「彼に振られたなんて信じられない。」「あんた、浮気してたんでしょ。自業自得だよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I want to <kanji>recruit</kanji> some people, so let's <kanji>gather</kanji> them up and do some <vocabulary>recruiting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>solicitation</vocabulary> to get them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>recruit</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are trying to raise money, aka you are <vocabulary>fundraising</vocabulary>.

Context 1-EN: Could you break a ten thousand yen bill? If you can I’ll donate a thousand yen to your fundraiser.

Meaning Mnemonic: If you are <kanji>tenacious</kanji> you will be able <vocabulary>to take control</vocabulary> of and <vocabulary>to carry out</vocabulary> any plan you want. You are tenacious, you are.
Reading Mnemonic: Notice how the word "take" is in this verb. If you take something, you might say <jp>取る</jp>. This word shares take's reading.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>賛成</jp> portion means <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>support</vocabulary>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to agree</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I agree that it’s a game we must win by any means necessary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それがどんな汚い手を使ってでも勝たなきゃいけない試合だってことには賛成するよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.
Context 1-EN: One leaf fell lightly to the ground.

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>夏休み</jp> and <jp>冬休み</jp>. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a <kanji>spring</kanji> <kanji>rest</kanji> of some kind. That would be a <vocabulary>spring break</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>spring vacation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>春</jp> is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The <jp>休み</jp> part is the same as the vocab word <jp>休み</jp>, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

Context 3-EN: Are you over your cold yet? It sucks having a cold during spring break, eh? If it’s still bad, don’t stay up late. Get well soon.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Present</kanji> your findings in <kanji>advance</kanji> during an early <vocabulary>presentation</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: If everyone is acting <kanji>solemn</kanji> and <kanji>strict</kanji> then you should probably pay special attention to the <vocabulary>gravity</vocabulary> of the situation you're in. Don't start playing the trumpet when you're supposed to be bowing your head!

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>. This is when something does this on its own. Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>neighbor</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is a <vocabulary>neighboring country</vocabulary>. For us, our <jp>隣国</jp> in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell...

Meaning: Genius,Person Of Exceptional Talent,Exceptionally Talented Person

It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>older brother</kanji> is <kanji>valuable</kanji> to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary>. P.S. You'll often see some gangstah thug call a higher ranking gangstah thug (one that acts like an older brother to all the other gangstah thugs) this. It's like family within the gang.

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>arrange</kanji>, and the verb version also means <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put in order</vocabulary>. This has to do with putting things in their rightful place, getting affairs in order, or even preparing equipment.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everything in your room has finally been <vocabulary>put in order</vocabulary>. Just as you finish, you hear a crash and turn to see your dog has jumped up onto your desk. "<reading>Toto no</reading> (<jp>ととの</jp>)!" you yell as he knocks everything over. Guess you have  <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>  it all over again. Dammit Toto.
Context 1-EN: Viet arranges his mustache into a triangle every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトは、口ひげが三角になるように毎日整えています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My older brother put all the things in order regarding our father's funeral.
Context 2-JP: <jp>父のそうぎの手はずは、兄が全て整えてくれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We’ll introduce you to methods for getting your hormone balance in order.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ホルモンバランスを整える方法をご紹介致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Look at a <kanji>chapter</kanji> on <kanji>family crest</kanji>s in that book and you'll see every <vocabulary>crest</vocabulary> in your area.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is the royal family’s crest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、王家の紋章です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji> for <kanji>juvenile</kanji>s are <vocabulary>nursery rhyme</vocabulary>s. Kids won't understand the heavy stuff, so you have to dumb it down for them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve learned new nursery rhymes in kindergarten.
Context 1-JP: <jp>幼稚園で新しい童謡を習ってきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Back in the day, a <kanji>bullet</kanji> was a <kanji>circle</kanji> shape. So, this word is <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>弾</jp> part is okay, but you never learned the on'yomi reading of <jp>丸</jp>, which is <jp>がん</jp>. When you shoot a bullet, you are using a <reading>gun</reading> (<jp>がん</jp>). Bang!
Context 1-EN: I expertly dodged a spray of bullets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺は弾丸の雨をとても上手くかわした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember <jp>球</jp>? This is also a bullet shape (remember how bullets used to be round spheres?). These are both similar ideas, though their intent is different, and they share the same reading.
Context 1-EN: My poop was shaped like a bullet for a gun the other day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先日、銃の弾のようなかたちの便が出た。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>patrol</kanji> of <kanji>thanks</kanji> is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a <vocabulary>pilgrimage</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve decided to go on a pilgrimage to sacred places around the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>世界中の聖地を巡礼しようと決心しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>gloom</kanji>y <kanji>energy</kanji> has filled the room. This makes for a <vocabulary>gloomy</vocabulary> feeling. One of <vocabulary>melancholy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of <jp>鬱</jp> or you'll feel gloomy.
Context 1-EN: My uncle's been home feeling melancholy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>伯父は、鬱気で家でふさぎ込んでいる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This song can really blow the gloom away.
Context 2-JP: <jp>鬱気を吹き飛ばしてくれるような歌ですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My depression's bothering me today and I can't get myself to study Japanese.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日は鬱気が邪魔をして、日本語を勉強する気になれません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Their death was too soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その死は早すぎました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: People cannot escape death, except for Koichi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>人は死をのがれることはできない…コウイチい外は。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m stricken with grief over the death of my pet dog.
Context 3-JP: <jp>愛犬の死に打ちひしがれています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji>. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an <vocabulary>opera</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This opera's main character is a natural-born Frenchman.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その歌劇の主人公は生粋のフランス人です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I played the role of a slave in an opera.
Context 2-JP: <jp>とある歌劇で、奴隷の役を演じました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We are going to increase our opera ticket prices by 2%.
Context 3-JP: <jp>歌劇のチケットの値段を2%値上げします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When something leaves <vocabulary>traces</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary>s behind, it's because they were there, but now they're gone, and you've come <reading><jp>後</jp></reading> (<jp>あと</jp>) they left.
Context 1-EN: Her lips left marks on the wine glass and I traced it with my finger.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は、ワイングラスに付いた彼女の唇の跡を指でなぞった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>listen</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji>, is someone who listens. This is a <vocabulary>listener</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

For this word, most often you'll hear the word <jp>リスナー</jp> but this is a kanji learning site, so you're going to be learning yourself some kanji, you hear?
Context 1-EN: Something might be wrong with the phone because it’s weird that no listeners have called in.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電話が壊れてるのかも。だって、聴者から電話が一本もないなんて、おかしいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some <kanji>odd</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are left over here. We don't really understand what happened, because it was a <vocabulary>miracle</vocabulary>, but it certainly left some odd traces behind.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Unless there is a miracle, a hundred people won’t be able to fart at the same time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奇跡でも起こらない限り、百人が同時におならをするのは不可能でしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something is <kanji>burdensome</kanji> to the <kanji>eye</kanji> (when you look at it), you know that that thing is <vocabulary>not good</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hopeless</vocabulary>. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean <vocabulary>not allowed</vocabulary>. Parents say this to their kids all the time.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: You absolutely cannot go on a trip with a boy!
Context 1-JP: <jp>男の子と旅行に行くのは、絶対に駄目ですからね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone on <kanji>sharp</kanji> <kanji>alert</kanji> has a <vocabulary>sharpness</vocabulary> about them. They are <vocabulary>quick witted</vocabulary> and have a strong <vocabulary>keenness</vocabulary> to them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That dog’s keen nose caught so many drug dealers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その犬の鋭敏な嗅覚は、何人もの麻薬密売人を捕らえました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading that you learned with the kanji, probably because it normally gets added on to other things, like the names of the state. Examples: <jp>カリフォルニア州</jp>, <jp>ニューヨーク州</jp>, etc.
Context 1-EN: I’m from New York state.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ニューヨーク州の出しんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are fifty states in the United States.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカがっしゅう国には、五十の州があります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The headquarters of Tofugu is located in Portland, Oregon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>オレゴン州ポートランド市には、Tofuguの本社がある。</jp>

Meaning: To Irritate,To Annoy,To Affect Negatively,To Be Bad For
Meaning Mnemonic: This is the verb version of <kanji>hinder</kanji>, but it's what happens when you hinder someone else enough. You'll start <vocabulary>to irritate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to annoy</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want <vocabulary>to irritate</vocabulary> me, all you have to do is make what I'm eating <reading>sou</reading>r (<jp>さわ</jp>). Did you know sour food is known <vocabulary>to be bad for</vocabulary> you, too? Don't make that sour face, stop eating sour things!
Context 1-EN: Sometimes her shrill voice can be really irritating.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の金切り声が時々癪に障るんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>映画</jp> in level 13. A <kanji>public building</kanji> for <kanji>movie</kanji>s (<jp>映画</jp>) is a <vocabulary>movie theater</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When I come back to this town next time, I guess this movie theater will be completed and it will change the townscape quite a bit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>次にこの町にくる時には、この映画館が完成して町なみもずいぶん変わってるんだろうね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The long holiday is over now, so the movie theater will probably be very quiet for a while.
Context 2-JP: <jp>れん休も終わったし、あの映画館多分しばらくガラガラだろうね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Would you like to go to the movie theater tonight?" "I wish I could but I have to finish this paper."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「今夜、映画館に行かない？」「そうできればいいんだけど、このレポートを仕上げなくちゃいけないんだ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>look to</kanji> the <kanji>sea</kanji>, you are <vocabulary>seaside</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>coastal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Many Japanese students experience going to seaside schools during the summer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の学生の多くは、夏に臨海学校に行く事を経験します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>贈る</jp>, which means "to give a present"? A <kanji>thing</kanji> that you give as a <kanji>present</kanji> is <vocabulary>a present</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>贈る</jp> and <jp>物</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "Here’s a present for you. It’s dried Fugu. I hope you like it." "Thank you. Just hearing that makes me happy."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「これ、君への贈り物。干しふぐだよ。気に入ってもらえるといいけど。」「有難う。聞いただけで既にとっても気に入ったわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that this has something to do with <kanji>read</kanji>ing and you know that <jp>方</jp> means <kanji>way</kanji> or <kanji>method</kanji>. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as <vocabulary>reading</vocabulary> (aka the reading of a word) or <vocabulary>pronunciation</vocabulary>. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're the readings you've learned with the kanji. <jp>方</jp> is like many other words you've come across as well, such as <jp>見方</jp> or <jp>作り方</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I can’t read sheet music.
Context 1-JP: <jp>楽ふの読み方を知らない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How do you read this word in the 7th line of the 3rd paragraph?
Context 2-JP: <jp>三だんらく目の七行目のこのたん語の読み方は、なんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please tell me how to pronounce the kanji in your name.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの名前の漢字の読み方を教えてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Whittle down</kanji> and <kanji>exclude</kanji> this item from the list. Time to remove it. It's <vocabulary>deletion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s gonna take some time to delete all your pictures off the Internet, but it’s not impossible for me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>インターネット上からあんたの写真を全部削除するのは、時間はかかるだろうけど、俺の手に掛かれば不可能じゃないね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There are <kanji>not</kanji> any <kanji>shake</kanji>s or <kanji>waves</kanji> or anything fun like that. It is just pure <vocabulary>dullness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My CD was suffering from a slump in sales for a little while, but since being introduced on the radio, sales are rising again this month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私のCDはしばらく売上不振に苦しんでいたが、ラジオで紹介されてから今月は売上げが上昇しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>pledge</kanji> myself to the <kanji>machine</kanji>s. It is my only <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary> to survive the upcoming machine apocalypse.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Coughing up blood was my opportunity to give up smoking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>吐血したのを契機に、煙草を止めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are <kanji>favor</kanji>ed with <kanji>know</kanji>ing things. You have <vocabulary>wisdom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intelligence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I racked my brain to write this love letter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>無い知恵を絞ってこのラブレターを書いたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>diagram</kanji> of the <kanji>earth</kanji>. What could that be other than a <vocabulary>map</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I got out the map on my smartphone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スマートフォンで地図を出しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I walked around Tokyo with a map.
Context 2-JP: <jp>地図をかた手に東京を歩きました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Teacher, if you forget your world map I have one tattoo'd on my forehead.
Context 3-JP: <jp>先生、もし世界地図を忘れたのなら、私の額にタトゥーの世界地図がありますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>government</kanji> behind a <kanji>curtain</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bakufu</vocabulary>. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>幕</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you try to peek through the <vocabulary>bakufu</vocabulary>'s curtain you'll only see someone's <reading>back</reading> (<jp>ばく</jp>). They all huddle together to discuss things so a row of hunched backs is all you'll get out of the shogunate. That's not helpful.
Context 1-EN: The bakufu slaughtered my family.
Context 1-JP: <jp>幕府が俺の家族を皆殺しにした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Everything that happened <kanji>since</kanji> you <kanji>descend</kanji>ed some stairs, is <vocabulary>hereafter</vocabulary>. It's all <vocabulary>after</vocabulary> the stairs thing you did, <vocabulary>since</vocabulary> you did it already.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The answer will be next week or after.
Context 1-JP: <jp>返事は来週以降になります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you call us again on or after August third?
Context 2-JP: <jp>八月三日以降にもう一度ご連絡していただけますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dad forbids me from going out after 9 p.m.
Context 3-JP: <jp>夜九時以降の外出は父に禁止されているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Poison</kanji> <kanji>inside</kanji> the <kanji>food</kanji> is <vocabulary>food poisoning</vocabulary>. No fun when you get this :(
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm terribly sorry that I took a day off because of food poisoning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>食中毒で会社を休んでしまい、大変申しわけありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Thank you so much for your helpful information on how to get over food poisoning from eating Häagen-Dazs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ハーゲンダッツを食べて食中毒を乗りこえるというとても役立つ情ほうを教えてくれて、本当にありがとうございました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu gave me a lecture about the risks of food poisoning, but his explanation was very hard to understand.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグが私に食中毒の危険性をレクチャーしてくれたんだけどさぁ、説明がすっごく分かりにくかったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning: To Spin,To Turn Over,To Reel In,To Shuffle
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>spin</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to spin</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is used here.
Context 1-EN: Oops. I’m sorry. I’m bad at shuffling cards.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おっと。すみません。トランプを繰るのが苦手なんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You send your <kanji>best regards</kanji> to everyone. Is this <vocabulary>good</vocabulary>? Is it <vocabulary>okay?</vocabulary> Is it <vocabulary>all right</vocabulary>? Yes, of course, how nice of you.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Is it okay for me to put my bag here?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここに鞄を置かせてもらっても宜しいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>遠慮</jp> is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decline</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to restrain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from <jp>遠慮</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Tomorrow is my physical check-up, so I’d rather not have alcohol today, if that’s okay.
Context 1-JP: <jp>明日、健康診断なので、できれば今日はお酒はご遠慮させてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>as much as you want</kanji>, you are getting an <vocabulary>all you can eat</vocabulary> deal.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading consists of the readings of <jp>食べる</jp> and <jp>放題</jp>. If you know those you should be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: I feel like my memory of going to the all you can eat restaurant with you is growing distant.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一しょに食べ放題に行ったのが、とおい昔のような気がするよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I went to an all-you-can-eat cake cafe in Japan and I was actually able to eat more than I'd expected.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本で、ケーキ食べ放題のカフェに行ってみたんですが、思っていたよりもたくさん食べられました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Ok, the coast is clear. Let’s go get all you can eat yakiniku.
Context 3-JP: <jp>よし、今がチャンスだ。さあ、焼き肉食べ放題へ行こう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>休み</jp> means "break?" When you take a break at <kanji>noon</kanji> it's your <vocabulary>lunch break</vocabulary>! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a <vocabulary>noon break</vocabulary> instead.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: Oh my! Lunch break is in five minutes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大変だ！あと五分で昼休みだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The katsudon I ate today during my lunch break was very delicious.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日の昼休みに食べたカツどんは、大変美味しかったです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm gonna change into a yukata during the noon break.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昼休みにゆかたに着がえるつもりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Drink</kanji>ing <kanji>as much as you want</kanji> is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an <vocabulary>all you can drink</vocabulary> place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the word <jp>放題</jp> (<jp>ほうだい</jp>) and <jp>飲む</jp> (<jp>のむ</jp>). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: I wonder which one is a better deal, all you can eat or all you can drink?
Context 1-JP: <jp>食べ放題と飲み放題だったらどっちの方がおとくかな？</jp>
Context 2-EN: "Can you plan a drinking party, Kanae?" "Okay! What's the theme of the party?" "Well, it's for the presentation of Viet's cosplay collection that he bought in Japan." "Okay. Can we do it at a super cheap all-you-can-drink Izakaya?"
Context 2-JP: <jp>「カナエ、ちょっと飲み会をき画してくれない？」「おっけー！どんなテーマの飲み会？」「うーんと、ビエトが日本で買ってきたコスプレコレクションのおひろ目会なんだけど。」「分かった。めっちゃ安い飲み放題のい酒屋でもいい？」</jp>
Context 3-EN: "So, you went to an all you can drink place last night. Anything else?" "No, that’s about it."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「じゃあ、あなたは昨夜飲み放題に行っていた訳ですね。他には何かしましたか？」「いや、まあそんなところだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sew</kanji> to <kanji>manufacture</kanji> things by <vocabulary>sewing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The sewing process was done with this sewing machine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>縫製加工はこのミシンで行われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You want your <vocabulary>beans</vocabulary>, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "<reading>MAMEYYYYY</reading>, MAMMMEEYYY!" (<jp>まめ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Beans, beans the magical fruit, the more you eat, the more you toot, the more you toot, the better you feel, so eat some beans at every meal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お豆さん、お豆さん、魔法の野菜。たくさん食べれば食べるほど、たくさん屁が出るぷっぷぷぷ。たくさんぷっぷぷ屁が出れば、気持ちが良くなるウッフフフ。だから毎食お豆を食べなさい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Invite</kanji> someone to <kanji>kidnap</kanji> you and you'll have a <vocabulary>kidnapping</vocabulary> on your hands. That wasn't very smart. You should try to be more careful.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to kidnap the manager’s son.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社長の息子を誘拐するつもりだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>殺人</jp> (murder) from level 13. So, <kanji>someone</kanji> who does <kanji>murder</kanji> is what? A <vocabulary>murderer</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That killer made a terrible mistake while running away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その殺人者は、とう走中に大変な失ぱいをおかしてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'd been suspected of being the murderer, but I was finally cleared.
Context 2-JP: <jp>殺人者とうたがわれていましたが、ついにようぎが晴れました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Up until now, my friend’s life has been an epic struggle. He began his life as the baby of a murderer.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今の今まで、俺の友達の人生は信じられない苦難の連続でした。彼の人生は殺人者の子どもとして始まりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word is made of <kanji>now</kanji> and <kanji>night</kanji> with the hiragana <jp>は</jp> at the end. The <jp>は</jp> here is pronounced as <jp>わ</jp> (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying <vocabulary>good evening</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the <jp>は</jp> at the end is actually the particle <jp>は</jp> so it's pronounced like <jp>わ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Good evening. What are you doing in a place like this?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今晩は。こんな所で何してるの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: "Oh hey, good evening." "Good evening." "How was the meeting with the president yesterday?" "Well, I was certain I would be promoted, but I was fired instead."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「あら、今晩は。」「今晩は。」「昨日の社長とのミーティング、どうだった？」「それが....てっきりしょう進するものだと信じてたんですが、首になりました。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: Good evening, Uncle Koichi. Thank you for taking care of our baby today. Hey, you didn’t microwave that, did you? Because it’s breast milk, you’re not supposed to do that.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今晩は、コウイチおじさん。今日は私とフグの赤ちゃんの面倒をみてくれて有難うございます。あ、ところで、電子レンジは使わなかったよね？ 母乳だから、電子レンジ使ったらいけないんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You only need to <kanji>hurry</kanji> to something if it's <vocabulary>urgent</vocabulary> and it happened all of a <vocabulary>sudden</vocabulary>. You didn't even have time to prepare.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: It was such sudden news that she was surprised.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それはとても急な知らせだったので、彼女は驚いた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I took an urgent assignment, so I have to pick my kid up later than usual today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>急な仕事を引き受けちゃったので、今日のおむかえはおそくなります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Sorry for the sudden request. We had to take an urgent order from the customer we cannot refuse.
Context 3-JP: <jp>急な依頼ですみません。どうしても断れないお客様からの急ぎの注文だったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

What's in <vocabulary>front</vocabulary> of you? Think about it. Make it something ridiculous. Now look at a tag that's on it. Who does this thing belong to? Oh, wait, it's <reading>my</reading> (<jp>まえ</jp>) thing there in front of me. Say that out loud for better memory.
Context 1-EN: In front is a flower shop and next door to it is a fish shop.
Context 1-JP: <jp>前は花やで、花やのとなりはさかなやです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Every morning I do 500 squats before leaving for work.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎あさ、会社に行く前に、スクワットを五百回します。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I’m in front of a red light, I get very excited at the thought of it turning green soon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>赤信号の前にいる時、「もうすぐ青に変わるぞ！」と思うとかなり興奮する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you <kanji>roast</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji>, you get <vocabulary>green tea</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>green leaf tea</vocabulary>or <vocabulary>sencha</vocabulary>.

In reality there are various ways to make green tea, but for the purposes of this mnemonic, let's imagine it's always roasted!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I made green tea. Would you like some?
Context 1-JP: <jp>煎茶を入れたので良かったら飲みませんか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I love Starbucks' sencha green apple tea.
Context 2-JP: <jp>スタバの煎茶グリーンアップルが大好きなんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My big brother pours green leaf tea over pancakes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の兄はホットケーキに煎茶をかけて食べるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Planting</kanji> seeds in land to <kanji>cultivate</kanji> crops is called <vocabulary>cultivation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m growing tomatoes in my garden.
Context 1-JP: <jp>庭でトマトを栽培しているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>space</kanji> as empty as the <kanji>sky</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blank space</vocabulary>. You're probably supposed to fill that in with something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please fill out your response in the blank space.
Context 1-JP: <jp>空欄に答えを書き込んでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Blind</kanji> <kanji>eye</kanji>s will mean you suffer from <vocabulary>blindness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We have a blind dog.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達は、盲目の犬を飼っているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>quit</kanji> your current <kanji>generation</kanji> to join an older one you need all the <vocabulary>flattery</vocabulary> you can get because you're starting to feel old. People probably still won't like you though, ya old fart.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi is not good at giving insincere compliments.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは心にもないお世辞を言うのが下手です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't like being complimented on my Japanese speaking.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お世辞で日本語が上手だと言われるのは好きではありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Oh wow! You look so beautiful tonight. Like a princess!" "Flattery will get you nowhere, daddy.”
Context 3-JP: <jp>「わぉ！今夜の君はとてもきれいだね。まるで、お姫様みたいだよ。」「パパ、お世辞を言っても何も出ないわよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> is something you put over your face to cover it. It's a <vocabulary>mask</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: On the Halloween night, I saw Viet wearing the Masked Rider costume and eating a whole box of chocolates.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ハロウィンの日の夜、仮面ライダーのコスプレをしながら、チョコレートを一箱平らげたビエトを見ました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Ah, you startled me! Why are you wearing that mask?
Context 2-JP: <jp>わぁ、びっくりした！何で仮面なんてかぶってるの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dream is to go to the masquerade in Venice and meet a knight on a white horse.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ヴェネツィアの仮面舞踏会に行って白馬の王子様に会うことが私の夢です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hermit</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hermit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mountain man</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "I’m just above you," said the hermit on the cloud.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「わしゃ、お前の真上におるぞ。」と、仙人が雲の上から言いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that goes towards being <kanji>frequent</kanji> is something that is <vocabulary>frequently</vocabulary> happening.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something that happens <vocabulary>frequently</vocabulary> is something that has really caught on. People want to do this thing frequently, because it is so <reading>chic</reading> (<jp>しき</jp>).
Context 1-EN: He repeatedly emphasized that both kids and adults can enjoy the Lion King show.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は「ライオンキングは子どもから大人まで楽しめるショーだ」ということを頻りに強調した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To do <kanji>loss</kanji> to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: In order <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> your opponent, you go way overboard. You <reading>soak</reading> (<jp>そこ</jp>) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried that you may ruin your health by working too hard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>働きすぎてあんたが健康を損なうんじゃないかって、心配してるのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>gun</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pistol</vocabulary>, because it's not long like a rifle, it's a short gun!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After a long time we eventually succeeded in finding the pistol that was used for the crime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しばらく時間はかかったが、ようやく犯行の凶器となった短銃を見つけることができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Repay</kanji> people for the <kanji>news</kanji> they tell you by <vocabulary>reward</vocabulary>ing them! Everyone deserves <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary> for the time they take to pass information to you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If this project is a success, Kristen will give me a kiss on the cheek as a reward.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このプロジェクトが成功すれば、報酬として、クリステンがほっぺにキスをしてくれます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Restore</kanji> what you <kanji>learn</kanji>ed with <vocabulary>review</vocabulary>s. That's what you do on WaniKani, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Preparation and review are both important.
Context 1-JP: <jp>予習と復習はどちらも大切です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>district</kanji> isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a <vocabulary>district</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>zone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I would like to inform you in advance that the person in charge of this zone will change next month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来月から、この地区のたん当者が変わるので、あらかじめお知らせさせていただきます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are thirty-eight people who receive provisional welfare benefits in this district.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この地区には、りん時ふくしきゅう付金を受きゅうしている人が三十八人います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It seems that Koichi is planning to give a videotaped confession to the district attorney’s office soon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、近日中に地区検察局に自白内容を収めたビデオテープを送ることを計画しているようですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bathe</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bathe</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You want to know the best way <vocabulary>to bathe</vocabulary>? With a bunch of <reading>a</reading>ardvarks (<jp>あ</jp>) in the water. They use their sticky little tongues to clean all your cracks and crannies.
Context 1-EN: I'll go take a bath before dinner.
Context 1-JP: <jp>晩飯の前に、ひとっ風ろ浴びてくるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We were afraid of being exposed to radioactivity and we ran away to this town.
Context 2-JP: <jp>放しゃ能を浴びるのが怖くて、この町ににげてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu introduced me his best friend, Wild Red Sea Bream. He told me Sea Bream lives at great depths and is bathed in hardly any sunlight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグは私に親友の天然鯛を紹介してくれました。鯛君は、深海に住んでいるので日光をあまり浴びないんだと言っていました。</jp>

Meaning: Month After Next,The Month After Next
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>next month</kanji> (<jp>来月</jp>) isn't enough... one more next month, please. Let's do it <kanji>again</kanji>. That month is the <vocabulary>month after next</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have the vacation time to take a weeklong getaway the month after next so do you want to go somewhere with me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>再来月に一週間の休暇が取れるんだけど、どこか一緒にいかない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>supply</kanji> of <kanji>bean</kanji>s is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary> (also known as <vocabulary>fermented soybeans</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is an exceptional one. <jp>豆</jp> is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The <jp>納</jp> part is weird though. Instead of being <jp>のう</jp> it's <jp>なっ</jp>. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do <reading>not</reading> (<jp>なっとう</jp>) want to eat <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary>. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.
Context 1-EN: Don’t get me wrong. I love Japanese food, but I could never just eat natto alone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誤解しないでね。日本料理は大好きなんだけど、納豆だけはどうしても食べられないの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you let someone <kanji>cut off</kanji> your <kanji>oil</kanji> supply, it's probably because of your <vocabulary>inattentiveness</vocabulary>. You <vocabulary>let your guard down</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Don’t let your guard down around Koichi. He’s a really tough guy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチには油断をするな。奴は中々手強い男だぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of <jp>再</jp>, so it shares the meaning <vocabulary>again</vocabulary> and also has the meaning <vocabulary>once again</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>Once again</vocabulary>, you put a <reading>footer</reading> in your note because you can't remember the reading to this word because the mnemonic is so bad (sorry!).
Context 1-EN: If you can, you should lick your elbow again.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしできるなら、再び肘を舐めてみるべきだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Oil</kanji> that has <kanji>stone</kanji>s in it is from the ground. It's not olive oil, it's <vocabulary>petroleum</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Oil prices are rising steeply.
Context 1-JP: <jp>石油価格が高騰している。</jp>

Meaning: To Burn,To Be Lighted,To Be Lit,To Be Burning
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lamp</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary>. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:
