Who wanted the candle <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary>? <reading>Tom</reading> (<jp>とも</jp>) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.
Context 1-EN: I can see light burning in that room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの部屋に明かりが灯るのを見たんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I say my <kanji>commandment</kanji> in order <vocabulary>to warn</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to caution</vocabulary> the people not to do bad things.
Reading Mnemonic: The first commandment I say <vocabulary>to warn</vocabulary> them of not doing bad things is <reading>I mash</reading> (<jp>いまし</jp>) my own potatoes. Nobody else mashes my potatoes. Got it?
Context 1-EN: Someone needs to warn her about her reckless driving, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かが彼女の無茶苦茶な運転を戒める必要があるんじゃない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>尊敬</jp> is respect. A respect <kanji>language</kanji> is <vocabulary>honorific Japanese</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>honorific language</vocabulary>, though usually this refers to Japanese).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>尊敬</jp> plus <jp>語</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: I often mix up honorific Japanese with humble Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>よく尊敬語と謙譲語がゴチャゴチャになってしまいます。</jp>

Meaning: To Stab,To Pierce,To Poke,To Sting,To Stick,To Shank
Meaning Mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>stab</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stab</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning that you are the one doing the stabbing... should I be afraid of you? 😅
Reading Mnemonic: If you're going <vocabulary>to stab</vocabulary> someone, use a <reading>saw</reading> (<jp>さ</jp>). It may seem more difficult to stab them with a saw at first, but when you see the damage, plus how hard it is to get back out, you'll realize a saw is the ideal stabbing tool.
Context 1-EN: Although I had stabbed my mom with a knife, I slept soundly that night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母親をナイフで刺したにもかかわらず、私はその夜熟睡した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>ethic</kanji> <kanji>al</kanji> are <vocabulary>ethical</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our company was selected as the most ethical business in the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの会社は、世界で最も倫理的な企業の一つに選ばれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> plus <jp>たち</jp> is <vocabulary>we</vocabulary>. Remember <jp>私達</jp>? It's just like that. Remember, <jp>俺</jp> is going to be much more casual and rough sounding, so be careful to only use it amongst friends / when you're shaking someone down.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We’ll go to Hokkaido next month to meet our younger sister, who has been separated from us for all these years.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺たち、生き別れになっていた妹に会いに、来月北海道に行くんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who is <kanji>different</kanji> from the person you thought it was is a <vocabulary>mistaken identity</vocabulary>. Whoops, sorry, I thought you were someone else. <jp>人違い</jp>!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are <jp>人</jp> and <jp>違い</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: Yes, we are also conjoined twins, but I’m afraid you are mistaking us for a different set of twins.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はい、私達も結合双生児ではありますが、申し訳ありませんがあなたは人違いをしていると思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: His girlfriend got him to cook kimchi casserole.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女が彼氏にキムチ鍋を作らせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>manga</kanji> <kanji>genius</kanji>! For some reason, this is a <vocabulary>comic dialogue</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>two man comedy</vocabulary>. Look up "manzai" on YouTube for some good times if you don't know what this is. It's not exactly the same, but <jp>漫</jp> DOES refer to manga, which is a type of comic book. Take the "comic" part from "comic" book, then change it to the "haha funny!" meaning of "comic," and then imagine people doing a dialogue. Then, you have a <vocabulary>comic dialogue</vocabulary>. Lots of steps, but hopefully it'll get you there.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Watching two man comedy acts and laughing loudly relieves my stress.
Context 1-JP: <jp>漫才を見て大声で笑うことはストレス解消になる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>have</kanji> and so the verb version means <vocabulary>to have</vocabulary>. An alternative meaning is <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary> though this refers only to non-living inanimate things, not moving and living things. So really, this is similar to "to have" as well.

These kanji aren't used too often, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize them!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>To have</vocabulary> something is very nice. But now, the only thing you possess are screams. Imagine this. You are in a totally empty room with no possessions. You open a little box and look inside. It contains screams that yell: "<reading>AAAAHHHH</reading>" (<jp>あ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: We still have a little mayonnaise.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マヨネーズなら、まだ少し有ります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is only one train per hour.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一じかんに一本しかでん車は有りません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There is gold in his house as well as silver on his roof.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼の家には金も有るが、屋根の上に銀も有る。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You can <kanji>rejoice</kanji> because your <kanji>lifespan</kanji> has reached this special point. That special point is your <vocabulary>seventy seventh birthday</vocabulary>. So many sevens, lucky!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of <jp>喜</jp> before, though it may be hard to remember at this point. Maybe you can think about how when you reach this <vocabulary>seventy seventh birthday</vocabulary>, all you want is a <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>) to the city so you can do whatever you want.
Context 1-EN: All of the part-time workers are going to celebrate the owner’s 77th birthday in his convenience store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バイトのみんなで、店長の喜寿をコンビニでお祝いする予定なんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>stiff</kanji> <kanji>fix</kanji> is when you fix something to be stiff, which leads to <vocabulary>rigidity</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>stiffness</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>stiffening</vocabulary>. This word feels pretty formal when used as a noun. You can also add <jp>している</jp> or <jp>した</jp> to mean "rigid," but it doesn't mean that on its own.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I believe that psychological rigidity can hinder problem solving.
Context 1-JP: <jp>心理的硬直は問題を解決する妨げになると思われる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The rigidity of society is a problem that we need to fix.
Context 2-JP: <jp>社会の硬直化は解決しなければならない問題です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wonder how long after death rigor mortis sets in.
Context 3-JP: <jp>死後どのぐらいで死後硬直が起きるんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something with <kanji>lucidity</kanji> is clear. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to become clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become transparent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The water in the pond was green yesterday, but it’s totally cleared up now. What happened?
Context 1-JP: <jp>池の水、昨日は濁って緑色だったのに、今はすっかり澄んでいるじゃないか。一体何があったの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji>/<kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> is the surface that makes up the <vocabulary>ground</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>Earth's surface</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>面</jp> is what you'd expect. <jp>地</jp> on the other hand is <jp>じ</jp>, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of <reading>Je</reading>sus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.
Context 1-EN: Fugu said that he'd rather live underground than underwater.
Context 1-JP: <jp>海の中じゃなくて地面の中に住めたらいいのに、とフグは言いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our front yard doesn't have any grass, so the earth's surface gets really hot during summer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>家の前の庭は草が生えていないので、夏の間は地面がとても熱くなります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi gently stroked Fugu and placed him on the ground.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチはフグを優しく撫でてから、地面に降ろしてあげました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're talking about some <kanji>other</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> you're talking about <vocabulary>another place</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Not here, let’s go to another store somewhere else.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここじゃなくて、どこか他所の店に行こうよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't compare us to other families.
Context 3-EN: I moved somewhere else to escape from my abusive husband.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は暴力夫から逃れるために、他所に移り住んだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji>s are a part of the <vocabulary>general affairs</vocabulary> of the people. That's why they're general, they're the ones everyone is involved in.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It will be assigned to the general affairs department this time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんど、庶務課に配属されることになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When do people tend to use the word <vocabulary>furthermore</vocabulary>? Right <reading>now</reading> (<jp>なお</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: If I warm it up and eat it, it becomes even more delicious.
Context 1-JP: <jp>温めて食べたら、尚、おいしくなりますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the reading for the kanji that makes it.
Context 1-EN: I have a fever of 38.9 degrees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねつが、三十八点九どあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Compared to what's in this closet, I have 2.5 times as many clothes scattered around in the other rooms.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このクローゼットにある二点五ばいのりょうのふくが他のへやにもちらばっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I agree with your point that the movie was really bad, but I didn’t realize it was such a waste of time until it was over.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの映画が駄作だったという点ではあなたに同意しますが、時間の無駄だったと気づいたのは映画が終わってからでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You move towards the <kanji>sake</kanji>. When you move towards it, you are doing something <vocabulary>for the sake of</vocabulary>. But why use fancy language like that? Let's just leave it as <vocabulary>for</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>For the sake of</vocabulary> public safety, you will need to <reading>tame</reading> (<jp>ため</jp>) the wild beasts loose in our city. Now go, <reading>tame</reading> them!
Context 1-EN: I wanted to sleep so that I could be ready for my night shift, but I couldn’t because the trains were too noisy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夜勤の為に寝ておきたかったが、電車の音がうるさすぎた為に眠れなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Buddha</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji>s are the rules Buddha made for Buddhists. These can be found in the <vocabulary>Buddhist Scriptures</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>Buddhist Writing</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that <jp>ぶつ</jp> gets shortened to <jp>ぶっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Can you put the Buddhist scriptures in this box?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その仏典はこの箱の中にしまってもらえますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: During peak hours, please be considerate of others waiting to use the Buddhist writings.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こんざつ時は、ゆずり合って仏典をご利用ください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you know how the Buddhist scriptures were translated from Sanskrit to Chinese?
Context 3-JP: <jp>仏典がどのようにしてサンスクリット語から漢語に訳されたのかご存じですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Immersed</kanji> to the point where it's <kanji>transparent</kanji>, because it's so soaked... that is total <vocabulary>permeation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>soaking</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>osmosis</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This face lotion is getting really popular because it deeply permeates into the skin.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こちらの化粧水は、お肌の奥深くまで浸透するということで、すごく人気が出てきています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have only <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji> so do everything with lots of <kanji>eager</kanji>ness (<jp>懸命</jp>). Do everything <vocabulary>with all one's might</vocabulary>. Go <vocabulary>all out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Everything except the <jp>生</jp> uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of <jp>生</jp> when you learned <jp>一生</jp>. You've really been going <vocabulary>all out</vocabulary> to learn these readings!
Context 1-EN: I was moved by the sight of my daughter singing in the chorus with all her might.
Context 1-JP: <jp>合唱団で歌う娘の一生懸命な姿に感動しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Look, it's unfair that you're the only one slacking off, because everyone is working so hard.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ほら、みんな一生懸命がんばってるんだから、一人だけサボるなんてずるいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I know I have to work my hardest to catch up with everyone, but it’s difficult.
Context 3-JP: <jp>遅れを取り戻すために一生懸命働かなくてはいけないのは分かっているんですが、中々難しいです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Luck</kanji> for your whole <kanji>lifespan</kanji>, that's a life of <vocabulary>happiness and longevity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I received a New Year’s greeting card with happiness and longevity written in it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>福寿と書かれた年賀状を受け取りました。</jp>

Meaning: To Engage In,To Participate,To Take Part In
Meaning Mnemonic: Somehow the kanji <kanji>portable</kanji> turns into the verb <vocabulary>to engage in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to participate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take part in</vocabulary>. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).
Reading Mnemonic: A <reading>Taz saw</reading> (<jp>たずさ</jp>) is a saw owned by a Tazmanian, and it is particularly portable. It allows you <vocabulary>to participate</vocabulary> in all kinds of things, like  cutting down trees, or being in a horror film.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t want to participate in an evaluation of my coworkers, but I didn’t have a choice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>同僚の評価に携わるのは嫌だったが、選択の余地はなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Pluck</kanji> a <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> out at random. It doesn't make sense. You can't physically pluck out a phenomenon! The reason is <vocabulary>abstract</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Her review was kind of abstract, so I didn’t really understand it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女のレビューは何だか抽象的だったので、あまりよく分かりませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>shinto shrine</kanji> <kanji>courts</kanji> are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the <vocabulary>imperial court</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Royal court</vocabulary> will do as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>宮</jp> is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how <reading>cu</reading>te (<jp>きゅう</jp>) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.
Context 1-EN: A chest cold is going around the Imperial Court.
Context 1-JP: <jp>宮廷では咳風邪が流行っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>宝</jp> is a <kanji>treasure</kanji>. <jp>くじ</jp> is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a <vocabulary>lottery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading uses the <jp>宝</jp> vocab reading, <jp>たから</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "My little sister won the lottery." "Oh cool! How much?" "10,000 yen."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「妹が宝くじに当たったのよ。」「すごいね！で、いくら？」「一万円。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's wishful thinking, but I'll probably win the lottery at some point next year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きぼうてきかんそくでは、来年あたりに宝くじに当たるはずです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dad's secretary won the lottery, but I made a spelling mistake when I posted it on Facebook. Secretary was spelled secretly. It confused people and I got a lot of congrats.
Context 3-JP: <jp>父親の秘書が宝くじに当たったんだけど、それをフェイスブックに書いた時に秘書を秘密と書き間違えてしまい、みんなが勘違いしてたくさんおめでとうコメントを残してくれました。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Due To,To Be Caused By
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>based on</kanji> and the verb means <vocabulary>to be due to</vocabulary>. This is probably because when something is based off something, it does something else, which is due to what it was based on. It was caused by what it was based on.
Reading Mnemonic: For example, <reading>yo</reading>gurt is due to milk. If milk didn't exist, neither would yogurt.
Context 1-EN: I was able to succeed because of everyone’s support. I’ll give you guys a lot of bacon in thanks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>皆様のお力に拠って、成功することができました。感謝の気持ちをこめて、ベーコンをプレゼントさせて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something filled with the <kanji>rule</kanji>s of various <kanji>action</kanji>s is something that contains a ton of knowledge. It contains all things and actions, right? What kind of "thing" is filled with all this information (that existed during the creation of words and kanji?)? One thing would be an <vocabulary>encyclopedia</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you are looking for Koichi, he is staring at an encyclopedia on the lounge chair in the sunroom.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチなら、サンルームの日光浴用のイスで事典とにらめっこしていますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The camera showed that you shoplifted an encyclopedia.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたが事典を万引きしたしゅん間がカメラに映っているんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I used my encyclopedia as a pillow because it was too big to be a book.
Context 3-JP: <jp>本としてはちょっと大きすぎたので、私は百科事典を枕として使っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Everything on a <kanji>location</kanji>'s <kanji>surface</kanji> is really just a part of the <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary> before you. This is the kind of scene that would be set in a novel. It's the <vocabulary>setting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: When I watched the scene where the wife packs up and leaves, I saw myself in her and felt bitter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つまが荷物をまとめて出ていく場面が自分にかさなりつらくなりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This phrase is useful in a business setting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このフレーズは、ビジネスの場面で有効です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I cried during the last scene.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最後の場面で泣いてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transit</kanji>, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are transiting one object over to another person (the word is <vocabulary>to hand over</vocabulary>), though, so it kind of makes sense. You see the <jp>す</jp>? You're <reading>su</reading>ing somebody, so you hand over the papers telling them you're suing them. Don't confuse this with <jp>渡る</jp> which is "to cross over." <jp>す</jp> is sue.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: When he handed me the pen my heart was pounding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼が私にペンを渡してくれた時、胸がどきどきした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hard</kanji> so the verb vocab version? <vocabulary>To make hard</vocabulary>. You need to differentiate this from <jp>固まる</jp>, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "<reading>mail</reading>" (<jp>める</jp>) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you.
Reading Mnemonic: Since the reading for <jp>固</jp> (<jp>かた</jp>) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. A <reading>cate</reading>rpillar (<jp>かた</jp>) forms a cocoon. The caterpillar's cocoon is hard and the caterpillar made it that way. Keep this in mind and you too will blossom into a beautiful butterfly.
Context 1-EN: You can harden clay with heat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねん土は熱で固めることができるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet takes an hour to make his pompadour hard every morning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは毎朝一時間かけてリーゼントをワックスで固めます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi decided to fortify his position and send his troops to Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、日本に軍隊を派遣する決意を固めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be overdue</vocabulary>. This is probably because something that has stagnated is running late, and therefore causes it <vocabulary>to be overdue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is wildsauce. I'm going to leave this one to your capable hands. Just think of <reading>Tod</reading> (<jp>とど</jp>) and some <reading>coo</reading>t (<jp>こお</jp>) doing something wild even though they're overdue for something else, or something. Anyways, best of luck to you on this one.
Context 1-EN: The landlord visited a guy who was six months behind with his rent and found him dead in the house.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家主が六ヶ月間家賃が滞っている男の家に出向くと、男は家の中で死んでいた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This isn't just any <kanji>lotus</kanji>. It's THE lotus. The <vocabulary>Sacred Lotus</vocabulary>. When you see it blooming all alone in a murky pond, you'll know.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The <vocabulary>sacred lotus</vocabulary> <reading>has</reading> (<jp>はす</jp>) a strong significance (and probably some powers). It has something at least, just remember it has something special going on, and you'll be fine.
Context 1-EN: What does the sacred lotus mean in the language of flowers?
Context 1-JP: <jp>蓮の花の花言葉は何ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>location</kanji> in the <kanji>city</kanji> where the <kanji>stock</kanji>s <kanji>ritual</kanji> takes place is the <vocabulary>stock market</vocabulary>. Just think of what happens in a stock market... the stock ritual, where people buy and sell stocks. And, of course, this is located in the city.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are all readings you've seen before - either from other words or from the kanji. Go through each kanji here and figure out which is which and try to remember. Just think of <reading>Joe</reading> (<jp>場</jp>) the stock broker for the last kanji.
Context 1-EN: The global slowdown has significantly affected our stock market, as well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>世界的な景気の減速は、私たちの株式市場にも影響を及ぼした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Psh, that guy's <kanji>damage</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji>. He's what I'd call "mostly <vocabulary>harmless</vocabulary>."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There was an earthquake with a magnitude 6.2, but it was harmless.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マグニチュード6.2の地震がありましたが、無害でした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What's with people who troll even harmless tweets?
Context 2-JP: <jp>無害のツイートにまでいちいちつっかかってるやつ、なんなの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t worry. Tofugu doesn’t have any poison. He’s a harmless blowfish.
Context 3-JP: <jp>心配しなくていいよ。Tofuguに毒は無いから。彼は無害な河豚だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>shame</kanji>? It could be <vocabulary>ashamed</vocabulary> or even <vocabulary> embarrassing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: When you're <vocabulary>ashamed</vocabulary> it's even worse when someone laughs at you: <reading>ha</reading> (<jp>は</jp>) ha ha!"
Context 1-EN: I feel ashamed to say this, but I tend to waste money on cheap things.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんなことを言うのは恥ずかしいんですが、私は安物買いの銭失いみたいなところがあるんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I will <kanji>permit</kanji> this, and you have my <kanji>agreement</kanji>. Both of these things combine to be my <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you allow me to marry your daughter, I’ll give you my consent to use our company’s trademark.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし娘さんとの結婚を許可してくださるのなら、あなたに我が社の登録商標の使用を許諾します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has a little hiragana attached to it but nothing that suggests it's a verb or an adjective. That means you can assume this word has the same meaning as its parent kanji.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <jp>すべ</jp> part, which is an admittedly difficult sound to remember. You have to think of the concept of <vocabulary>all</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>entire</vocabulary>. When you think of that concept, think of someone's entire fortune. All their money. You want to get all of Beth's money, so you <reading>sue Be</reading>th (<jp>すべ</jp>) for <vocabulary>all</vocabulary> she has.
Context 1-EN: It all went smoothly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全て上手く行きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am sorry, but all the seats are fully occupied at the moment, so...
Context 2-JP: <jp>申しわけございませんが、げんざい全てのおせきがうまっているじょうきょうでして...。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was the first to do it. Wikipedia copied my entire homework assignment afterwards.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕が先だよ。ウィキペディアが僕の宿題を全て真似したんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You pick up some <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>. Hmm, I'd like to wear these, you think. But, the shopkeeper comes up and says, in a really weird accent, "No, I'm afraid those are <reading><jp>ころも</jp></reading> clothes." <jp>ころも</jp> clothes? What is that? Oh... you find out this guy has a speech impediment and is trying to say "<jp>こども</jp> (<jp>子供</jp>) clothes." Try to say the word with him, but he keeps saying it wrong. You get frustrated and blurt out, "It's the <reading>key</reading> to not being <reading>nude</reading> (<jp>きぬ</jp>)!" This does the trick, he lets you have your <jp>ころも</jp> clothes and goes into the back room to cry.
Context 1-EN: I think dressing for the season is so tiresome, what do you think?
Context 1-JP: <jp>衣替えをするのって、とても面倒くさいと思うんだけど、どう思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>stupid</kanji> when it comes to <kanji>sound</kanji>s, then you're <vocabulary>tone deaf</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m tone-deaf so I’m bad at karaoke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>音痴なので、カラオケは苦手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: My stomach aches from stress.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ストレスで、胃がキリキリします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Ugh, that <kanji>field</kanji> <kanji>guy</kanji>. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the <vocabulary>bastard</vocabulary>. Really though, he's just this <vocabulary>guy</vocabulary>, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That bastard got promoted to sales manager. I’m sick to my stomach.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのクソ野郎がセールス・マネージャーに昇進するなんて本当に気に食わねぇ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is the current night, aka <vocabulary>tonight</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Would you like to go out for drinks with me tonight?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今夜、いっしょにのみに行きませんか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The exam is coming up tomorrow, so I am gonna burn the midnight oil tonight.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日しけんがあるから、今夜はてつ夜でがんばります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I feel like eating chicken wings for dinner tonight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今夜は晩ご飯に手羽先が食べたい気分だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pluck</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pluck</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pick</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to prune</vocabulary>, like with plants.
Reading Mnemonic: You are going outside <vocabulary>to pluck</vocabulary> <reading>two</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>) of your favorite flowers.
Context 1-EN: She carefully plucks each rose petal by hand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は薔薇の花びらを一枚一枚丁寧に手で摘んでいきます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>comrade</kanji> who came <kanji>before</kanji> me is my <vocabulary>senior</vocabulary>, my senpai (<jp>せんぱい</jp>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, but just remember that the second kanji is read as <jp>ぱい</jp> because of the rendaku on <jp>はい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My superior isn’t a bad guy, but he and I just haven’t been able to hit it off.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の先輩、悪い人では無いんだけどさ、ただちょっと俺とは反りが合わないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you are about to <kanji>attain</kanji> <kanji>winter</kanji>, then it's the <vocabulary>winter solstice</vocabulary>. Happy winter, everyone!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>冬</jp> is the on'yomi reading, and one you haven't learned before. You're going to want to think about how you are celebrating the <vocabulary>winter solstice</vocabulary> in one particular place, that place being <reading><jp>とう</jp></reading> (<jp>とう</jp>). See the Tokyo landmarks around you, think that you are there on the winter solstice, and also think about the things you are doing to celebrate, here in Tokyo. Also, watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Why do people say it’s good to eat squash on the winter solstice in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして日本では冬至の日にカボチャを食べると良いというのですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It is <kanji>obsolete</kanji> so we must <kanji>stop</kanji> it. No more of it anymore. This is <vocabulary>abolition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you agree or disagree with the abolition of the death penalty?
Context 1-JP: <jp>死刑制度廃止には、賛成ですか、反対ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is another section of Japan. It's quite nice, too. Look on a map and try to find it. So, the meaning of this word is also the reading, which you should be able to figure out because it's all on'yomi: <vocabulary>Shikoku</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: I still haven’t been to Shikoku.
Context 1-JP: <jp>四国にはまだ行ったことがありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Have you gotten used to life in Shikoku yet?
Context 2-JP: <jp>四国での生活にはなれましたか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was traveling through Shikoku to learn how to make the best udon noodles.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最高の饂飩の作り方を求めて、四国を旅していた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Heaven</kanji>'s <kanji>climate</kanji> is <vocabulary>the weather</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I know there will be extra costs if we travel during peak season, but the weather will be the best around that time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>繁忙期に旅行をすれば費用が嵩むのは分かっているけど、そうはいっても天候もその時期が一番いいからね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>invade</kanji> with <kanji>aggression</kanji> that's an <vocabulary>invasion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It was funny that when they tried to invade our village high atop the mountain, the entire enemy camp got altitude sickness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奴らが山のてっぺんにある俺たちの村を侵攻しようとした時、敵陣が全員高山病に罹ってしまったのには笑えたよ。</jp>

Meaning: Eaves,Stand In A Row,Stand Side By Side
Meaning Mnemonic: In order to use a <kanji>house counter</kanji> in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find <vocabulary>eaves</vocabulary>. And all those eaves together <vocabulary>stand in a row</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

These houses that <vocabulary>stand in a row</vocabulary> are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have <reading>no key</reading> (<jp>のき</jp>). With no key, those <vocabulary>eaves</vocabulary> are just there for you to look at.
Context 1-EN: There are a lot of ramen carts standing in a row here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここには多くのラーメン屋台が軒を連ねています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Kanji doesn't go together much better than this. <kanji>Both</kanji> plus <kanji>day</kanji> equals <vocabulary>both days</vocabulary>.

This is a bit of a formal word though, you'll hear important people say it more than your friends.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that <jp>日</jp> uses the reading <jp>じつ</jp> for this one instead of <jp>にち</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’ll be in a meeting both days.
Context 1-JP: <jp>両日とも、会ぎが入っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The tofu festival had good weather for both days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>とうふまつりは、両日ともせい天にめぐまれた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I attended the iPad lecture session on both days, but I still have no clue how to use it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>iPadの使い方についての講義に両日とも参加したが、まだ使い方が分からない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Think of your favorite <vocabulary>shop</vocabulary>. Okay, now imagine yourself going to it. When you arrive, the entire shop is totally <reading>missi</reading>ng (<jp>みせ</jp>). Feel the shock and awe of this. It's as if it picked up and left overnight. No building, no anything. Just missing.
Context 1-EN: Please draw a map from the station to the store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>えきからその店までの地図をかいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The restaurant is already fully booked for the rest of the year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この店は年内はすでにずっとよやくでいっぱいだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You’re going to love this shop. They have the best meatloaf in the world.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この店のこと絶対気に入るぜ。世界一うまいミートローフがあるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Pick Someone Up,To Meet Someone,To Welcome,To Invite
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>welcome</kanji>, but the verb version is <vocabulary>to pick someone up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to meet someone</vocabulary>. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going <vocabulary>to meet someone</vocabulary> too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.
Reading Mnemonic: <vocabulary>To pick someone up</vocabulary> you are going to drive your <reading>moo ca</reading>r. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.
Context 1-EN: We are thinking of getting a puppy, but which kind can be easily trained not to bark unnecessarily?
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちに仔犬を迎えたいなと思ってるんですが、無駄吠え防止の訓練をしやすいのは何犬でしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>commander</kanji> of the <kanji>army</kanji> is the <vocabulary>shogun</vocabulary>. Do you know the shogun? He ran Japan, and was like the ruling general over the states. You can also call him the <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>commander</vocabulary>, if you like.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That is to say, I’m dating the enemy shogun.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つまり、敵の将軍と付き合っているってこと。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>debt</kanji> <kanji>ticket</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bond</vocabulary>. You buy it from the government and then they pay it back to you with interest... in theory.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What time is the bond market open until?
Context 1-JP: <jp>債券市場は何時まで開いてますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The Tokyo Metropolitan Government has issued additional bonds for the upcoming Olympics.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京都は来たるオリンピックのため、追加で債券を発行した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Current bond rates are no good for people who can't buy them for in the hundred million yen range.
Context 3-JP: <jp>債券取引は、一億円単位で売買できない人には不利なレートになってるですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>invite</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You <reading>saw so</reading> (<jp>さそ</jp>) much in this person that you decided <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary> them to dinner.
Context 1-EN: "I finally asked her out on a date and she said yes, so we’re going out for dinner tonight." "Well, have fun! Don’t do anything I wouldn’t do."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ついに彼女をデートに誘ったんだけど、なんとOKの返事をもらえたんだよ。だから、今夜、食事をしに出かけるんだ。」「そうなんだ！楽しんできてね！くれぐれも悪いことはしないようにね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>rest</kanji> you do in your <kanji>spare time</kanji> is your <vocabulary>time off</vocabulary>. It is your <vocabulary>holiday</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How far in advance do you usually make vacation plans?
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつもどのくらい前から休暇の予定を立てますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>debt</kanji> <kanji>rights</kanji> state that you have a certain amount of <vocabulary>credit</vocabulary> with your bank. And if they try to say you don't have that credit you can file a <vocabulary>claim</vocabulary> against them!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Creditors often receive some money from bankruptcy proceedings, but stockholders rarely do.
Context 1-JP: <jp>債権者は破産手続きによっていくらかお金を受け取れることが多いが、株主は滅多に受け取ることがない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Is the <kanji>evidence</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> enough to convince me? Is this really <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary> enough?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We have verification that Kristen is truly the well-protected daughter of a respectable family.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クリステンが正真正めいの箱入りむすめであることが証明された。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you have something to verify your identity?
Context 2-JP: <jp>何か身分を証明できる物は持っていますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Would you rather receive some sort of certificate proving you finished the TextFugu and WaniKani courses?
Context 3-JP: <jp>テキストフグとワニカニの各コースが修了するごとに、修了証明書のようなものが受け取れた方がいいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In the <kanji>middle</kanji> of a <kanji>whirlpool</kanji> you'll find a spinning <vocabulary>vortex</vocabulary> of water. You really don't want to get sucked in there.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He’s in a vortex of divorce turmoil.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は離婚騒動で渦中の人だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>value</kanji> is in various <kanji>steps</kanji>. Each step is a different amount, and each amount is a <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading for <jp>値</jp> plus the on'yomi reading for <jp>段</jp>. Combine them together to get the reading here. You've learned both of these readings already, so just remember <jp>値</jp> is <jp>ね</jp> because you <reading>neigh</reading> (<jp>ね</jp>) when you see a good <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: It’s true that we are working on our TV tie-in book, but the price hasn’t been decided yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>テレビとタイアップした書籍を手がけているのは本当だが、まだ値段は決まっていない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>return</kanji> to the <kanji>hometown</kanji> you are going <vocabulary>to return to one's hometown</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>帰</jp> is the on'yomi reading, which you haven't learned. Just think about how when you return to your hometown, you're going to need a <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>) to get into your old home, which you haven't been to in a long time.
Context 1-EN: Like most gamblers, she believed she had talent, but in the end she lost everything to a poker game and had to go back to her hometown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ほとんどの博打打ちが思っているように、彼女も自分には天分があると思っていたんだが、結局あるポーカーのゲームで全財産を失って、帰郷するはめになったんだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Charge A Battery,To Recharge,To Recharge A Battery
Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>充電</jp> is a <kanji>recharge</kanji> then the verb version is going to be <vocabulary>to recharge</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to charge a battery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>充電</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I forgot to charge my battery and my cellphone died, so my alarm didn’t go off.
Context 1-JP: <jp>充電するのを忘れたから携帯の電源が切れて、目覚ましが鳴らなかったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you let words <kanji>pass through</kanji> you, and as they do you <kanji>translate</kanji> them, you are doing <vocabulary>interpreting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If I were omnipotent, I would be able to interpret this conversation for you, but I’m not, so I can’t. Sorry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし私が全能の神だったら、この会話を通訳してあげることができるけど、そうじゃないから無理だわ。ごめんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>替える</jp> is to <kanji>replace</kanji>? Well, you're replacing what you <kanji>wear</kanji>. That's a <vocabulary>change of clothes</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>着る</jp> and <jp>替える</jp> put together. The <jp>か</jp> goes to <jp>が</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My mother apologized for forgetting to bring me a change of clothes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母は、私の着替えを持ってくるのを忘れた事を謝りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This place has <kanji>extreme</kanji> <kanji>comfort</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>paradise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The novel about a man who went to paradise by mistake was made into a movie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>間違いで極楽に行った男についての小説が、映画化されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm a <kanji>servant</kanji> to my <kanji>salary</kanji>. It is the <vocabulary>supply</vocabulary> that keeps me going, and also allows me to buy my supply.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Our maximum priority is to stabilize the supplies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最優先事項は供給を安定させることだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Fix,To Repair,To Fix Something,To Repair Something
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fix</kanji> so this vocab word means <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary>. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to learn the <jp>なお</jp> part. Think of it this way. You need <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary> something! It's urgent! You have to fix it <reading>now</reading>! (<jp>なお</jp>). This will also work with the similar word, <jp>直る</jp>, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.
Context 1-EN: My PC broke. Can you fix it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>パソコンがこわれたんですが、直せますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You'd better think it through again.
Context 2-JP: <jp>考え直した方がいいですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You don’t need to fix something if it’s not broken.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし壊れていなければ、それを直そうとする必要はないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word can also mean <vocabulary>core</vocabulary> because that's where the nucleus is in a cell, and <vocabulary>nuclear</vocabulary> because we like to blow ourselves up nowadays...
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.
Context 1-EN: Why is the nucleus located at the center of the cell?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして核は細胞の中心部に位置するんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Okita-kun became interested in atomic nuclei when he was an elementary school student, and now he's working as the nucleus of this team.
Context 2-JP: <jp>沖田君は小学生の時に原子核について興味を持ち、今ではこのチームの核として働いてくれています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The nuclear missile launch is three hours behind schedule now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>核ミサイルの発射が、もう予定より三時間も遅れています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>one sided</kanji> <kanji>corner</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary>, just a really small one.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That had always been stuck in the corner of my mind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのことが心の片隅にずっと引っかかっていたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Trade</kanji> is <kanji>easy</kanji> if you like <vocabulary>trade</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>commerce</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>貿</jp> reading is okay, but the <jp>易</jp> reading is different from what you're used to. Just think about how a lot of the trade that comes in will come into the train <reading>station</reading> (<jp>駅</jp>). So if you want good trade, you'll want to be at the <jp>えき</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m looking for a job as the clerk of a trading company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>貿易事務の仕事を探しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Obsolete</kanji> <kanji>ruins</kanji> are places that are abandoned because nobody can run them anymore (due to being obsolete, or due to not having money, or due to whatever else). These things are <vocabulary>ruins</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>abandoned buildings</vocabulary>. People like to explore these, a lot.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have muscle pain because I played tag in the abandoned building yesterday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日廃墟で鬼ごっこをしたので、筋肉痛になりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
If you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>product</kanji>, it's not really a product anymore, but <vocabulary>a work</vocabulary>. It's your <vocabulary>work</vocabulary> of art or literature, or maybe a theater <vocabulary>production</vocabulary>.

This can be any kind of artistic creation: a book, a composition, a painting, a movie, a play... It doesn't mean "product" (you'll learn the word for that later!) but it can be used for a product when you want to highlight the artistic talent behind it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This miniature garden work is made from a matchbox.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この箱庭の作品は、マッチ箱で作られています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The strange statue at the entrance of Tofugu office is a work of Koichi's from when he was fifteen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグオフィスの入り口にあるヘンテコな像は、コウイチの十五才の時の作品ですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s been a while since I came across a work I like. Attack on Titan is so good that it might be one of my top three anime. I highly recommend it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>久々にいい作品に出会ったわ。進撃の巨人は、私の好きなアニメの歴代三位に入るんじゃないかってくらい良かったよ。マジでお薦めするわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>morally good</kanji> person who has <kanji>mercy</kanji> upon people gives to <vocabulary>charity</vocabulary>. These people prove they're good by mercifully giving all their money away to the poor and needy.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This book was published for the purpose of supporting charitable projects.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この本は慈善事業支援の目的で出版されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>eat</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You have to remember the <jp>た</jp> portion if you want to be able to read this word, which uses the kun'yomi reading. Think about yourself <vocabulary>eat</vocabulary>ing some <reading>ta</reading>cos (<jp>た</jp>). Imagine yourself eating it, that raw beef taste in your mouth (either like it or hate it).
Context 1-EN: I eat natto every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎あさ、なっとうを食べます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I never have enough time to eat healthy foods.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつも、けんこうにいいものを食べるじかんがないんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like to eat while I’m sleeping. It’s just like sleepwalking, but it’s called sleep-eating.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、寝ながら食べるのが好きだ。夢遊病のような感じで、それは夢遊食事病と呼ばれる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The taste of something with <kanji>acid</kanji> is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a <vocabulary>sour</vocabulary> taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word.
Reading Mnemonic: Something was so <vocabulary>sour</vocabulary> that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) the maker of this nasty sour thing.
Context 1-EN: The first food I ate was rotten and sour.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最初に食べた食べ物は腐りかけていて酸っぱかったです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Using your animal <vocabulary>fang</vocabulary> you are able to eat <reading>kibble</reading> (<jp>きば</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Our stock of fake fangs for Halloween is running out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ハロウィン用の偽物の牙の在庫が切れそうです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that <kanji>wither</kanji>s from <kanji>thirst</kanji> ends up <vocabulary>drying up</vocabulary>. If you let a plant <vocabulary>dry up</vocabulary> like this it might die if you don't water it soon.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>渇</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If all of your plants are <vocabulary>drying up</vocabulary> you should just give them to your <reading>cats</reading> (<jp>かつ</jp>). Cats love to play with dried up plants. At least they won't go to waste.
Context 1-EN: The petroleum will dry up very soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もうすぐ石油は枯渇する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We must <kanji>maintain</kanji> the <kanji>new</kanji> and get rid of the old. It's time for a <vocabulary>restoration</vocabulary> of policy! This also refers to the <vocabulary>Meiji Restoration</vocabulary> too. In fact, it probably mostly refers to this, though you'll learn a more full version of this later.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I studied the Meiji restoration in school, but I can’t remember anything about it other than its name.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校で明治維新について勉強はしたんですが、名前以外は何にも覚えていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>dare</kanji> to do something <kanji>risky</kanji>. It's <vocabulary>adventure</vocabulary> time! Imagine yourself daring yourself to do risky things. Is this an adventure? If not, make it so!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Viet left the work unfinished and went on an adventure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトは仕事を残したまま、冒険に出かけた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We should reserve our energy for our adventure tomorrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日からの冒険のために、力を残しておいた方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We went on an adventure trip up the Nile River, but my boyfriend caught West Nile Virus and he is still in the hospital.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私たち、ナイル川を遡るっていう冒険旅行をしたんだけど、彼氏が西ナイル熱にかかっちゃってさあ。未だに病院で入院してるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are trying to <kanji>research</kanji> the <kanji>extreme</kanji>s. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the <vocabulary>ultimate</vocabulary> weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Even Mr. Sakaki congratulated me on finding out the ultimate fundamental truth of the universe.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの榊氏までもが、私が宇宙の究極の原理を解明したことに祝いの言葉を述べてくれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If we <kanji>take along</kanji> our <kanji>alliance</kanji> and move it forward to something better, we have a <vocabulary>league</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>federation</vocabulary>. It's like we're one group now!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Figure skaters are complaining about the Japan Skating Federation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スケート選手たちは、日本スケート連盟について不平を漏らしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>hand</kanji>'s <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> is the back of it (see you can make it shaped like a turtle shell if you try hard!). That's why this is the <vocabulary>back of one's hand</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the respective vocab readings of <jp>手</jp> and <jp>甲</jp>.
Context 1-EN: She is proud that the backs of her hands are so beautiful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とても綺麗な手の甲を持っていることが彼女の自慢です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>special</kanji> and in a <kanji>hurry</kanji> must be special indeed. This refers to <vocabulary>limited express train</vocabulary>s in Japan. They go fast, they stop at fewer stops (because they're special!) and they hurry. Look out for these if you want to get somewhere in a jiffy.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the <jp>とく</jp> goes to <jp>とっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: We decided, spur of the moment, to take the limited express.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ノリで特急に乗ることに決めました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I had my checkup, they found something unusual in my EKG, so I have to go back for a complete physical at a university hospital in Osaka via the limited express train on Monday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>けんこうしんだんで、心電図に異常があったので、月曜日に特急に乗って大阪の大学病院まで行って、せいみつけんさを受けなければいけません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I already got an express ticket for you, so if you leave now you can still catch the 3:50 express train.
Context 3-JP: <jp>特急券を先に買っておいたので、今出れば三時五十分の特急に間に合うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
If you <kanji>extract</kanji> your <kanji>waist</kanji> you're pulling your body from the situation and trying to escape. What a <vocabulary>coward</vocabulary>. 

Or, picture a little kid trying hiding behind their mom. Try to extract them from behind their mom's waist. They're holding on! They don't want to come out. What a coward of a child!

There are lots of different kinds of cowards.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've learned already. Go you!
Context 1-EN: There are too many coward employees who resign before being promoted to management.
Context 1-JP: <jp>管理職に昇進する前に辞職する腰抜け社員が多すぎる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leak</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to leak</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you <vocabulary>to leak</vocabulary> all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend <reading>Moe</reading> (<jp>も</jp>). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.
Context 1-EN: Hey, doesn’t it smell like leaking gas?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねえ、なんかガスが漏れてる臭いがしない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>invade</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to invade</vocabulary> as well!
Reading Mnemonic: I'm going <vocabulary>to invade</vocabulary> your country, <reading>oka</reading>y (<jp>おか</jp>)? Sorry about that, but everything will be <reading>oka</reading>y when I'm done.
Context 1-EN: Many people are upset about their privacy being violated.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たくさんの人たちが、プライバシーを侵されたことに憤慨しています。</jp>

Meaning: Passing An Exam,Make The Grade,Passing The Exam
Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>reach</kanji>ed the <kanji>ordinal prefix number</kanji> that represents a passing score on my test. This means I was able to <vocabulary>make the grade</vocabulary> and have a status of <vocabulary>passing an exam</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Hey, do you remember what score you need to get a passing grade?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねぇ、及第点って何点だったか覚えてる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conceal</kanji>, so if you conceal yourself and walk around you are going <vocabulary>to lurk</vocabulary> or you are going <vocabulary>to lie dormant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>He so</reading> (<jp>ひそ</jp>) hidden. Where you at?
Context 1-EN: The crabigator might be lurking in the corners of your room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニはあなたの部屋の片隅に潜んでいるかもしれませんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something with <kanji>reason</kanji> you're arranging it. That's why this is <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I really appreciate that you organized the bookshelf.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本だなを整理してくれたこと、大変感謝しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It takes a great deal of time and effort to arrange all of these documents.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この書るいを全て整理するには、大変な時間と労力が必要である。</jp>
Context 3-EN: So let me get this straight. It’s okay for men to cheat, but not for women. Is that what you’re trying to say?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと話を整理させてね。つまり、男の人が浮気をするのはいいけど、女の人がするのはだめってこと？それがあなたの言いたいこと？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>believe</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to believe</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>信</jp> is <jp>しん</jp> no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: Believe it or not, Viet turned out to be a spy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>信じられないかもしれないが、実はビエトはスパイだったんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm the type of person who only trusts what they can actually see.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自分が目にしたもの以外は信じない主ぎなんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I guess I've been irritated lately by the fact that I no longer believe in Santa Claus.
Context 3-JP: <jp>自分がもはやサンタクロースを信じていないということに、最近イライラしている...と思うんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>build</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to build</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? <reading><jp>たてる</jp></reading>. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!
Context 1-EN: This man is well known for building very sturdy houses.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この男は、とても丈夫な家を建てることで有名です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The king built an unbelievably beautiful castle on top of the mountain.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その王は、山の上に信じられないほど美しいおしろを建てました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our company is saving money to build a school for children in another country.
Context 3-JP: <jp>我が社は、外国の子どもたちに学校を建ててあげるために貯金をしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>explanation</kanji> that's <kanji>bright</kanji> is just a really clear and well developed <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You need to formally explain this.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これについて、正式に釈明をする必要がある。</jp>

Meaning: To Make Dirty,To Make Something Dirty
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>汚れる</jp> is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "<vocabulary>to make dirty</vocabulary>." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you immediately. This happens a lot.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>汚れる</jp>, so if you know that you can read this.
Context 1-EN: We are out of clean bibs. Our baby boy got them all dirty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>綺麗な涎かけが無くなっちゃった。うちの赤ちゃんが全部汚しちゃって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that <kanji>hurry</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> faster than the other things are <vocabulary>express</vocabulary>. This is often used with trains or subways, so look out for it if you're looking to get somewhere in a hurry. Also be careful in case it doesn't stop at your stop, because <jp>急行</jp> trains don't stop at every station (which is what makes them express!).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The police officer hurried to the scene of the crime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>けいさつは、はんざいげん場へ急行しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I sent thank you gifts express to the people who were nice to me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私にやさしくしてくれた人たちに、急行便でお礼の品を送りました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh noooooo! The express train left. Now I'm going to be late. I’m really scared of being punished by Koichi.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あーーーしまったーーーー。急行列車が行ってしまった。ってことは私の遅刻も確定だ。コウイチから受ける処罰がすんごく怖いんですけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.
Context 1-EN: We are going to pass out various documents to each person present first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>各出席者の方に、まず諸書類をお配り致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Random</kanji> <kanji>magazine</kanji> is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a <vocabulary>magazine</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I really like the time-lapse photography on this magazine’s cover.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この雑誌の表紙のインターバル撮影された写真すごい好きかも。</jp>

Meaning: To Grow Longer,To Be Stretched,To Make Progress
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stretch</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to grow longer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be stretched</vocabulary>. You know that this is the version where you aren't doing the stretching, because you're letting someone stretch you on a torture rack in order to win a <reading>beer</reading> (<jp>びる</jp>). You're that desperate.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck!
Context 1-EN: Do you know why her English skills are rapidly improving?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして彼女の英語力がグングン伸びてるのか知ってる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>walk</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to walk</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <jp>ある</jp> portion. Imagine yourself going <vocabulary>to walk</vocabulary> outside. But, as you walk, you walk like a pirate. You have a peg leg, a parrot, and a hook. Lastly, you say "<reading>arrrrr</reading>" (<jp>ある</jp>). Go ahead, say it out loud while walking around your room like a pirate. It will help.
Context 1-EN: I’m planning to walk to school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学こうまで歩くつもりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's the first time we've walked holding hands in a long time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたと手をつないで歩くなんて、何年ぶりかしら。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m so fat that when I walk down the street and step on a penny, I squeeze a booger out of the Queen’s nose.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はとても太いので、私が道を歩いている時にペニーを踏んだら、女王様の鼻から鼻くそが飛び出ます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>enter</kanji> your <kanji>supply</kanji> into the machine, that is your <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary> for the day. Every day you have to enter your supply, otherwise they crack down on you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Where is the due date for the tuition payment written?
Context 1-JP: <jp>授業料の納入期限はどこに書いてありますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Because I couldn't prepare a big chunk of money immediately, I used the installment payment system.
Context 2-JP: <jp>急に大きいお金を準備できなかったから、分割納入制度を利用しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want you to deliver the product within five days, is that possible?
Context 3-JP: <jp>五日以内にその製品を納入して頂きたいのですが、可能でしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>search</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> things, you are probably part of a <vocabulary>criminal investigation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to draw up some important documents for a criminal investigation today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本日は捜査に関する重要書類を作成する予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adjective form of <jp>汚</jp>, which is <kanji>dirty</kanji>. This word is the adjective <vocabulary>dirty</vocabulary>, but you can also use it to say things like <vocabulary>filthy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>foul</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>unclean</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is different from the other kun'yomi readings you've learned so far with this word. It is <reading><jp>きたな</jp></reading>. Think of it like you're saying "<jp>来た、な</jp>", as in "it came, huh?" What came? A really dirty looking monster, and it's coming for you.
Context 1-EN: The dirty wash cloth fell into the toilet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>汚い雑巾が、トイレに落ちていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>healthy</kanji> bit of <kanji>forget</kanji>ting <kanji>symptom</kanji>s means you might have <vocabulary>amnesia</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have a relative who is suffering from amnesia.
Context 1-JP: <jp>健忘症に苦しんでいる親戚がいます。</jp>

Meaning: Fast Talker,Fast Talking,Fast Speaker,Fast Speaking,Quick Talker
Meaning Mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>fast</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji>, you're probably a <vocabulary>fast talker</vocabulary>, right motormouth?
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how body parts often change even jukugo words to kun'yomi readings? That's what happened here too. Both readings are kun'yomi, making this one <reading><jp>はやくち</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: My older brother is a really fast talker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの兄は、とても早口です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why did you say that you love me the most so quickly?
Context 2-JP: <jp>お前のことが一ばん大すきだよって、何でそんなに早口で言ったの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve never seen such a fast talking baby before.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こんなに早口の赤ん坊なんて見たことないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>群れ</jp> is a <kanji>flock</kanji>? This is the verb version, and means <vocabulary>to flock</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to crowd</vocabulary> together with a bunch of other people.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>群れ</jp>, so if you know that you can flock together the two memories in your brain.
Context 1-EN: I wonder why delinquent kids tend to hang out in front of the convenience stores in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして日本では、不良少年少女は、コンビニの前で群れる傾向があるんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Who are all <kanji>like</kanji> "I want to <kanji>preserve</kanji> and <kanji>protect</kanji> what I have, get out of my business, government!"? <vocabulary>Conservative</vocabulary> people, of course.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading doesn't match up for this word's <jp>守</jp>. The reading is <jp>しゅ</jp>, but you can remember that because the conservatives want to protect and preserve their <reading>hoe</reading>s (<jp>ほ</jp>) and their <reading>chute</reading>s (<jp>しゅ</jp>) from the government. For some reason those get taxed a lot.
Context 1-EN: My school was very conservative, so students were required to wear uniforms in accordance with the school regulations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>保守的な学校だったので、学生はみんな校そく通りにせい服を着用するよう要求されました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you think the Japanese are conservative people?
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本国民は、保守的な国民だと思いますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi told Viet that people tend to become more conservative as they get older, but he doesn’t want to be like that.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチはビエトに、年をとるにつれて保守的になる人が多いけど、俺はそうはなりたくない、と言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>god</kanji> <kanji>Nara</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kanagawa Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>か</jp> of <jp>神</jp> is used here (losing the <jp>み</jp>). Then, everything else should be self explanatory.
Context 1-EN: There is a boom in manga in Kanagawa Prefecture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>神奈川県では漫画がブームです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>mirror</kanji>s - that's <vocabulary>binoculars</vocabulary>. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>鏡</jp> part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for <jp>鏡</jp>). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, <reading>today</reading> (<jp>きょう</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: Do you have these binoculars in black?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この双眼鏡の黒はありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>weave</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to weave</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: When you have <vocabulary>to weave</vocabulary> the only thing you can weave is an <reading>O</reading> (<jp>お</jp>) shape. That's it. Just O's.
Context 1-EN: My mother is very much into handwoven carpets lately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の母親は、最近手織り機でカーペットを織ることにはまっているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fix</kanji> so the verb version is similar to that, <vocabulary>to be fixed</vocabulary>. This word is for when something is fixed, but you're not the one fixing it.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to learn the <jp>なお</jp> part. Think of it this way. Something needs <vocabulary>to be fixed</vocabulary>. It's urgent! You have to fix it <reading>now</reading>! (<jp>なお</jp>). This will also work with the similar word, <jp>直す</jp>, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.
Context 1-EN: When can I get my broken car fixed?
Context 1-JP: <jp>こしょうした車が直るのはいつですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If it makes you feel better, then I don't mind at all, Aya.
Context 2-JP: <jp>それでアヤの気げんが直るなら、おれはぜんぜんかまわないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The farmer’s broken tractor was fixed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>農夫の壊れたトラクターは直った。</jp>

Meaning: To Spit Out,To Disgorge,To Spew Out
Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>吐く</jp> is to throw up, and if <jp>出す</jp> is to remove or hand over, then if you throw up and hand that throw up over to someone via your throwing up, you are going <vocabulary>to spit out</vocabulary> at them, or <vocabulary>to spew out</vocabulary>, or something gross along those lines. Then again, this word can be used to be like "spit the info out already!" too, so it's not all spitting for reals.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>吐く</jp> and <jp>出す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The man spit out the candy he’d been sucking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>男は舐めていた飴を吐き出しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: Why don't we eat lunch together at that diner during our lunch break today?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の昼、あそこの定食屋でお昼一しょに食べようよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My alarm didn't go off and it was already noon when I woke up.
Context 2-JP: <jp>目ざまし時計が鳴らなくて、起きたらすでに昼だった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to take a one hour lunch break, so please hold my calls.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今から一時間昼休憩を取るので、電話は取り次がないようにしてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>第一</jp> is <vocabulary>the first thing</vocabulary>. <jp>段</jp> is a <kanji>step</kanji>. So, this is <vocabulary>the first step</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I may need to review the basics for the first step.
Context 1-JP: <jp>第一段階として、まずは基本の復習をしなくちゃいけないかもしれない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
Reading Mnemonic: Know how <jp>飛ぶ</jp> means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.
Context 1-EN: She performed a perfect triple axel, but her score wasn’t very good.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は完璧なトリプルアクセルを跳んだのに、スコアはあまり伸びなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>connection</kanji> <kanji>related</kanji> to another <kanji>connection</kanji> obviously has some kind of <vocabulary>connection</vocabulary>, at least between all those meanings.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Viet is a yakuza, but I can say for sure that he is not connected to that crime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトはヤクザだが、そのはんざいには関係してないとだん言できます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet is wondering if he should cut his connections with the yakuza and just focus on his work at Tofugu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは、ヤクザとの関係をたってトーフグの仕事に専念するかどうかまよっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "He’s been married before and has three kids." "I know, but that has nothing to do with it."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「彼は前に結婚していて、子供も3人もいるのよ。」「知ってるわよ。でも、それとこれとは関係ないでしょ。」</jp>
