Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cover</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hide</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You decide <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "<reading><jp>おお</jp></reading>!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you <jp>おお</jp> at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.
Context 1-EN: My garden is covered in fallen leaves.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の庭は落ち葉に覆われています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I’m weak-willed to pressure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺は押しに弱いんだよなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The only kind of <kanji>writing brush</kanji> you can use for <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>fountain pen</vocabulary>! All other pens run out of ink and then you're out of luck. But fountain pens can be refilled, making them work for pretty much exactly ten thousand years.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You dropped your fountain pen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>万年筆を落とされましたよ。</jp>

Meaning: Tale Of Genji,The Tale Of Genji
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>源氏</jp>? He has his own <jp>物語</jp>. This is the very first novel ever written (that we know about). This is the <vocabulary>Tale of Genji</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the combination of <jp>源氏</jp> and <jp>物語</jp> which you have learned before so you should have no problems with this one.
Context 1-EN: I’ve only read the manga version of the Tale of Genji.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は源氏物語を漫画でしか読んだことがありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>指揮</jp> is "command" or "lead" then <kanji>someone</kanji> who does those things is a <vocabulary>commander</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>conductor</vocabulary>. Usually the kind that conducts an orchestra!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is the reading of <jp>指揮</jp> plus the on'yomi reading of <jp>者</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Neither commander has come yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どちらの指揮者もまだ来てないんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>good</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>good</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

A <vocabulary>good</vocabulary> way to pass the time is with a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<jp>よ</jp>). But it better be a good yo-yo. A bad one will just fall apart.
Context 1-EN: Aries and Libra are compatible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お羊ざと天びんざは相しょうが良い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't they say, "The closer you are, the more you fight?"
Context 2-JP: <jp>けんかするほど仲が良いって言うだろ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: That’s a good idea, but the fact is that we don’t have enough money for it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>良い考えだけど、実際はそれをするには資金が足りないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Look to</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> to see how much longer this will last. It's not forever, it's <vocabulary>temporary</vocabulary>, which is why we must look to time to figure out how much longer it'll be around.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Mami got an extra bonus, so she bought more bacon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マミは、臨時のボーナスが出たので、さらにベーコンを購入した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>お</jp> makes the word more polite. You're elevating the "<vocabulary>older sister</vocabulary>" title because you're a good younger sibling. Otherwise, the meaning of this word is the same as the kanji - just the feeling is different. You can also use this word to refer to a youthful-looking woman that you don't know, as in "Excuse me <vocabulary>miss</vocabulary>!"
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is different too. It has some hiragana attached to it, which is a clue that this uses a kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to learn that reading. 

Imagine your <vocabulary>older sister</vocabulary> (even if you don't have one). She is, for some reason, a horse. Imagine petting her, giving her carrots, and doing other horse-related things with her. What do horses say? They say <reading>nehhhh</reading> (<jp>ねえ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Midori’s older sister is wearing glasses.
Context 1-JP: <jp>みどりちゃんのお姉さんはめがねをかけています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I totally thought you were Viet's older sister, but you aren't, eh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたのこと、てっきりビエトくんのお姉さんだと思ってたんですが、ちがったんですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My older sister thinks that buying a motorcycle will help her get a boyfriend.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私のお姉さんは、バイクを買うことが彼氏を見つけることに繋がると考えています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>poem</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji> is <vocabulary>poetry</vocabulary>. It's not quite a song but I think you can make the connection.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know these readings, but there's usually an extra <jp>い</jp> in the middle. Don't worry, <jp>しか</jp> is totally fine too, but <jp>しいか</jp> is more common. You got this!
Context 1-EN: I enjoy poetry every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日詩歌を楽しんでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Fugu's secret skill is composing marvelous poetry.
Context 2-JP: <jp>フグにはすばらしい詩歌を作るかくれた才のうがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Shiika means Japanese poetry and that generally includes kanshi, waka, or haiku.
Context 3-JP: <jp>詩歌とは日本の詩のことですが、一般的には漢詩や和歌、俳句のことを指します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>reject</kanji> <kanji>other</kanji>s, you are excluding them, doing <vocabulary>exclusion</vocabulary>. That's not a nice thing to do.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Japanese press club is fairly exclusive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本記者クラブはかなり排他的だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>come</kanji> to the party wearing something really, really <kanji>old</kanji>, everyone will know you're from <vocabulary>ancient</vocabulary> times (as if your wrinkles didn't give it away already, right?).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The kappa is an ancient Japanese yokai.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カッパは、日本古来のようかいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In ancient times, this pond was known as "WaniKani Pond."
Context 2-JP: <jp>古来、この池は、「ワニカニの池」という名まえでしられていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The toilet is a wonderful invention that has been handed down since ancient times to the present-day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トイレは、古来から現代へと受け継がれてきた素晴らしい発明品だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>shining</kanji> <kanji>peace</kanji> time was a time known as the <vocabulary>Showa Era</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the <vocabulary>Showa Emperor</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>Showa</vocabulary> itself. Everything Showa is here.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Which year of Showa were you born in?
Context 1-JP: <jp>昭和何年生まれですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>bright</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <jp>あか</jp> portion. What is <jp>あか</jp> in Japanese? It is "red." So, think of something that's really <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>. Now, imagine it being totally red (aka <jp>あか</jp>). In Japan, the color red is associated with the sun, and the sun is pretty bright. If you can remember this you can also remember the reading of this word.
Context 1-EN: This room is bright.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このへやは明るい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu workers are all cheerful people.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの社いんは、みんな明るい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your future is still bright, Grandpa.
Context 3-JP: <jp>未来はまだまだ明るいよ、おじいちゃん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <jp>幸</jp>. Kanji means <kanji>happiness</kanji> and the vocab word means <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

On your quest for true <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>, you meet a happiness guru. <reading>She always says</reading> (<jp>しあわせ</jp>), "just be happy!" She always says that, and you always listen. You can't believe how simple yet profound her approach is!
Context 1-EN: I wish you happiness for many years to come.
Context 1-JP: <jp>末ながくお幸せにね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A fortune teller told Viet that happiness will come to him within the year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは、うらないしから今年中に幸せがおとずれると言われました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I think money can buy happiness because watching fireworks makes me happy. If I had a lot of money, I could enjoy fireworks every day and feel happy all the time," she said happily.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「私はお金で幸せは買えると思います。何故なら、私は花火を見ていると幸せな気持ちになるからです。もし私が大金持ちだったら、毎日花火を楽しんでずっと幸せな気持ちでいられることができます。」彼女は幸せそうな口調でそう言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>Buddha</kanji>'s <kanji>image</kanji>. What is that? It's an <vocabulary>image of Buddha</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>statue of Buddha</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do I have to declare if I buy a statue of Buddha in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本で仏像を買ったら、申告しないといけませんか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Buddha statues are often made gold.
Context 2-JP: <jp>仏像はよく金色に作られています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Someone sends a Buddhist statue to our office every month. If you are that person, please come forward and identify yourself.
Context 3-JP: <jp>誰かがうちのオフィスに毎月仏像を一体ずつ送ってくるんです。心当たりのある方は、どうか名乗り出て下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>VIP</kanji> <kanji>come</kanji>s to your door. They're your <vocabulary>guest</vocabulary>! I hope you aren't going to make them sleep in the couch.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We’d like to thank everyone, including the guests, for honoring us with your presence while you’re all busy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来賓の方々をはじめ、皆様にはお忙しい中、ご臨席を賜り誠にありがとうございます。</jp>

Meaning: Last Ten Days Of The Month,End Of Month,End Of The Month
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>time of month</kanji> is the bottom part of the month. It's the <vocabulary>last ten days of the month</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>end of the month</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m planning to go back to Japan at the end of April and come back to the states at the beginning of June.
Context 1-JP: <jp>四月の下旬に日本に戻って、六月上旬にまたアメリカに戻ってくる予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You give your <kanji>congratulations</kanji> to someone a few times because they seem so <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vibrant</vocabulary>. You feel like you should because it must be nice to be like that still. Someday it will be gone, so make sure you say it a few times right away.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.
Context 1-EN: Everyone was fascinated by her vibrant voice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の瑞々しい歌声が人々を魅了した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>explode</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is when someone attacks with exploding things, like bombs. This is a <vocabulary>bombing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The chocolate factory crumbled to pieces from the bombing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのチョコレート工場は、爆撃を受けて粉々になりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means <vocabulary>chutzpah</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>courage</vocabulary> (besides just being <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary>). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary> isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you <reading>chemo</reading> (<jp>きも</jp>) to help get rid of that cancer.
Context 1-EN: I took another bite of chicken liver before going to the bathroom.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トイレに行く前に、鳥の肝をもう一口かじりました。</jp>

Meaning: To Humbly Receive,To Humbly Accept,To Humbly Eat,To Humbly Drink
Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>humbly</kanji> do something you are going <vocabulary>to humbly receive</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to humbly accept</vocabulary>, or eat or drink it. Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. And you can use this word for all of them!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You technically already know this reading! You know how people say <jp>いただきます</jp>? Well that's the same as this! You're humbly receiving your meal. So <vocabulary>to humbly receive</vocabulary> is <reading><jp>いただく</jp></reading>!
Context 1-EN: Thank you very much for your congratulations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お祝いを頂き、本当に有難うございます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>mercy</kanji> for people who are <kanji>sad</kanji> you have a lot of <vocabulary>compassion</vocabulary>. You just can't help but go easy on sad people.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My grandmother was a really compassionate person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>祖母は本当に慈悲深い人だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>product</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>brand new</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>new item</vocabulary>. I like looking around the store for the brand new stuff because it's interesting!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice though that <jp>ひん</jp> changes to <jp>ぴん</jp>. This is because you're buying some <vocabulary>brand new</vocabulary> pins?
Context 1-EN: I dropped my brand new abacus onto the train tracks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>線路に新品のそろばんを落としてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I spilt some fermented soy beans on my new jeans and that ruined my mood.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新品のジーパンになっとうをこぼしてしまって、テンションめっちゃ下がってます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I heard you bought a new computer." "Well, it’s not brand new. It’s a hand-me-down from Viet."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「新しいパソコンを買ったんだって？」「うーん。新品ではないんだけどね。ビエトのお下がりだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fire</kanji> in a <kanji>bottle</kanji> that makes a <kanji>big fire</kanji> when thrown is called a <vocabulary>Molotov Cocktail</vocabulary>. Don't throw them in the house please.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The man threw a Molotov cocktail.
Context 1-JP: <jp>男は火炎瓶を投げつけた。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Afflicted,To Be Afflicted With Illness,To Be Sick
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>afflicted</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be afflicted</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: I was afflicted with an ancient Egyptian disease that turned me into sun god Ra, but now I'm okay. I <reading>was a Ra</reading> (<jp>わずら</jp>), but now I'm just me again.
Context 1-EN: In the shelter there are many homeless people sick with tuberculosis.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シェルターには、結核を患うホームレスの人がたくさんいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>soup</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is what you use to refer to <vocabulary>soups</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is both the kun'yomi readings combined to form one word. So, you'll want to make sure you know the word <jp>汁</jp>.
Context 1-EN: He asked the waitress three times if there was any soup in the restaurant and she answered no each time. She was bewildered.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつ、あのウェイトレスさんに三回もこのレストランに汁物はないのかって聞きやがったんだぜ。ウェイトレスさんその度にありませんって言ってさ、困惑してたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Whittle down</kanji> and <kanji>decrease</kanji> something. This is a <vocabulary>reduction</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cutback</vocabulary>, since you're whittling down and decreasing it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ll have a hard time reducing the cost.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コストの削減に苦戦しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is the place you go to do your task of punishment. It is a <vocabulary>jail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prison</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This prison is full at the moment, so we’ll put you on the waiting list.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この刑務所は今満員なので、キャンセル待ちとさせて頂きますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who is so <kanji>afflicted</kanji> that you have to <kanji>hurry</kanji> and help is an <vocabulary>emergency patient</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The understaffed and overcrowded hospital refused to treat the emergency patient and he died, but it’s not all the hospital’s fault.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人員不足でごった返しになっていた病院が急患の受け入れを断ったせいで、男性が死亡したそうなんだけど、でもそれって病院だけのせいじゃないよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>carry</kanji> <kanji>happiness</kanji> with you, you look at the good side of everything and end up having really <vocabulary>good luck</vocabulary>. Someone who carries happiness will be really lucky in life.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ll get good luck with this good luck charm.
Context 1-JP: <jp>幸運になるおまじないよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This fortune cookie says that fortune will come to you if you help unpack moving boxes for somebody.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このフォーチュンクッキーには、だれかの代わりに引っこしの荷ときをしてくれたら、あなたに幸運がおとずれるでしょう、って書いてあるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm guessing that the meaning of Koichi's name is the "most lucky" person. What do you think?
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチの名前の意味は、一番幸運な人っていう意味なんじゃないかとすいそくしてるんだけど、どう思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>heights</kanji>. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is <vocabulary>Osaka</vocabulary>. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The <jp>大</jp> reads like <jp>おお</jp> from <jp>おおきい</jp>. Then, <jp>阪</jp> uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like <jp>坂</jp>, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen <jp>坂</jp> you can apply that reading over to here, making <jp>おおさか</jp>. Then again, if you know this word means <vocabulary>Osaka</vocabulary> you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double <jp>おお</jp> though!
Context 1-EN: I heard that not many cars obey the speed limit in Osaka, is that true?
Context 1-JP: <jp>大阪では、せいげん速度を守って走る車は少ないと聞いたんですが、本当ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was so excited about the Osaka trip that I totally neglected my studies.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大阪旅行が楽しみすぎて、勉強がすっかりお留守になってしまっていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m afraid I won’t be able to make it next Wednesday. What about going to Osaka next Thursday instead?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あいにくですが、来週の水曜日はちょっと都合がつかないんです。代わりに来週の木曜日に大阪に行くってのはどうでしょうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>tenacious</kanji>ly <kanji>wear</kanji> something. You have some kind of <vocabulary>attachment to</vocabulary> it. Some kind of <vocabulary>tenacity</vocabulary> that makes you <vocabulary>obsessed with</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’d like to write a novel about a guy who has an abnormal obsession with money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>異常なほどお金に執着する男の小説を書いてみたいんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Explode</kanji> <kanji>departure</kanji> is when an explode departures from a certain point, causing an <vocabulary>explosion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Her words caused him to explode with anger.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の一言が彼の怒りを爆発させました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The things that are <kanji>basics</kanji> (<jp>基本</jp>) <kanji>like</kanji> (<jp>的</jp>) are <vocabulary>basic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fundamental</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing how to read the word <jp>基本</jp> will be helpful too.
Context 1-EN: Basically, I have no interest in politics.
Context 1-JP: <jp>基本的に政治に関心がないんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was told by my boss that I don't even know the fundamentals and that I'm useless.
Context 2-JP: <jp>上司に、基本的な事も知らない役立たずだと言われました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How often are you surprised by making basic mistakes?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どのくらい頻繁に自分の超基本的な間違いにびっくりしますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the <vocabulary>tide</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>current</vocabulary>. These days, we usually use this word for the current <vocabulary>trend</vocabulary>s that come in like the tide.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They brought about a social trend against the rich.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼らは、富裕層に反対する社会的風潮を生み出した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Product</kanji>s you're paying a <kanji>fee</kanji> to <kanji>eat</kanji> later are your <vocabulary>groceries</vocabulary>. Buy them now, eat them later, yum!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I heard that the workers at the grocery section are making demands for higher wages.
Context 1-JP: <jp>食料品コーナーで働いている人たちが、ちん上げを要求しているらしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "Salmon, we should buy some groceries in case of emergency." "Fugu, we don't need to buy them. We have food here!" "Where?" "If we have trouble with food, we just need to prey on each other."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「サーモン、万が一にそなえて、食料品を買っておかなくちゃ。」「フグ、買わなくても大丈夫よ！食料品ならここにあるじゃない。」「え、どこに？」「食料にこまったら共食いすればいいだけじゃない。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you tell me where the grocery section is?
Context 3-JP: <jp>食料品売場はどこにありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: There is a girl’s ghost in the corner of the room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この部屋の隅に、少女の霊がいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>take</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to take something</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're the kind of person who likes <vocabulary>to take</vocabulary> things. "What things?" you ask. Little <reading>toe</reading>s (<jp>と</jp>). Because that isn't creepy.
Context 1-EN: I finally got my driver's license!
Context 1-JP: <jp>運転めんきょ証がやっと取れました！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you take a mug from the shelf for me?
Context 2-JP: <jp>たなからマグカップを取ってくれない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I take full responsibility for my actions. I am truly sorry.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私がこの行動の責任はすべて取ります。本当にごめんなさい。</jp>

Meaning: To Put Up A Sign,To Put Up
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>display</kanji>, so if you're doing the action of displaying something, you're going <vocabulary>to put up</vocabulary> something, or, sometimes more specifically, <vocabulary>to put up a sign</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You have <vocabulary>to put up</vocabulary> a sign for your newest invention, the <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>かか</jp>). It is a car made so that other cars can drive the car. Nobody wants to buy it, which is why you have <vocabulary>to put up a sign</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: James set a new goal: to bring his pencil sharpening to the next level.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ジェームズは、鉛筆削りの技術のレベルを上げるという目標を掲げた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>courage</kanji> and <kanji>daring</kanji>! You're a <vocabulary>brave</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>heroic</vocabulary> hero of old. A samurai perhaps?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Your father was a very brave soldier.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前の父さんは、とても勇敢な戦士だったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of <kanji>worry</kanji>, making it <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>worry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> about it.
Context 1-EN: I don’t mind hearing your advice about my troubles, but I’m running out of money. If you want to eat out with me, it’s your treat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>悩み事の相談に乗るのは構わないんだけど、金欠なんだよね。外食したいなら、あんたの奢りだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Your collar is twisted.
Context 1-JP: <jp>襟が曲がっていますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>struggle</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to struggle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fight</vocabulary>. This struggle is fairly figurative, too. It's more like "the struggle against terrorism" or "the fight against drugs." Not so much a fight with people, which would be <jp>戦う</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "<reading>ta ta, ca</reading>r (<jp>たたか</jp>). Ta ta."
Context 1-EN: These kids are all fighting against their diseases.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この子たちは、みんな病気と闘っているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the <jp>りょう</jp> reading, because you gotta get in your row boat to be a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I know that fisherman because he is my brother in law.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はその漁師を知っていますよ。私の義理の兄ですから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Your <vocabulary>younger sister</vocabulary> is really into <reading>emote</reading>s (<jp>いもうと</jp>). Look up this word if you're not a teenage girl. Just imagine her sending you these on your phone over and over. You tell your younger sister: "HEY, STOP SENDING ME EMOTES."
Context 1-EN: Who is Tanaka’s younger sister?
Context 1-JP: <jp>田中さんの妹はどの人ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I feel betrayed by my little sister.
Context 2-JP: <jp>妹にうら切られた気分です。</jp>

Context 3-JP: <jp>私の妹は、バービー人形にウィッグを作ってあげたいからと、自分の髪の毛を切った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: President Koichi was supposed to meet with the press corps, but he got food poisoning and it was canceled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ大統領は、報道陣と会見をする予定でしたが、食中毒にかかってしまったため中止となりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: People who are <kanji>biased</kanji> about what they <kanji>eat</kanji> usually only eat sweet stuff like candy and ice cream. This <vocabulary>picky eating</vocabulary> gives them a really <vocabulary>unbalanced diet</vocabulary>. Candy and ice cream are okay, but you have to be open to eating other things too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried because my kids tend to have unbalanced diets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子供が偏食がちなので困っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Ethics</kanji> and <kanji>reason</kanji> together in a person make them have very strong <vocabulary>ethics</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>morals</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please abide by business ethics properly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちゃんと職業倫理を守ってください。</jp>

Meaning: To Well Up,To Gush Forth,To Spring Out,To Surge
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>well</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to well up</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You're fishing in a hole in the ice when suddenly the water starts <vocabulary>to well up</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to gush forth</vocabulary> out of it. A huge <reading>wa</reading>lrus (<jp>わ</jp>) splashes out and jumps on you. No wonder there weren't any fish! This is a walrus hole.
Context 1-EN: Bitter tears welled up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>悔し涙が湧きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are <kanji>determine</kanji>d to get an <kanji>agreement</kanji> out of people so you decide to be really <vocabulary>positive</vocabulary> with them. As long as you make it seem like everything is super great, and totally good for them, they'll end up agreeing with everything you say.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why won’t you say yes or no?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして肯定も否定もしないんですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: First of all, try to affirm yourself.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まずは自分を肯定してみてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Cherish that positive feeling from now on.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その肯定の気持ち、これからも大切にしてね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things are <kanji>equal</kanji> in how they're <kanji>arrange</kanji>d. They have perfect <vocabulary>symmetry</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>balance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She has a very well proportioned body.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女はとても均整のとれた体形をしている.</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>orphan</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is sadly still an <vocabulary>orphan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I consulted my wife and we’ve decided to take charge of an orphan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妻と相談して、孤児を引き取ることにしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>baseball base</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is a <vocabulary>base hit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>single</vocabulary> in baseball terms. A <jp>二塁打</jp> is a double, a <jp>三塁打</jp> is a triple, and a homerun is something you'll learn here on WaniKani at some point if you haven't already.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!
Context 1-EN: It’s been a long time since he made a base hit. He always hits homeruns.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼が塁打を打つのは久しぶりだね。いつもはホームランだからな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Follow</kanji> people who <kanji>grieve</kanji> by <vocabulary>mourning</vocabulary> with them. You don't want to be the only one who doesn't seem sad.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>追</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're <vocabulary>mourning</vocabulary> the loss of your pet pig. You can't help but yell <reading>SOOEY</reading> (<jp>つい</jp>) to the sky, hoping she'll come back to life. It doesn't work so you stay in a state of mourning for the rest of your life. She was your best pig friend, after all.
Context 1-EN: Why don’t we open his memorial concert with everyone?
Context 1-JP: <jp>みんなで奴の追悼コンサートを開かないか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji> is when someone goes out to try to find people who do bad things, so that they can be punished. The people who do this are people like a <vocabulary>police detective</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>detective</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Without warning that officer grabbed my girlfriend’s arm and kissed her. So I punched him and he arrested me. It’s unfair.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その刑事は俺の彼女の腕を突然掴んで、彼女にキスをしたんだ。だから、俺はそいつを殴りつけてやったんだけど、そしたら逮捕されたんだよ。そんなの不公平だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Barbarian</kanji>s who live in <kanji>field</kanji>s, not even in huts or houses or anything, are called <vocabulary>savage</vocabulary> by people who DO live in huts and houses. They think if you live out in a field you're really <vocabulary>uncivilized</vocabulary>. But that's all a matter of opinion, I guess.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You must not associate with such savage people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そんな野蛮な人たちと付き合ってはいけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>write</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to write</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the on'yomi one, but this word is read with the kun'yomi, <jp>か</jp>. So just be sure to remember the kun'yomi reading to read this word in the <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>) ... or <vocabulary>to write</vocabulary> it, or whatever.
Context 1-EN: Even Japanese people are losing the ability to write, so WaniKani is just focusing on the readings and meanings of kanji.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本人でさえ漢字を書けなくなっている人がふえているので、ワニカニは漢字の読みと意味を重ししています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's handwriting is far from being good.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、お世辞にも字を書くのが上手だとは言えません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yay! I just hacked into Koichi’s Facebook account. Now I can make Koichi’s posts whatever I want to write about. Hehehe.
Context 3-JP: <jp>よっしゃ！今コウイチのフェイスブックアカウントをハッキングしてやったぜ！これから、コウイチのポストとして、何でも好きなことを書くことができる。へへへ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>retreat</kanji>, and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to retreat</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to withdraw</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to resign</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need <vocabulary>to retreat</vocabulary> because <reading>she re-zo</reading>ned (<jp>しりぞ</jp>) where you are standing. Now this is a no standing zone. Who is she? The re-zoner, duh.
Context 1-EN: It’s still too early for you to resign from your position as head softball coach.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ソフトボールチームのヘッドコーチのポジションを退くには、まだ早過ぎますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>lazy</kanji> <kanji>lazy</kanji> person is plagued with never ending <vocabulary>laziness</vocabulary>. They never get up. They just move slowly around the floor.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What do you think you can do to conquer your laziness?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうすれば怠惰を克服できるのでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning: To Appeal For,To Invite,To Raise,To Grow Violent,To Become Stronger
Meaning Mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>recruit</kanji> so the verb vocab version would, you'd think, be 'to recruit,' but it's <vocabulary>to appeal for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. So, it's kind of like recruiting, but instead of people, you're recruiting for things and actions.

This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean <vocabulary>to grow violent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become stronger</vocabulary>. It's like all of that recruiting is happening inside of you and causing some weird things to happen to you!
Reading Mnemonic: You'd like <vocabulary>to appeal for</vocabulary> <reading>two, no</reading> (<jp>つの</jp>), three things! Three!
Context 1-EN: My distrust for my wife is only growing stronger.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妻への不信感は募るばかりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's all appeal for funding together!
Context 2-JP: <jp>みんなで募金を募りましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned <jp>捕まる</jp> is "to be caught." Well this is the transitive version, so it means <vocabulary>to catch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to capture</vocabulary>. You (or someone else) is doing the catching, which is better than being the one who gets caught, I suppose.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is also not the same as <jp>捕まる</jp>. Sorry! It does have a similar reading to <jp>取る</jp> though, which also has to do with grabbing things (like grabbing onto an idea, for example). You can use <jp>取る</jp> as a jumping off point for remembering the reading of this word. You might also find it useful to think back to <jp>捉える</jp>, which has to do with mentally "catching" or "grasping" things.
Context 1-EN: I was able to capture the moment the sun rose with my camera.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ご来光のしゅん間をカメラで捕えることができました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Catching mice is my cat’s specialty.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の猫は鼠を捕えることが得意なんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>wash</kanji> <kanji>wash</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is where you go to get your clothes washed extra well. It's the <vocabulary>dry cleaners</vocabulary>! They wash your clothes way better than you can because they wash them twice.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for <jp>洗濯</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>屋</jp>. You've learned all of these readings by now, so you should be able to read this word too!
Context 1-EN: I’m going to pick up my dress shirt from the dry cleaners.
Context 1-JP: <jp>洗濯屋にワイシャツを取りに行ってきます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to return something</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: "I wish I hadn’t said that horrible thing to him." "Yeah, but once you say something you can’t go back to before."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「彼にあんなひどいこと言わなければよかったわ。」「そうね。でも、言ってしまったことはもう元には戻せないわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sink</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sink</vocabulary>. 

This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you're sinking something else. You can differentiate it from the intransitive <jp>沈む</jp> by imaging that you're watching an enemy ship sink, and they shout out, "Who did this to me!" You respond, <reading>me</reading> (<jp>め</jp>). I did."
Reading Mnemonic: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "<reading>she's</reading> (<jp>しず</jp>) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.
Context 1-EN: He is watching the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony and sinking into the sofa.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はソファに身を沈めながら、アカデミー賞の授賞式の生中継を観ています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The things that <kanji>line up</kanji> are the <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>average</vocabulary> things. The extraordinary things skip the line, because they don't have to wait. Sad for all the ordinaries.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: All the people who went off to fight in <reading>Nam</reading> (<jp>なみ</jp>) were just <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>average</vocabulary> folk.
Context 1-EN: He had ordinary reflexes, but a great mind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>運動神経は並だったが、頭はすこぶる良かった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Clumsy</kanji> and <kanji>immature</kanji> people end up being really <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary>. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary>, if you didn't already guess that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s not a very good article, but please read it if you’d like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>稚拙な文章ですがもしよければ読んでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>規模</jp> is <kanji>scale</kanji>? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a <vocabulary>large scale</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Hosokawa thanked Kojima for helping him stage a large-scale rally against resuming nuclear power plant operations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>細川は、原発再稼働に反対する大規模デモの実現に協力してくれたことについて、児島に礼を述べた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>oil</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is an <vocabulary>oil painting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for <jp>油</jp> (which you learned with the vocabulary) and the on'yomi for <jp>絵</jp> (which you learned with the kanji).
Context 1-EN: I bought this oil painting for 1500 yen at a flea market.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この油絵はフリマで千五百円で買ったんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My grandmother used to collect oil paintings.
Context 3-EN: What's the most famous brand of oil paints?
Context 3-JP: <jp>油絵用の絵の具で有名なブランドは？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>gulf</kanji> isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents <vocabulary>Taiwan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>たい</jp> for <jp>台</jp>, which is a little different from what you learned, but not the end of the world (especially if you can get the meaning down). The <jp>わん</jp> is however what you learned, so even if you arrive to <jp>だいわん</jp>, you'll probably realize that this is <jp>たいわん</jp>.
Context 1-EN: We’ve traced the source of the infection and it was a flock of ducks in Taiwan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>感染源を台湾のアヒルの群れだと突き止めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fragrance</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kagawa Prefecture</vocabulary>. Might help to look at the reading first.
Reading Mnemonic:
This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for <jp>香</jp> and <jp>川</jp> (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for <jp>県</jp>. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>香</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help:

If you want to get to <vocabulary>Kagawa Prefecture</vocabulary> you're going to need a <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!
Context 1-EN: Both Mr. and Mrs. Fugu live in Kagawa prefecture, but they live apart from each other now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグ夫妻は二人とも香川県には住んでいるが、別居中です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>sink</kanji> and <kanji>die</kanji> it's because you were <vocabulary>sinking</vocabulary> in the ocean or a pool or something. It's important to notice you're <vocabulary>going down</vocabulary> so you don't die like that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There’s a person who predicted the sinking of the Titanic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>タイタニック号の沈没を予言していた人がいるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: All the extra things in your <kanji>head</kanji> <kanji>die</kanji> when you <vocabulary>immerse yourself</vocabulary> in one thing. That way the one thing you're focusing on is the only thing your brain hears.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.
Context 1-EN: If you can immerse yourself in things you like, you’ll be happy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>好きなことに没頭できるなんて、幸せですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: The word "county" is now often used in place names.
Context 1-JP: <jp>現在、郡は地名に使われることが多い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have gotten a mission. You must go out and <kanji>detain</kanji> a dangerous criminal to <kanji>protect</kanji> your country. While you go do that, you will be <vocabulary>away from home</vocabulary> and have an <vocabulary>absence</vocabulary> from society.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mom is out shopping, so my sister and I are house sitting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母は買い物に出かけているので、私と妹が留守番をしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I visited Koichi's house, but he was not there.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの家にいってみたが、留守でした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My husband is always away from home because of his business trips. I get very lonely so I call him at least five times a day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の夫は出張で留守がちです。夫が留守にしてる間、とても寂しいので、一日少なくとも五回は電話をします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Use <kanji>attire</kanji> that <kanji>imitate</kanji>s your surroundings to create a <vocabulary>disguise</vocabulary>. Or throw on some <vocabulary>camouflage</vocabulary> so that no one will be able to find you in Walmart.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You must not excuse the food company’s disguise.
Context 1-JP: <jp>食品会社の擬装を許してはいけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Our house is right next to the house with a brown gate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私たちの家は、茶色い門のある家のすぐとなりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you pass under the big gate, you will see the holy shrine.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あそこの大きい門をくぐると神でんが見えるよ。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>門には鍵がかかっているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: He who is both in his <kanji>infancy</kanji> and <kanji>immature</kanji> is probably <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>immature</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Why do so many Japanese girls speak like children?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして幼稚な喋り方をする日本人女性が多いのですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a vocab is alone with no okurigana (that's hiragana attached to a kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji too. That goes for this word as well. So, if you know the kanji's meaning (<kanji>seven</kanji>) you'll know the vocab's meaning (<vocabulary>seven</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: Most single-kanji all-alone vocab words like this use the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this rule. That being said, four and seven are exceptions to this exception to the rule (because the on'yomi readings sound too much like the word for "death"). You should learn both readings for this word, though we're going to go with <jp>なな</jp> for the main one here. You can remember that because you had seven <reading>nana</reading>s after you.
Context 1-EN: Why don’t we meet at the station at seven tomorrow morning?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あしたのあさ、七じにえきであいませんか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to be friends with the seven dwarves.
Context 3-JP: <jp>七にんのこびととともだちになりたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>yearn for</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to yearn for</vocabulary>. But that sounds kinda old fashioned, so you can just use <vocabulary>to adore</vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You realize you're starting <vocabulary>to yearn for</vocabulary> someone way more than you used to. "<reading>Sh*t</reading> (<jp>した</jp>)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!
Context 1-EN: I adored him like an older brother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は彼のことを兄のように慕っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>盛り上げる</jp> is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going <vocabulary>to get excited</vocabulary>. Note how <jp>上がる</jp> is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>盛り</jp> and <jp>上がる</jp>. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.
Context 1-EN: Kids can take the most mundane, random things and get so excited.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもっていうのは、どんなささいなことでも手当たり次第に盛り上がることができるのよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>laugh</kanji>ing <kanji>face</kanji> is a <vocabulary> smiling face</vocabulary> (or just a <vocabulary>smile</vocabulary>!). <jp>笑顔s</jp> all around!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word won't make you <vocabulary>smile</vocabulary>, though. You were smiling, but then you heard about the reading of this kanji. It made you yell out "<reading>EH</reading>??" (<jp>え</jp>). Just watch out for the rendaku of <jp>かお</jp> to <jp>がお</jp>.
Context 1-EN: That smiling face proves Koichi's integrity, eh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの笑顔がコウイチのせい実さを証明しているよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The prince of this country is a very terrible man who kills his citizens with a smile.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この国の王子は笑顔で国民を殺すとてもひどい男です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This smiling, lovely guy with me is Koichi.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この笑顔の素敵な男は俺の連れで、コウイチっていうの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>恥ずかしい</jp> is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be shy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be bashful</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>恥ずかしい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Although she was determined to become a stripper, she’s still shy about dancing naked in public.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ストリッパーになると自分で決断したにも関わらず、彼女はまだ人前で裸で踊ることを恥ずかしがっているんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We're <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>together</kanji> on this information. Just you and me, inside our knowledge. It is <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>confidential</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I secretly record conversations with my IC recorder.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はICレコーダーで会話を内緒で録音します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>preface</kanji> of <kanji>order</kanji> is still <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>. Because order is always prefaced by more order. Order keeps us all in check.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please do not disturb order.
Context 1-JP: <jp>秩序を乱すようなことはしないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The final <kanji>bullet</kanji> of <kanji>censure</kanji> is <vocabulary>impeachment</vocabulary>. You've already been publicly humiliated and now you're being impeached because of it. Yikes.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A large-scale anti-government demonstration was held for the impeachment of the President.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大統領の弾劾を求める大規模な反政府デモが開かれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It’s the era of <kanji>Bright</kanji> <kanji>Rule</kanji>! If this doesn't make sense, don't worry about it. Focus more on the reading, which is <jp>めいじ</jp>. Sound familiar? This is the famous <vocabulary>Meiji Era</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Meiji Emperor</vocabulary>. If you don't know about it consider reading up, it's interesting history!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My grandmother was born in the Meiji era, and she devotedly practiced the Buddhist teachings when she was alive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>明治生まれのそ母は、生前は仏教の教えをちゅう実に守っていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm writing a paper about the Meiji Restoration.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明治い新についてのろん文を書いています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was watching a drama series about life in the Meiji period and I was surprised that ten thousand yen was a large amount of money back then.
Context 3-JP: <jp>明治時代の生活を描いたドラマを見ているんですが、当時は一万円が大金だったということに驚きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The best time to plant <vocabulary>seedling</vocabulary>s is at <reading>nigh</reading>t (<jp>なえ</jp>). If you plant them at night they'll sleep through the whole transplanting process and they'll wake up happy and ready to grow.
Context 1-EN: I planted seedlings in April.
Context 1-JP: <jp>四月に苗を植えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of <reading>salt</reading> (<jp>しお</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Can’t we find out when the tide rises by looking online?
Context 1-JP: <jp>インターネットで調べたら潮の満ち引きの時刻が分かるんじゃない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>far</kanji> <kanji>consider</kanji> is when you let your considerations go far from you so you don't think about how angry you are about what's going on in front of you. It allows you to have some <vocabulary>restraint</vocabulary>, since your considerations are far from here. It also allows you to <vocabulary>decline</vocabulary> things, since you're not considering the other person's feelings.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Don’t hesitate to ask me any questions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>質問があればどんなものでも遠慮なくおっしゃって下さいね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: If you don’t have a bottle opener, I know a trick to open a beer bottle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>栓抜きが無くても瓶ビールの栓を抜く裏ワザを知っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>吸う</jp> meaning "to smoke" and <jp>殻</jp> meaning "shell" or "husk." The husk left over after you're done smoking is the <vocabulary>cigarette butt</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>tobacco ashes</vocabulary> if you just have a pile of them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>吸う</jp> and <jp>殻</jp>. Change the <jp>う</jp> to <jp>い</jp> and don't forget the rendaku, and you should be able to remember this reading too!
Context 1-EN: If two cigarette butts pile up, please empty the ashtray immediately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>吸い殻が二本たまったら、すぐに灰皿を交換してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There is much <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>theory</kanji> exchanging when you are trying to present an <vocabulary>argument</vocabulary>. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument."

Context 1-EN: Koichi and the others are discussing whether we should take a plane or a boat to Japan.

Meaning Mnemonic: If there is only <kanji>semi</kanji> <kanji>criticism</kanji> on a law <vocabulary>ratification</vocabulary> is still possible. It's only if everyone criticizes it that it won't be ratified.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The ratification of New START is a maximum priority issue.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新戦略兵器削減条約の批准を最優先課題としています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: With lots of <kanji>grief</kanji> and <kanji>gloom</kanji> in your life you'll probably end up in a spiral of <vocabulary>depression</vocabulary>. Don't worry, you'll be okay. Things get better with time so don't give into the <vocabulary>gloom</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>会社へ出勤するのが憂鬱です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>lack</kanji> <kanji>stretch</kanji>ing, your body has to get that energy out somehow, so you end up <vocabulary>yawning</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've never seen more <vocabulary>yawning</vocabulary> than when you performed <reading>acu</reading>puncture (<jp>あく</jp>) on a <reading>bee</reading> (<jp>び</jp>). It was so relaxed from being the one poked for once that it just couldn't stop yawning.
Context 1-EN: It was too boring and I yawned.
Context 1-JP: <jp>退屈すぎて欠伸が出てきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Before you can give an <kanji>explanation</kanji> of who you are to someone you're about to <kanji>meet</kanji>, you have to <vocabulary>nod</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bow</vocabulary> as a <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary> first. It's rude to start explaining who you are before you greet them.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>会</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When someone <vocabulary>bow</vocabulary>s to you, you always feel a little uncomfortable, so you say, "<reading>Eh</reading>" (<jp>え</jp>) and try to get them to stop. You're so uncomfortable that you can't think of words and "eh" is all you can manage to get out.
Context 1-EN: You might have the decency to return my nod with a nod.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会釈をしたら会釈を返すのが礼儀でしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>first</kanji> thing is <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary> thing.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>cluster</kanji> is when you get a bunch of warmth together, and then use it to warm your home. This is indoor <vocabulary>heating</vocabulary>, kind of like the same way how an air conditioner is a "cool cluster."

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Usually it's attached to things, because it tells you what kind of ticket something is.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Join</kanji> and <kanji>join</kanji> with each other. This is a <vocabulary>merger</vocabulary>.

Context 1-EN: The United States of America annexed Texas the year I was born.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカ合衆国は、私が生まれた年にテキサスを併合しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
With time your <kanji>body</kanji> will <kanji>acquire</kanji> a certain type of <vocabulary>character</vocabulary>. It shows your true <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> as a person.

Note: We almost always use this word in the phrases <jp>得体が知れない</jp>/<jp>得体の知れない</jp>, so check out the context sentences to see what kind of "character" we're talking about.

Context 3-JP: <jp>得体の知れない何かが、猛スピードで迫ってくるような感覚に襲われ、冷や汗が止まらなくなりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>degree</kanji> of your <kanji>spirit</kanji> is what helps you to hone your <vocabulary>precision</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>accuracy</vocabulary>, for some reason. Just imagine yourself throwing a ball. You miss the target. Hmm, okay... time to power up like on Dragonball. Up that spirit energy. Turn the degrees up on it. Boom. Awesome. Now throw again. Hit! You hit it! What great <vocabulary>precision</vocabulary> you have gained by honing your spirit!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>profit</kanji> is really a <kanji>benefit</kanji>. Let's make more <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary> then.

Context 1-JP: <jp>この新しいタイプの下着が、莫大な年間利益を上げることを予想しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>戯れる</jp> can mean "to play" or "to flirt?" Well this is when you <vocabulary>play flirt</vocabulary>! Or just make a <vocabulary>joke</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <vocabulary>Kansai</vocabulary> region of Japan is the Southern Central part of Japan. It actually <kanji>connects</kanji> the East side of Japan (at least back in the day) to the West side, making it the "connection to the west." For our purposes, though, we should call it "Kansai."
Reading Mnemonic: Urgh, what a confusing reading! The <jp>西</jp> is <jp>さい</jp> instead of <jp>せい</jp>. Readings like this just make you want to <reading>sigh</reading> (<jp>さい</jp>), no?

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>Life</kanji> <kanji>guarantee</kanji> is something you get on someone else. If their life ends, it's guaranteed with money. That's a <vocabulary>life insurance</vocabulary> policy, for yah! (A.K.A. <vocabulary>life assurance</vocabulary> in some parts of the world!)
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>peak</kanji> of the mountain is a <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mountain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you climb to the top of the <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary>, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is <reading><jp>竹</jp></reading> (<jp>たけ</jp>). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...
Context 1-EN: There is a mountain called Tsurugidake, which literally means Mt. Sword, in Toyama prefecture.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Spirit</kanji> of the <kanji>god</kanji>s. This refers to both the "religious spirit" and the "spirit spirit." It's your <vocabulary>spirit</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pure</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "In order to stay <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>, you shouldn't ever do anything dirty or bad. That is the <reading>key, yo</reading> (<jp>きよ</jp>)."

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It's worth mentioning that a more common way to say beach is <jp>ビーチ</jp>, and many people actually say <jp>海</jp> even though this literally means "sea".

They fill you all the way up and you can't help but tell everyone about them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shift</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shift</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: All that dubstep (<reading><jp>うつ</jp></reading>) playing downstairs is causing all of your glassware <vocabulary>to shift</vocabulary> off the shelf and onto the floor. Damn that dubstep. <jp>うつうつうつうつうつ♪</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>hold</kanji> on and <kanji>preserve</kanji> something you are doing the act of <vocabulary>retention</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>maintenance</vocabulary> on it. This is <vocabulary>preservation</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>cure</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to cure</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to ease</vocabulary> something. This particular verb is when someone does the curing. The illness or injury doesn't just get better by itself. How can you remember that? Because when you try to heal someone and you mess up, they can try to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I need you <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary> him, and I need you to heal him right <reading>now</reading> (<jp>なお</jp>). NOW NOW NOW! 

This also shares the reading for <jp>直す</jp>, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word <jp>なおす</jp> was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.

Meaning Mnemonic: This is like a fancy and humble way of saying <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>. Sure, the kanji means <kanji>suppose</kanji>, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why <jp>存じる</jp> means <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's another way of saying <kanji>wise</kanji>? <vocabulary>Smart</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>discerning</vocabulary>.
