Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>bay</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> isn't what you might think, it refers to <vocabulary>Edo</vocabulary>, which is what Tokyo was called back in the day. You'll still see references to it everywhere, though, so it's good to learn. You can also call this <vocabulary>Tokyo</vocabulary> if you want, but I'd prefer if you answered "Edo," instead.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Of course, it will be easy if you know the word <vocabulary>Edo</vocabulary> already.
Context 1-EN: Stop mucking around and go upstairs and do your homework. You said you gotta write an essay about the Edo period in Japan, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>だらだらしてないで、さっさと二階に行って宿題をしなさい。日本の江戸時代についてレポートを書かないといけないって言ってたでしょ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>感慨</jp> meaning "strong feelings" and <jp>深い</jp> meaning "deep." Something that makes you feel strong emotions deep down inside is <vocabulary>deeply moving</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of a jukugo word and an i-adjective. You've learned both of them so just mash them together, with the rendaku making <jp>ふ</jp> to <jp>ぶ</jp>, and you've got the reading down pat!
Context 1-EN: This is the first time my writing will be published, so of course it’s a deeply moving thing for me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>初めて自分の書いたものが出版されるのは、やっぱり感慨深いものがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>diagram</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is an <vocabulary>illustration</vocabulary> that is used as an <vocabulary>explanatory diagram</vocabulary>. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm looking for a textbook with illustrations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>図説付きの参考書をさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Aya made an explanatory diagram of the in-house Tofugu relationships.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アヤが、トーフグ社内の人間関係の図説を作ってくれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think it would be easier to understand if there was an illustration with an explanation, what do you think?
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし解説と共に図説があれば、より分かりやすくなるかと思うんですが、如何でしょうか？</jp>

Meaning: Loss Of A Close Game,Regrettable Defeat
Meaning Mnemonic: Your team was about to win the game but you decided to be <kanji>frugal</kanji> with your shots near the end and it resulted in <kanji>failure</kanji>, making it a <vocabulary>loss of a close game</vocabulary>. If you had just taken those shots your team probably would have won. What a <vocabulary>regrettable defeat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our school missed getting into the top eight by losing a close game.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わが校は、惜敗でベスト8入りを逃しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fee</kanji> for <kanji>fragrance</kanji> and <kanji>spicy</kanji> in your food is the fee of <vocabulary>spices</vocabulary>. If you don't pay your spices fee, you aren't going to have any spice or fragrance in your food. If you do, you'll have those things and your food will be awesome!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The cumin seed is one of the most important spices for Indian curry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クミンシードは、インドカレーには欠かせない香辛料のうちの一つです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you <reading>cuss yuri</reading> (<jp>くすり</jp>) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.
Context 1-EN: When I take medicine, I pinch my nose tight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鼻をきつくつまみながら薬を飲みます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: His life is loaded up with drugs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの男は、薬づけの生活を送っている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My favorite kind of medicine is the suppository kind.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は薬の中で座薬が一番好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Append</kanji> and <kanji>attach</kanji> this document to your email. It's an <vocabulary>attachment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>添</jp> is what you'd expect. The reading for <jp>付</jp> is the on'yomi reading, which you've never learned. It's <jp>ふ</jp>, but for this word it becomes <jp>ぷ</jp> from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an <vocabulary>attachment</vocabulary> where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of <reading>poo</reading>p (<jp>ぷ</jp>). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.
Context 1-EN: Dear hiring manager, please have a look at the resume attached to this email. Thank you for your time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人事部長様、 恐れ入りますが、このEメールに添付された履歴書にお目通し頂けますでしょうか。お忙しいとは存じますが、よろしくお願い申し上げます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>distract</kanji> and the adjective version is <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misleading</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You know who is particularly <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary>? That <reading>maggie</reading> (<jp>まぎ</jp>) girl. She's confusing because she uses <reading>magi</reading>c (<jp>まぎ</jp>). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.
Context 1-EN: It was a basketball after all, but it was really misleading. I thought it looked exactly like a pregnant woman’s stomach.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結局それはバスケットボールだったんですが、とても紛らわしかったです。私は完全に妊婦さんの大きなお腹だと思っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Mediocre</kanji> and <kanji>common</kanji> things are still <vocabulary>mediocre</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>common</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He was a mediocre man but was filled to the brim with love.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は凡庸な男ですが、愛に満ちあふれていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <kanji>rest</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> then there are <vocabulary>no holidays</vocabulary>. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is <vocabulary>always open</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>nonstop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi usually works without taking holidays.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは大てい無休で働いている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Kana and Mami are making WaniKani example sentences without any breaks.
Context 2-JP: <jp>カナとマミは、無休でワニカニの例文を作っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu’s website is always open, twenty-four hours a day, every day of the year.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguのウェブサイトは、24時間年中無休で開いております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>orphan</kanji> is <kanji>stand</kanji>ing <vocabulary>alone</vocabulary> in the streets. Orphans don't have any parents and most of the time they're <vocabulary>friendless</vocabulary> too. It's really sad.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The incident is isolated to their place of work.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ある事件があって、職場で孤立してしまったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>append</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to append</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>To append</vocabulary> something to something else, you can just <reading>sew</reading> (<jp>そ</jp>) it onto something else.
Context 1-EN: The chef garnished the steak with some vanilla ice cream.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのシェフは、ステーキにバニラアイスクリームを添えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Seeing the <vocabulary>bell</vocabulary>, you decide you need to ring it. You take your <reading>cane</reading> (<jp>かね</jp>) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.
Context 1-EN: Apparently he raised the price of the bell shaped charm since I told him that I was a tourist, but I felt a little sorry for him, so I didn’t say anything and paid the price he told me anyway.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私が旅行者だと言うと、男は鐘の形をしたお守りの値段を明らかに釣り上げたが、何だかそいつに悪い気がして、そのまま何も言わずに言われた通りの値段を払ったんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is an <kanji>eye</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji>? Oh wait, that's easy. It's an <vocabulary>eyeball</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 目玉, however, is an exception. Perhaps this is because it includes a body part (the eye) in it, which often makes a word switch to kun'yomi readings. Either way, it doesn't matter too much. Both the readings you learned for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi, meaning you should know how to read this one. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: I’ll use these potatoes for the snowman’s eyeballs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このじゃがいもを、ゆきだるまの目玉にします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The princess' hobby is to collect eyeballs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王女は目玉をコレクションするしゅみがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think these grapes look like monster eyeballs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ようかいの目玉のようなぶどうだとおもう。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Changed,To Be Transformed,To Be Altered,To Vary,To Be Turned
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how <jp>変える</jp> means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, it means <vocabulary>to be changed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be altered</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: Whoever said that fried bacon tastes the same no matter how you make it was wrong.
Context 1-JP: <jp>だれがベーコンをやいてもおいしさはそんなに変わらないと言うのはうそです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The custom varies from country to country, so we should just get used to it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>習かんは国によって変わりますから、なれるしかないですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t believe how much makeup can change a face.
Context 3-JP: <jp>化粧でこんなに変わるものかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dry</kanji> <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> is one that's worth cheering to. This is the Japanese way to say "cheers!" or "toast" or whatever else you say before drinking something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Alright, cheers cheers! Hey, bottoms up!
Context 1-JP: <jp>さあ、乾杯、乾杯！それ、ぐいと一杯、飲み干したまえ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>This</kanji> (<jp>この</jp>) <kanji>approximate</kanji> is this approximate time. It is <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nowadays</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>these days</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>頃</jp> reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.
Context 1-EN: These days I’ve been adding chopped hazelnuts to my coffee for added flavor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この頃、風味を出すために砕いたヘーゼルナッツを珈琲に加えてるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>earnings</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to earn income</vocabulary>, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be <vocabulary>to make money</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You earn your income, and every time you're paid, you're given your money in a brief<reading>case</reading> (<jp>かせ</jp>). Imagine getting your income from a briefcase, opening it up, and grabbing the money from within. Then, you have to give the briefcase back at the specified dropoff.
Context 1-EN: Do you know how much more money the incumbent president earns than the former president?
Context 1-JP: <jp>現職の大統領が、前大統領よりもどれだけ多くのお金を稼いでいるか知っているかい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is <vocabulary>one's youth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>early life</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>若い</jp> and <jp>頃</jp> combined into one.
Context 1-EN: When I was young, I didn’t care about what I ate, but now I do and I always add a little less sugar than the recipe calls for because my doctor told me that I’m at risk for diabetes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>若い頃は食べ物について気にしなかったけど、今はお医者さんに糖尿病予備軍だって言われたので、食べ物に気をつけるようになったし、いつもレシピに書かれてるよりも少ない砂糖を入れるようにもなりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>win</kanji> <kanji>especially</kanji> well everyone will find you <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary>. So get out there and win!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That’s an admirable woman.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは殊勝な女だったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something has <kanji>showy</kanji> <kanji>beauty</kanji> then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as <vocabulary>gaudy</vocabulary>. Too much is too much.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Shouldn’t you restrain yourself from wearing gaudy clothing?
Context 1-JP: <jp>華美な服装は控えた方がいいんじゃないですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you make your <kanji>theory</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with an <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary> for it. Before it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you give your explanation, it gets bright and easy to understand! Yay!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please explain why you suddenly slowed down the train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電車のスピードを急に落とした理由を説明してください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How could he be fit to be company president with a terrible explanation like that?!
Context 2-JP: <jp>あんな無茶苦茶な説明で、よく会社の社長がつとまるよな。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry, I don’t understand at all. What does your explanation mean?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ごめん。さっぱり分からないよ。要約すると、説明の趣旨は何なの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>中国</jp> is China, right? That's what this <jp>中</jp> represents. And, of course the Chinese are known for being super showy, which is why you have <kanji>showy</kanji> there.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m in the mood for Chinese. Do you want to go out to eat Chinese with me tonight?
Context 1-JP: <jp>中華料理が食べたい気分だ。今夜一緒に中華食べに行かないか？</jp>

Meaning: To Be Split,To Be Torn,To Burst Apart
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>split</kanji>, so this verb has to do with something splitting. 

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be split</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be torn</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to burst apart</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <jp>裂く</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Lately, I've been eating cheese that can be split (AKA string cheese) every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近は毎朝、裂けるチーズを食べています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hey, Kenichi. Your jeans are torn at the crotch.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ねえ、ケンイチ君。ジーンズの股が裂けてるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm so sad that my heart feels like it will burst apart.
Context 3-JP: <jp>悲しすぎて、心が裂けちゃいそうだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scream</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to scream</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you want <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary> at someone you should pick a word that will really hit them. Give them a big <reading>whammy</reading> (<jp>わめ</jp>) to the face! Hey, that word works. Shout WHAMMY!
Context 1-EN: A drunk guy is shouting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>酔っぱらいが喚いているんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Gender</kanji> <kanji>love</kanji> is that kind of love that has to do with gender parts. That's <vocabulary>sexual love</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm studying sexual love at university.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学で、性愛学について勉強しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Interfering with another married couple's sexual love is just indecent.
Context 2-JP: <jp>他人の夫婦の性愛に口出しするなんて、下品にもほどがあるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m not sure if I’m asexual or have erotophobia.
Context 3-JP: <jp>性欲が無いのか性愛恐怖症なのか自分では判断できません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wash</kanji> your clothes with a <kanji>dose</kanji> of <vocabulary>detergent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why did it take you three hours to buy one bottle of detergent?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして洗剤一本買うだけで三時間もかかるの。</jp>

Meaning: To Stare At,To Look At,To View,To Gaze At
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stare</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stare at</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to look at</vocabulary> in a very staringish way).
Reading Mnemonic: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is <jp>長い</jp>, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's <reading><jp>なが</jp></reading>, just like <jp>ながめる</jp>'s kanji-part reading.
Context 1-EN: My nephew likes watching the Shinkansen so much that he can stare at it all day long.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの甥っ子は新幹線を見るのが好きで、一日中眺めていることもできます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have the <kanji>nature</kanji> of being <kanji>lazy</kanji> it will become a <vocabulary>habit</vocabulary>. The <vocabulary>momentum</vocabulary> created by your natural laziness will make it so you can't break out of your lazy cycle.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I had no will to study, I simply attended university out of habit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕は、勉強への意欲は無く、ただ惰性で大学へ通っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>hall</kanji> is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a <vocabulary>cafeteria</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>dining hall</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>diner</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The owner of this diner is so old fashioned that he insists that men shouldn't interfere in domestic matters.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この食堂の店主は、古くさい男で、男は家庭のことに干渉すべきではないと主ちょうするんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I went to the Tofugu dining hall a while ago, there was free live music from some singer I didn't know.
Context 2-JP: <jp>さっきトーフグ食堂に行ったんだけど、無名の歌手が無料のワンマンライブをしてたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you want to eat lunch in the cafeteria? If so, I don’t have a second period class, so I could find some seats for us.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お昼ごはん、食堂で食べない？もしよければ、私二限目のクラスが無いから、席取っておけるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>ridicule</kanji> everyone but your<kanji>self</kanji> because you have so much <vocabulary>pride</vocabulary>. When you talk about yourself you only <vocabulary>boast</vocabulary> because there's nothing to ridicule. That's how great you think you are.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s impossible for me to proudly boast about my own affair.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分の不倫を得意気に自慢するとか、ありえないんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>instruction</kanji> is my <kanji>commandment</kanji>. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary>. This is my <vocabulary>admonition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My coworker always dozes off during study sessions and our boss finally admonished him for it today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつも勉強会で居眠りする同僚がいてさ、ついに上司が今日それについて訓戒を与えてたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Four</kanji> <kanji>corner</kanji>s are <vocabulary>four corners</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both by now, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Can you teach me the best process to make the four corners of a picture dark?
Context 1-JP: <jp>写真の四隅を暗く加工するにはどうすればいいのか教えてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>illusion</kanji> that changes your <kanji>concept</kanji> of the world is a big <vocabulary>fantasy</vocabulary> (it's also an <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when it changes your concept of the world, it becomes a total fantasy!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: No matter how old Fugu gets, he still lives in a world of illusion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグはいくつになっても幻想の世界の住人なんだな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I sometimes cherish the sweet illusion that Koichi is my son.
Context 2-JP: <jp>時々、コウイチが自分の息子だというあまい幻想をいだいています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My older brother maintains the ridiculous fantasy that he is the king of the blowfish.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の兄は、自分が河豚の王だという馬鹿げた幻想を持ち続けている。</jp>

Meaning: To Become Exhausted,To Become Tired,To Get Tired
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>exhausted</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to become exhausted</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to become tired</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get tired</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this with "to be sleepy." No, this is a different kind of tired, like a physical or mental one, like you just worked out or studied a ton.
Reading Mnemonic: For example, if you tried to lift <reading>two ca</reading>rs (<jp>つか</jp>) you'd become exhausted for sure. So, think about that as you learn this word's reading.
Context 1-EN: The toilet was clogged and it flooded before we used the plunger, so I had to clean it up early in the morning and I’m really exhausted.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トイレが詰まって、すっぽんで詰まり抜きをする前に水が溢れちゃって、朝早くから掃除をしなくちゃいけなかったから、とっても疲れました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an <vocabulary>empty seat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>open seat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I went to see a movie on Christmas day in the U.S. and I was surprised to see that the theater was nearly empty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカでクリスマスに映画を見に行ったら、ほとんど空席でびっくりしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you tell me if there are any lessons with free seats left?
Context 2-JP: <jp>空席の出そうなじゅ業があれば教えてもらえませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Are there still many open seats left? If possible, I’d prefer to sit in the front.
Context 3-JP: <jp>まだ空席はたくさんありますか？できれば前の方の席がいいのですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Spinning</kanji> <kanji>exploit</kanji>s sheep, but you keep <vocabulary>spinning</vocabulary> anyway because you're cold and you need the sweater you're making.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Kensetsu bouseki is a spinning method particular to synthetic fibers not spun from cotton.
Context 1-JP: <jp> 牽切紡績とは、化学繊維特有の紡績方法で、綿からの紡績ではありません。</jp>

Meaning: Europe And America,America And Europe,Usa And Europe,Europe And Usa,The West
Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>Europe</kanji> and <kanji>America</kanji>. This word represents the relationship between <vocabulary>Europe and America</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>America and Europe</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m searching for a place in Europe and America that grows pink roses.
Context 1-JP: <jp>欧米でピンクの薔薇を栽培している所がないか探しているんですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you take a <kanji>dose</kanji> of something, you are taking a <vocabulary>dose</vocabulary> of <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>. Take your cough syrup, child!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.
Context 1-EN: I heard it through the grapevine that you guys are going to do some hush-hush antidote experiments.
Context 1-JP: <jp>解毒剤の極秘開発を行う予定だとちょいと小耳に挟みましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>skin</kanji> <kanji>touch</kanji> is  the feeling of touching with your skin. That is <vocabulary>the touch of</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>feel of</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>texture</vocabulary> of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>肌</jp> plus <jp>触る</jp>'s reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: This towel is very soft and pleasant to the touch.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このタオルはとても柔らかくて心地よい肌触りです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a <vocabulary>novel</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I seriously love this novel. This is legit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この小説マジで大好きだわ。これはホンモノだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Dad is glowing with pride because his novel is selling well, huh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>お父さん、小説が売れて鼻高々だね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: “Here, wipe your tears and nose,” Koichi said, ripping off a page of the novel that he'd been reading and handing it to Kristen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ほら、これでなみだと鼻をふきなよ」と言いながら、コウイチは読んでいた小説のページを一枚やぶって、クリステンにわたした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Government</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> (aka money) is what makes up <vocabulary>government funds</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: No matter what happens, never misuse government money!
Context 1-JP: <jp>間違っても官金に手を出すんじゃないぞ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you think dropping off a child at a daycare using a public car is a misuse of government money in any way?
Context 2-JP: <jp>保育園まで公用車に子どもを乗せて行くことは、ある意味で官金の私消に当たると思いますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: My best friend was arrested on Friday for the embezzlement of over $10,000 of government funds, but I doubt she actually did it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>金曜日に親友が一万ドルの公的資金を濫用したとして官金私消罪で逮捕されたのだが、私には彼女がそんなことをしたとは思えない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: It’s the terrible twos now, you know.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今は「魔の二歳児」ですからねー。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When <kanji>medicine</kanji> is sent to your <kanji>direction</kanji> it's going to you. That's your <vocabulary> prescription</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I lost the prescription that the doctor had given me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>医者にもらった薬方を失くしてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The handwriting is so messy that I don't understand what's written on the prescription at all.
Context 2-JP: <jp>字がきたなすぎて、薬方に何が書いてあるのかさっぱり分かりません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Some of the old prescriptions were considered to be dangerous and have been removed from use in modern medicine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>古い薬方の中には、危険であるということで現代医療からは除かれているものもある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>壊す</jp> is "to break something." <jp>壊れる</jp> is when something just gets broken or is broken, and you're not doing the breaking. This is <vocabulary>to be broken</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>壊す</jp>, so try not to break any of your memories and remember this.
Context 1-EN: I overslept, missed my breakfast, and then my car broke down. It’s really not my day today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>寝過ごして朝ごはんを食べ損ねた上に、車が壊れたんだ。本当に今日はついてないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>request</kanji> then you <kanji>request</kanji> again. This is starting to turn into more of a <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary> if you ask me. Also can refer to a <vocabulary>claim</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm told that I can claim a reimbursement later for the parcel shipping cost.
Context 1-JP: <jp>荷物を送った送料は後で請求可能だと言われています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I desperately needed money, so I borrowed some as an illegal loan. Then I was charged illegal amount of money, so I am now in more trouble.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お金に困ってやみ金から借りたら、法外な金額が請求されて余計困りました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to request a cancellation of the bill because I think we were billed for the wrong amount.
Context 3-JP: <jp>請求書の金額が間違っているように思うので私はその請求の取り消しを要請します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>closed</kanji> <kanji>chain</kanji> lets everyone know that a building or store is <vocabulary>closing</vocabulary> for good. It's got to <vocabulary>lockout</vocabulary> everyone so they won't try to get in anymore.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The pool is closed this month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このプールは今月で閉鎖されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Destitute</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji>s lead to <vocabulary>distress</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I appealed to the government about the wretched conditions, but I didn’t receive a response.
Context 1-JP: <jp>役所に窮状を訴えたのですが、聞き入れてもらえませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the <vocabulary>summary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>outline</vocabulary> of something bigger.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you explain the outline of the incident first?
Context 1-JP: <jp>まずは事件の大略を説明してくれないか？</jp>

Meaning: To Be Diluted,To Be Diminished,To Become Weak
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>dilute</kanji>, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the <jp>まる</jp> ending. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be diluted</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be diminished</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to become weak</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

The reading comes from <jp>薄い</jp>, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don't want your drink <vocabulary>to be diluted</vocabulary>, so <reading>you sue</reading> (<jp>うす</jp>) anyone who dares pour you a weak drink.
Context 1-EN: Please don't take this with alcohol as its effectiveness will be diminished.
Context 1-JP: <jp>効果が薄まるので、お酒と一緒には飲まないで下さい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The pink paint, diluted with water, was left on the palette.
Context 2-JP: <jp>水で薄まったピンクの絵の具がパレットに残っていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: With just one remark, the inherent value of the letter was diminished.
Context 3-JP: <jp>たった一つの発言でせっかくの手紙のありがたみが薄まった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>confused</kanji> urges <kanji>overthrow</kanji> normal thoughts and feelings it's a <vocabulary>perversion</vocabulary>. Some are harmless, but some are not.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Perverse thoughts first negate reality.
Context 1-JP: <jp>倒錯思考はまず現実否定から始まる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how we use <kanji>feeling</kanji>s to <kanji>memorize</kanji> things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your <vocabulary>senses</vocabulary>, because feelings are memorized best when you use <vocabulary>the senses</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The sensation in my tongue is gone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>したの感覚がまひしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like Tofugu's sense of humor.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグのユーモアの感覚が好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you really want to quit smoking, you should see what it feels like to be someone with diseased lungs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし本当に煙草を止めたいなら、肺を病む人特有の感覚を知ってみることだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>interior</kanji> <kanji>formal name ender</kanji> (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is <vocabulary>your wife</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I’m sorry for the interruption, but it seems that your wife’s just gotten stuck in an elevator.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お話中恐れ入りますが、奥様がエレベーターに閉じ込められてしまったようなんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Whoever holds the <kanji>pipe</kanji> has <kanji>control</kanji> of the situation so you give them <vocabulary>jurisdiction</vocabulary> to do whatever they want. It's better than getting hit by a pipe.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The southern police have jurisdiction here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここは、南署の管轄です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>confused</kanji> <kanji>riot</kanji> causes even more <vocabulary>confusion</vocabulary>. Soon there will be so many <vocabulary>distraction</vocabulary>s happening, what with cars tipping over and fires starting, that no one will know which way is up!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Their consciousness seemed to be confused by the medicine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>薬で意識が錯乱しているようでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>river bottom</vocabulary>, also known as the <vocabulary>riverbed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for <jp>底</jp>!
Context 1-EN: The river is deep around there, so be careful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの辺りは川底が深いので気を付けてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There's a lot of sand on the bed in this river.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この川は、川底にかなりのすながたまってしまっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "What did you do during Golden Week, Salmon?" "I lost my wedding ring in a river, so I was looking for it. It took me three days, but I finally found it buried in the riverbed."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「サーモンはゴールデンウィーク期間中何してたの？」「結婚指輪を川で無くしちゃって、ずっと探してたの。三日もかかったけど、ようやく川底に沈んでいる指輪を見つけたわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plow</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to plow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to till</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need <vocabulary>to till</vocabulary> your land because you want to have a <reading>tige</reading>r <reading>ya</reading>rd (<jp>たがや</jp>). That's either when you have a yard full of live tigers, or you plant bushes and shape them into tigers. I hope it's the second kind of tiger yard. Either way, you have to plow the land to get it ready.
Context 1-EN: I’ll plow the field with this machine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この機械で畑を耕すんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>roof</kanji>s are <kanji>spread</kanji> out around your property. Put these roofs and areas all together and you have your <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>estate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: His wife does nothing but aimlessly wander around the estate everyday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>男の妻は毎日お屋敷で何もせずただブラブラしている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: How dare you say you’ve dealt with walking down the thorny path in life just to keep up with their level of hardship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この程度の苦難で、茨の道を歩んでいるような人生だとか、よく言えるよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>shamisen song</kanji> is a <vocabulary>shamisen song</vocabulary>, yes. But did you know it's also... a <vocabulary>song</vocabulary>?! Oh, you did? Well okay then.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I wrote this song with my older brother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この唄は、私と兄が一緒に作りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>servant</kanji> is bigger than the rest of the servants. One type of servant is one who serves the people (as is the case with this one). A big servant is someone high up in the realm of serving the people. So, let's call this big servant a <vocabulary>minister</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cabinet member</vocabulary>. Big cheese.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She was fired because she forgot to hand out the documents to the cabinet members before the meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は大臣たちに会議の前に資料を配るのを忘れてしまったために、首になっちゃったんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Maybe you didn't know this, but if you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the cuss words first. <jp>くそ</jp> is sh*t / garbage, though it's not really a "bad" word in Japanese like it is in English. So, what is your <kanji>nose</kanji> sh*t? It's your <vocabulary>snot</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>boogers</vocabulary>. Ewwww, stop eating them!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. <reading><jp>はなくそ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I saw a man with an aquiline nose pick his boogers and put them in the nostrils of a sleeping man with a short nose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かぎ鼻の男が、ほじくり出した鼻くそを、ねむっている低い鼻の男の鼻の穴に入れるのを見ました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm collecting the snot I pick out with my finger on a tissue.
Context 2-JP: <jp>指でほじくり出した鼻くそをティッシュの上に集めています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu accused me of being selfish. Talk about an eye crust laughing at a booger.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグが僕のことを自分勝手だって責めるんだ。目くそ鼻くそを笑うだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You'll be <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>destitute</kanji> if you're living in <vocabulary>poverty</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My parents were living in poverty but I didn’t have the money to help them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>両親は生活に困窮していましたが、私にも彼らを助ける余裕はありませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>title</kanji>, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to give praise</vocabulary> to you.
Reading Mnemonic: After they go <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary> you, you're all like "I don't need praise! <reading>Ta ta</reading> (<jp>たた</jp>)! I'm outa here."
Context 1-EN: I was doing my Wanikani reviews every day and the teacher praised me for my diligence.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニのレビューを毎日していたら、先生から勤勉だと褒め称えられた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Just because you have to <kanji>wait</kanji> for special <kanji>treatment</kanji> doesn't mean it's not still good <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary>. And just because everyone didn't cheer when you arrived, doesn't mean you're getting a cold <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary>, you know? Maybe they're planning a surprise party for you or something... yeah.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Thanks to this card I can taste VIP treatment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このカードのお陰で、VIP待遇を味わうことができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: My father has a different colored bow tie every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は、毎日色の違う蝶ネクタイをしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Torture</kanji> may be a <kanji>problem</kanji> but that doesn't stop people from using <vocabulary>torture</vocabulary> to get their way.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My older sister was brutally tortured by the mafia.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の姉は、マフィアから残虐な拷問を受けたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>日</jp> refers to <kanji>Japan</kanji> (It's the <jp>日</jp> of <jp>日本</jp>). So, you have Japan and <kanji>Europe</kanji>, which is <vocabulary>Japan and Europe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Europe and Japan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The meeting concerning trade between Europe and Japan was sidetracked due to the moderator’s absence.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日欧貿易に関する会議は、司会者の不在によって横道に逸れてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in what you <kanji>calculate</kanji> is a <vocabulary>miscalculation</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>pierce</kanji> some fabric with a needle it needs to <kanji>pass through</kanji> to the other side to actually <vocabulary>pierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>penetrate</vocabulary> it. Make sure it goes all the way through if you want to sew properly.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My wire bra protected me from the bullet penetrating.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ブラジャーのワイヤーが弾丸の貫通を防いでくれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>club</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>clubroom</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As for that manga, we have the whole series in the clubroom.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのまんがなら、部室に全かんそろってるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: For some reason, there is a cat with a fish in its mouth in the clubroom.
Context 2-JP: <jp>何ぜか部室に魚を口にくわえたネコがいるんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I forgot something in the clubroom.
Context 3-JP: <jp>部室に忘れ物をしちゃった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When <kanji>writing</kanji> just happens to "<kanji>fall</kanji>" on the wall (whoops, wasn't me who did that, how strannnnge) it's writing that's not supposed to be where it is. This kind of writing is <vocabulary>graffiti</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. <jp>書</jp>, however, is kun'yomi in this case and also has rendaku. So just remember that it's read as <jp>が</jp> for this vocab and you'll be fine.
Context 1-EN: Koichi's sketches have increased in value by as much as a million dollars at auctions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの落書きは今やオークションで百万ドルで落札されるまでになった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There used to be lot of graffiti along the underground passages at Shinjuku Station a long time ago, but we rarely see them now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新宿駅の地下道には、昔、たくさんの落書きがしてありましたが、今はほとんど見当たりません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Spray-painting graffiti is already a bit old-fashioned. The newer artists create works of art by scrubbing the dirt off the wall.
Context 3-JP: <jp>スプレーでの落書きアートは既に少し時代遅れです。新しい芸術家達は、壁の汚れをゴシゴシ擦って洗い落としながらアートを創りだします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>rot</kanji> <kanji>dose</kanji> is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is an <vocabulary>antiseptic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>preservative</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Where should I throw away old antiseptics?
Context 1-JP: <jp>古い防腐剤はどこに捨てればいいですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading! Just don't forget the <jp>か</jp> at the end.
Context 1-EN: The chimes echoed from far away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その鐘の音は、遥か彼方まで響き渡った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Destitute</kanji> <kanji>land</kanji>s will be faced with a <vocabulary>dilemma</vocabulary>. Do they leave? Or do they try to make the best of it?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It was driven into a corner and finally showed it’s tail.
Context 1-JP: <jp>窮地に追い込まれ、ようやく尻尾を見せました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

When you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You <reading>tore</reading> (<jp>とり</jp>) off its wing and started eating it (pretend it's cooked first, if that makes you less nauseous).
Context 1-EN: There are a lot of beautiful birds in this park.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この公えんには、きれいな鳥がたくさんいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I opened my curtain this morning, everything was covered with bird poop.
Context 2-JP: <jp>けさカーテンをあけたら、何もかもが鳥のふんにおおわれていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wish I was a bird because then I wouldn’t get made fun of for walking like one.
Context 3-JP: <jp>自分が鳥だったらいいのになと思うよ。だって、そうすればもう鳥みたいに歩いているとからかわれないだろうからね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>boat</kanji> <kanji>ship</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>ship</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Which country is this ship registered under?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その船舶は、どこの国に登録されているものですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>biased</kanji> way of <kanji>see</kanji>ing, people will think you hold <vocabulary>prejudice</vocabulary> against them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That is called prejudice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それが偏見というものです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is no world where prejudice doesn't exist.
Context 2-JP: <jp>偏見が全くない世界なんてものは存在しない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She seems to be prejudiced against Asian people.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女はアジア人に偏見があるようだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>welcome</kanji>, so it means a <vocabulary>welcome</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary>, but it's usually used for someone who's coming and <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary> you!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: I’ll send someone to meet you at the station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>駅まで迎えをよこすよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Fit Inside,To Settle Down,To Be Finished
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

If you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something, you'll want it <vocabulary>to fit inside</vocabulary> your bag. Otherwise how can you take it home? Depending on the context, this verb can also mean <vocabulary>to settle down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be finished</vocabulary>. 

Like most verbs with <jp>まる</jp> as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something fit inside, or settle down.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don't fit inside your bed anymore. I guess you've grown? Better get out the trusty <reading>o</reading>ld <reading>saw</reading>s (<jp>おさ</jp>) and chop off your footboard.
Context 1-EN: Did the one hundred million yen fit inside the suitcase?
Context 1-JP: <jp>一億円、そのスーツケースに収まった？</jp>
Context 2-EN: After eating the ice cream, my emotions started to settle down.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アイスを食べたら、感情が収まってきたんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We wanted to eat all five large pizzas, but they couldn't be finished within the all-you-can-eat time limit.
Context 3-JP: <jp>皆で大きいピザを五枚食べきりたかったが、食べ放題の時間内に収まらなかった。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Extended,To Be Delayed,To Be Prolonged
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be extended</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be delayed</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be prolonged</vocabulary>. If you know the word <jp>ビル</jp>, you can think about how building work is always prolonged or delayed, to help you remember that this is intransitive. We never know why it's delayed, it just happens all by itself!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <jp>延ばす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Because of construction work, my usual running route has been extended.
Context 1-JP: <jp>工事のせいでいつものランニングのコースが延びた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The Tokyo Olympics were delayed to the following year, but they might get canceled.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京オリンピックは翌年に延びたがキャンセルになるかもしれない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I hate it when meetings are prolonged because of my boss.
Context 3-JP: <jp>上司のせいで会議が延びるのが嫌いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after a number, it’s for physical <vocabulary>bill</vocabulary>s of money.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a suffix that takes the on’yomi reading, which you’ve learned already!
Context 1-EN: Could you give me change for a 10,000 yen bill?
Context 1-JP: <jp>一万円札を小ぜににくずしてもらえませんか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you break this 2,000 yen bill to two 1,000 yen bills, please?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この二千円札、千円札二枚と両がえしてくれない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Apparently, there are many hundred-dollar bills hidden all over the Tofugu office.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグのオフィスのあちこちに、百ドル札が隠されているらしいぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have to <kanji>pierce</kanji> this piece of information into your brain until it finally <kanji>penetrate</kanji>s, which takes a lot of <vocabulary>persistence</vocabulary>. Do that and it will be quite the <vocabulary>accomplishment</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It was hard, but we were able to carry through with the plan we had decided on together.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大変だったけど、みんなで決めた計画を貫徹することができた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I regret that I couldn't realize the dream that I had ten years ago.
Context 2-JP: <jp>十年前の夢を貫徹できなかったことを残念に思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll do my best to prepare to accomplish my original goals.
Context 3-JP: <jp>初志貫徹の心構えで頑張ります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If the <kanji>extent</kanji> you go to do something is properly (<jp>よく</jp>) done, then you did it <vocabulary>properly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Nice!
Context 1-EN: Mix the ground meat well.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Narrow</kanji> <kanji>biased</kanji> people are considered to be <vocabulary>narrow minded</vocabulary> and they're usually disliked for their <vocabulary>intolerance</vocabulary> of other cultures and anything unfamiliar to them.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>狭</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Context 1-EN: The stereotype is that human beings are narrow-minded.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Stand</kanji> behind someone and <kanji>embrace</kanji> them. That's how you show them you're <vocabulary>backing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>supporting</vocabulary> them. Do this to your local politicians.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m sure that they are just trying to support the candidate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうせ出馬者を擁立しようとしているだけだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something <kanji>erupt</kanji>s and <kanji>shoots</kanji> a bunch of water or lava out it comes out in a huge <vocabulary>jet</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>spray</vocabulary>s everything.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: Those <kanji>love</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s you're having mean you're in <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>!

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> of the <kanji>flower</kanji> is <vocabulary>flower arrangement</vocabulary>.

Meaning: To Move Something Close To,To Pull Something Over,To Contribute Something
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. The kanji itself means <kanji>approach</kanji>, and the verb version is about making or letting something approach. That's why it means <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pull something over</vocabulary>, and also <vocabulary>to contribute something</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary> you, but it's out of reach. The solution, of course, is to take out your trusty <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<jp>よ</jp>) and lasso that thing and pull it closer!
Context 1-EN: I moved the toys close to the wall.
Context 1-JP: <jp>オモチャをカベに寄せた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I pulled the car over and parked.
Context 3-EN: All kinds of comments were posted on this podcast episode.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このポッドキャストには色んなコメントが寄せられた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of <jp>怒る</jp>. So instead of being "to be angry," it's just the idea and concept of <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>wrath</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I have a lot of <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> because <reading>I carry</reading> (<jp>いかり</jp>) all of my own things (books, luggage, drinks) and no one will ever carry them for me. Plus, the more things I carry, the more anger I carry inside. Ahh!
Context 1-EN: My anger will not go on for more than three minutes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の怒りは三分以上続かない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>erupts</kanji> from <vocabulary>water fountains</vocabulary>. Sometimes they're big eruptions and sometimes they're small, but they're always fun to watch and enjoy in the hot summer.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Let’s meet at the water fountain over there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこの噴水で待ち合わせをしましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Try singing a <kanji>nose</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji>. How does it sound? Like <vocabulary>humming</vocabulary> perhaps?
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a <jp>鼻</jp> is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know <jp>鼻</jp>'s reading from the kanji (<jp>はな</jp>) and you know <jp>歌</jp>'s reading from the vocabulary word <jp>歌</jp> (<jp>うた</jp>). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, <jp>はなうた</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Koichi was humming while making his nose swell.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、鼻をふくらませながら、鼻歌を歌っていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet was happily riding his bicycle while humming.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは鼻歌まじりで楽しそうに自転車に乗っていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: LMAO! You are just terrible at humming.
Context 3-JP: <jp>爆笑！お前鼻歌下手すぎだっつーの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji> is an <vocabulary>eyeball</vocabulary>. Eww.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>私は自分の左の眼球をあちこち捜したが、なかなか見つけられなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>gather</kanji> things and <kanji>use</kanji> them. The things I've gathered, are the things I <vocabulary>use</vocabulary>.
