Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>exhibit</kanji> of things in a <kanji>row</kanji> only happens at an <vocabulary>exhibition</vocabulary>. Everything will be neatly lined up on <vocabulary>display</vocabulary> for you there.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What did you think of the bakery’s exposed exhibition?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたは、パン屋のむき出しの陳列についてどう思いますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Perfume</kanji> <kanji>fragrance</kanji> is what you'll smell if you spray a bottle of <vocabulary>perfume</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I enjoy the fragrance of the aroma oil rising out of the bath.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お風呂あがりには、アロマオイルの芳香を楽しみます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You remember how <jp>洗う</jp> is "to wash"? Well, when you <kanji>wash</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji>s you're doing <vocabulary>hand washing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings 手 and 洗う put together.
Context 1-EN: Koichi is angry with his workers because they don't wash their hands and gargle, regardless of how many times he's told them to do so.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは何度言っても社員達が手洗い、うがいをしないので機嫌が悪い。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>お手洗いをお借りしてもいいですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: You can’t use a washing machine for Tofugu T-shirts. You have to wash them by hand.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグTシャツに洗濯機は使えません。手洗いをしなくてはいけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>drum</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>drum</vocabulary>. This word can be used for any type of drum, but a common one in Japan is the <vocabulary>taiko</vocabulary>. There are lots of different types of taiko, and most of them are big and fat, and make a lovely deep sound. They're super cool to watch and play!

If talking about taiko drums specifically, you can also say <jp>和太鼓</jp> to be clear that you're not talking about any old drums.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My children like to play with drums.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの子供は太鼓で遊ぶのが好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My stomach is so full that it looks like a drum.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お腹がパンパンで太鼓みたいになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm really into a game called "Taiko Master."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「太鼓の達人」っていうゲームにハマってるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine a <vocabulary>fish</vocabulary>. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a <reading>soccer nu</reading>n (<jp>さかな</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I like fish, but I don’t like it raw.
Context 1-JP: <jp>魚はすきですが、生魚はにが手です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I always eat granola and fish for a well-balanced breakfast.
Context 2-JP: <jp>バランスのいいちょう食をとるために、いつもグラノーラと魚を食べます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll never buy fish from the back of a pickup truck in Mexico again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もう絶対にメキシコの軽トラの積み荷から魚を買うもんか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Who do you <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> as an <kanji>offering</kanji> to the gods? A poor <vocabulary>victim</vocabulary> will be your <vocabulary>sacrifice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you want to succeed so badly that you’re willing to sacrifice someone?
Context 1-JP: <jp>だれかを犠牲にしてまで成功したいかい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a <kanji>seat</kanji> is <kanji>lack</kanji>ing the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an <vocabulary>absence</vocabulary>. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <jp>けつ</jp> is shortened to <jp>けっ</jp> as <jp>つ</jp>s often are when in a situation like this.
Context 1-EN: The pharmacy department is absent today, eh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は薬学はかせは欠席なんですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I fired him because he no call no show'd three times in row.
Context 2-JP: <jp>無だん欠席が三回つづいたので、首にしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m terribly sorry, but an urgent business trip has come up, so I’ll be absent from the reunion party tonight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大変申し訳ないのですが、急な出張が入ってしまったので、今夜の同窓会は欠席させて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If it's in your <kanji>nature</kanji> to <kanji>ridicule</kanji> people, it will become a <vocabulary>chronic</vocabulary> problem. You can't change something that's so embedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I suffer from chronic gastroenteritis.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は慢性胃腸炎を患っているんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Soak,To Seep,To Dip In,To Pickle
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pickle</kanji> or <kanji>soak</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to pickle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to soak</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!
Context 1-EN: Please eat it dipped in soy sauce like this.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こうやって醤油に漬けて食べてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Sometimes even though you're very much awake and <kanji>alive</kanji> you need to <kanji>sleep</kanji> for a little bit, so you take a <vocabulary>nap</vocabulary>. But you're not dead! You're totally alive, so let's hope no one thinks you're doing anything but <vocabulary>dozing off</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It seems like they dozed off while driving.
Context 1-JP: <jp>運転中に居眠りしてたみたいなんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Your <kanji>loss</kanji> comes from <kanji>damage</kanji> done to you. This is <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary>.

This word is usually used as a noun. It can occasionally be turned into verb by adding <jp>する</jp>, but this is very rare!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The truck crash damaged the cargo, but it was only minor damage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トラックの衝突で積荷がダメージを受けたが、小さな損害で済んだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>pain</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, so it means to inflict pain. In other words, it's <vocabulary>to injure something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the word <jp>痛い</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Playing games too much will hurt your eyes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ゲームのやりすぎは目を痛める。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I ran a full marathon in slippers and injured my ankles.
Context 2-JP: <jp>スリッパでフルマラソンをしたら足首を痛めた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That incident is still breaking mom's heart.
Context 3-JP: <jp>母は今でもそのことで心を痛めている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Animals <kanji>exit</kanji> the mountains into your land and never seem to <kanji>die</kanji>! They end up <vocabulary>appearing frequently</vocabulary> in your garden, eating all your yummy carrots and watermelons, and then make their exit back into the hills. They're <vocabulary>infesting</vocabulary> your home now and you don't know what to do!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Bears appear frequently in large quantities all over Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本各地でクマが大量出没している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something acting like that person had <kanji>die</kanji>d, it's called <vocabulary>confiscation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>forfeiture</vocabulary>. Maybe if they were alive, you think, they wouldn't have let me take it. Well they are still alive so it's theirs and you can't keep it forever.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I forfeited my cell phone to the teacher.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生に携帯電話を没収されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're only <kanji>blind</kanji> to <kanji>color</kanji> then you have <vocabulary>color blindness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Can color-blindness be cured?
Context 1-JP: <jp>色盲って治るんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fear</kanji>? When you feel fear, you think something is <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary> is it? It's <reading>Oh so</reading> (<jp>おそ</jp>) scary!
Context 1-EN: You may feel scared, but you can’t defy the laws of nature. It’s no use now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>恐ろしいと思うかもしれないが、自然の法則には逆らえないんだよ。仕方がないさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>daring</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji> you'll <vocabulary>boldly</vocabulary> go where no one else has gone before!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That man plans to boldly oppose the difficult situation with nothing but his own determination.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの男は、まるで自分の意志で敢然と難局に立ち向かっているつもりなのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If your <kanji>back</kanji> is <kanji>wide</kanji>, you need a nice <vocabulary>business suit</vocabulary> to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it <jp>び</jp> not <jp>ひ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I lost a button from my suit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>背広のボタンをなくした。</jp>

Meaning: To Advance Something,To Move Something Forward
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>advance</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to advance something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to move something forward</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, so you act upon something else. You advance something. You move something forward. Like a school project, or your plans for taking over the world.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help:

You are moving your lawsuit forward against Sue. But now she says that YOU'RE the problem. "<reading>Sue, sue me</reading>," (<jp>すすめ</jp>) you say as you continue to advance the lawsuit. Make sure to say "me" like "mehh," in a really snobbish way.
Context 1-EN: Thank you for giving us advice on advancing our research.
Context 1-JP: <jp>研究を進めるための助言をして下さって、ありがとうございます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: With this snow, we can't move the construction forward anymore.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この雪じゃ、これ以上工事を進められないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please move your work forward at the current pace.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このペースで作業を進めてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something <kanji>erupt</kanji>s out an <kanji>exit</kanji> it usually had to fight pretty hard to get to that exit. That's why it ends up <vocabulary>spewing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gushing</vocabulary> all over the place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is it true that gas spews out of black holes?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ブラックホールからガスが噴出しているって本当ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hunting</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hunting dog</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>犬</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who has the best <vocabulary>hunting dog</vocabulary> in the world? <reading>Ken</reading> (<jp>けん</jp>) from Street Fighter! His dog is also named Ken, because that's how Ken and Ken do things.
Context 1-EN: It’s said that hunting dogs typically bark a lot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一般的に猟犬はよく吠えると言われています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how the word <jp>情け</jp> means pity, so adding <jp>ない</jp> to that turns it into an adjective meaning <vocabulary>pitiable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>miserable</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: It's sad, but I have a very trusting nature, so I often get duped.
Context 1-JP: <jp>情けないですが、すぐに人を信じる性格なので、よくだまされるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's shameful to get a job using connections. You should compete using your merits alone.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ツテでしゅうしょくするなんて、情けない。実力で勝負しろよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There really are a lot of deplorable Japanese politicians.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の政治家には、本当に情けない奴が多い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Hunting</kanji> in <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is only done through illegal <vocabulary>poaching</vocabulary>. If you weren't poaching protected animals you wouldn't have to do it secretly.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What do you think can be done to prevent the poaching of elephants?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうすれば象の密猟を防止できると思いますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When a <kanji>light</kanji> shines on how much you've <kanji>prosper</kanji>ed, it's a great <vocabulary>honor</vocabulary>. You don't feel like you did anything so special, but it's really a privilege for the light to come down on you like this.

Don't confuse this with <jp>栄光</jp>! With that one, you made things prosper and the light came after, making you look glorious. With this, light is shining on you, and you receive honor from it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It's truly an honor for us to be able to interview you, Mr. Abe.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あべさんにインタビューさせていただけることをとても光栄に思っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should know that it's indeed a privilege for you to chat with King Koichi in person.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチ王と直せつお話ができることは、大変光栄なことなんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m deeply honored to have this opportunity to work at the Tofugu headquarters. I’ll do my best to be of use to you all.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの本社で勤務する機会を頂いたことを、とても光栄に思います。皆さんのお役に立てるよう精一杯頑張りますので、どうぞよろしくお願いいたします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first <vocabulary>cause</vocabulary> is the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Since we married for money, not for love, we fought a lot and ended up getting divorced.
Context 1-JP: <jp>愛情からではなく金のためにけっこんしたのが原因で、けんかがたえず、結局りこんしてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Due to the wildfire of unknown origins, the town has been in such a chaotic situation.
Context 2-JP: <jp>原因不明の山火事で、町は大変なことになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t worry. Viet has already uncovered the cause of the bugs and is fixing it right now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>心配ないよ。ビエトがすでに不具合の原因を突き止めて、現在修復作業中だよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Accompanied By,To Preside Over,To Subdue
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>obey</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, so some of its meanings refer to when you make someone obey you, or in other words <vocabulary>to preside over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to subdue</vocabulary>. Depending on the context though, it often just means <vocabulary>to be accompanied by</vocabulary> someone. To help you remember this, imagine that everyone you're accompanied by obeys you!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 従う. Remember it?
Context 1-EN: The singer came here accompanied by her three bodyguards.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その歌手は三人のボディガードを従えてやってきた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: At the age of twenty, he was already a company president that presides over a hundred employees.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二十才の時には、すでに百人の社員を従える社長になっていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The oni subdued the villagers by force.
Context 3-JP: <jp>鬼は力で村人たちを従えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>suffer</kanji>, and the verb is all about when you make someone else suffer. That's why it's <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to harass</vocabulary>.

You need to differentiate this from <jp>苦しむ</jp>, which is about when YOU suffer. You can remember that <jp>苦しめる</jp> is about making someone else suffer with this mnemonic: Who made you suffer? She (<jp>し</jp>) made me (<jp>め</jp>) suffer! She's so mean!
Reading Mnemonic: By now, you've learned 苦しい and 苦しむ. The kanji in these words all use the same reading! Yay!
Context 1-EN: Don't hurt me anymore!
Context 1-JP: <jp>これ以上、私を苦しめないで！</jp>
Context 2-EN: The rice shortage is tormenting all citizens of Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>米不足が全日本の国民を苦しめている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Without realizing it, I was harassing the first-graders every day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>知らないうちに、毎日一年生を苦しめていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <kanji>lies</kanji> puke (<jp>吐く</jp>) out of your mouth, you're a <vocabulary>liar</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings, one of which you haven't seen yet. You'll see this word without the <jp>吐</jp> kanji too, but for now let's learn its kanji reading! 

You can't just tell one <vocabulary>lie</vocabulary>, it always turns into <reading>two</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>). Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.
Context 1-EN: Usopp is a liar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ウソップは嘘吐きだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Apparently, Fuguko has a boyfriend who is a complete liar and they fight quite often.
Context 2-JP: <jp>フグ子ちゃん、大嘘つきの彼氏がいて、よくケンカするんだって。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In that era, all liars were to be burned.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その時代、嘘吐きは全員燃やされていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: We need about a hundred skewers for the BBQ that's coming up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今度のBBQには100本くらい串が必要です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you skewer the meat and potatoes?
Context 2-JP: <jp>肉とジャガイモに串を刺してくれませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yakitori is chicken spitted on skewers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>焼き鳥とは、串に刺さった鶏肉のことです。</jp>

Meaning: To Spread Something,To Unfold Something,To Open Something Up
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>wide</kanji>, and the verb version is what happens when you try to make something wider. How do you make something wider? That's right, you have <vocabulary>to spread something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to unfold something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to open something up</vocabulary>. All of those actions will make a thing wider!

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You spread something. Like a newspaper, or a cloth on a table.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder mnemonic to help you:

You are going <vocabulary>to spread something</vocabulary>. What are you going to spread? How about your arms, so that you can fly into the sky like the super <reading>hero</reading> (<jp>ひろ</jp>) that you are! Most heroes can fly when they spread their arms wide!
Context 1-EN: It was water that spread the virus in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本にそのウィルスを広げたのは水だった。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>大人三人でブランケットを広げた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As soon as I went inside, I opened the book.
Context 3-JP: <jp>中に入ってすぐ本を広げた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. When we talk about this kind of <vocabulary>candy</vocabulary>, it's usually <vocabulary>hard candy</vocabulary> though. 🍬
Reading Mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, and it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: Please give me a candy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>飴を一つ下さい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Curry flavored candy has been trending in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本では、カレー味の飴が流行っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Are you the type of person who sucks on candy or just swallows them?

Meaning: To Disconnect Something,To Miss Something,To Exclude Something,To Remove Something
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji <jp>外</jp> means <kanji>outside</kanji>, and the meaning of this verb is somewhat related. It means <vocabulary>to disconnect something</vocabulary>. Think of it like this, if you disconnect a plug from a socket, you are taking the plug "outside" of the socket, right? Depending on the context, this verb can also mean <vocabulary>to miss something</vocabulary> (like the target during archery practice), <vocabulary>to remove something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to exclude something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You disconnect something, like a plug, or remove something, like your dog's leash. It's worth mentioning that most verbs ending in <jp>す</jp> are transitive, so you'll start seeing this pattern as you learn more!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be a kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're going <vocabulary>to disconnect something</vocabulary>, it <reading>has</reading> (<jp>はず</jp>) to be the right thing! Don't go disconnecting the wrong plug, you'll cause no end of trouble!
Context 1-EN: Once you disconnect the plug, please use the exit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コンセントを外したら、出口から出てください。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>またターゲットを外してしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We excluded Kyoko from the team.
Context 3-JP: <jp>キョーコをチームから外した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're involved in a <kanji>daring</kanji> <kanji>struggle</kanji> you need to be strong and <vocabulary>fight bravely</vocabulary>. Even if you might get hurt, you should do your best!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>優勝候補を相手に、よく敢闘したと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Black</kanji> <kanji>smoke</kanji> is <vocabulary>black smoke</vocabulary>. It's also something you should avoid if you can.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> type is called <vocabulary>lean</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>slim</vocabulary>. These days this is usually used in the context of <vocabulary>slimming</vocabulary> salons and massages you can get that may or may not work.

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wet</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get wet</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>envy</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to envy</vocabulary> someone.

Meaning: To Change Something,To Revise Something,To Correct Something,To Check Something
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>renew</kanji>, and this verb's meaning isn't far off. It's transitive, meaning it is done to something. What do you do if you renew something, usually to make it better? You're going <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to revise something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to correct something</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>to check something</vocabulary>, like train tickets, or the change you've been given.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

We all want <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>. Probably <reading>a lotta</reading> (<jp>あらた</jp>) things! Think about all the things you want to change. Your name? Your habits? Your plans? The rules? The government? I bet you can think of a lotta things you want to change.
Context 1-EN: We decided to change the date.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日を改めることにしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should correct that way of thinking.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その考え方は改めた方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Just as we discussed, we revised a part of the plan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>話し合った通りに計画を一部改めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>bury</kanji> things into people who look like they've <kanji>die</kanji>d. It's called <vocabulary>implantation</vocabulary>. They're not really dead though. This is surgery and they'll wake up and go about their lives with whatever that thing was that you put in them.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>埋</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Wait that's not a person you're <vocabulary>embedding</vocabulary> things into. It's a bunch of <reading>mi</reading>ce (<jp>まい</jp>). I guess that's okay. Just don't go putting the mice into people. That's... don't cross that line.
Context 1-EN: I had double eyelids surgically implanted with plastic surgery.
Context 1-JP: <jp>整形手術で二重の埋没手術をしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>sushi counter</kanji> is counting <vocabulary>one piece of sushi</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>consistency</vocabulary>, which makes sense if you think about piece of sushi—each one should be as consistent as the last!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Flat</kanji>ten out your <kanji>equilibrium</kanji> and you'll have perfect <vocabulary>balance</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: If there is a <kanji>cave in</kanji> because it was <kanji>lack</kanji>ing something that means there was a <vocabulary>defect</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fault</vocabulary> in there somewhere.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The safety defect in this product was identified by consumers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>消費者からこの商品の安全性の欠陥が指摘されています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji <jp>受</jp> means <kanji>accept</kanji> and this verb is related. It means <vocabulary>to get accepted</vocabulary>, usually into something good like a university or a new job. It can also mean <vocabulary>to succeed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary>, often in the context of a test or an exam. 

This is an intransitive verb, meaning it happens on its own. The <jp>かる</jp> ending is a hint, because verbs with <jp>かる</jp> as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.

Watch out: whereas in English we'd say "to pass an exam", in Japanese it's <jp>試験に受かる</jp>, or "to pass in an exam". That's why it's intransitive in Japanese, even though we might make it transitive in the English translation!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Here's a little mnemonic to help ya remember:

You open up your acceptance letter and shout "OOOO!!!" (<jp>う</jp>). You passed!
Context 1-EN: Yay! I got accepted into a university in Seattle!
Context 1-JP: <jp>やった！シアトル市の大学に受かったよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you don't pass next time, you'll have fewer chances of becoming a doctor.
Context 2-JP: <jp>次回受からなければ、医者になれるチャンスは少なくなるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I made a resolution that I won't go out on weekends until I pass my exams.
Context 3-JP: <jp>試験に受かるまで週末は出かけないって決心したんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>lack</kanji>, and this verb simply means <vocabulary>to lack something</vocabulary>.

It's a transitive verb. That means that it takes a direct object. You lack something. Like a car, concentration, or a soul. This is different from <jp>欠ける</jp>, which happens all by itself.
Reading Mnemonic:
You learned this reading when you learned <jp>欠ける</jp>, but here's a mnemonic just in case:

You never know when you're going <vocabulary>to lack something</vocabulary>. Like a <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>). Did you plan for it to break? NO! But it happened and now you lack a car in a big way. Not <reading>cool</reading> (<jp>く</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: The reason you lack concentration are those construction noises.
Context 1-JP: <jp>工事の音が、集中力を欠く原因だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think your banana-only diet lacks balance.
Context 2-JP: <jp>バナナだけの食事はバランスを欠いていると思いますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The internet is an indispensable service in our lives.
Context 3-JP: <jp>インターネットは私たちの生活に欠くことのできないサービスだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a person <kanji>die</kanji>s in a <kanji>war</kanji> they're considered to have been <vocabulary>killed in action</vocabulary>. There are lots of memorials around the world for people who died this way.

Reading Mnemonic:

If you're going to travel through a huge <vocabulary>ravine</vocabulary> you have to stay hydrated. The best thing to bring is some taste, cold <reading>Coke</reading> (<jp>こく</jp>). Nothing quenches your thirst from sweating through a long, rough ravine like delicious Coke!
