Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A <reading>hoe</reading> (<jp>ほ</jp>), like a garden hoe, you sicko.
Context 1-EN: "You can buy anything you want. Money is no limit." "Wow! Do you have a fever? What’s up with you?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「欲しいものを買っていいよ。金額の制限は無しだよ。」「まあ！熱でもあるの？ 何かあったの？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>fall</kanji> during a <kanji>cave in</kanji> you'll <vocabulary>fall</vocabulary> along with everything around you. And that <vocabulary>sinking</vocabulary> feeling in your stomach is because... I mean, well you ARE sinking into the ground.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do you think that Toyota fell from being the best in the world?
Context 1-JP: <jp>トヨタが世界一から陥落したのは何故だと思いますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>laziness</kanji> is <kanji>loose</kanji> you can't pull yourself together and you end up moving really <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary>. Your arms and legs get loose and your movements become <vocabulary>sluggish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>緩</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've become so <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> that you can only eat things out of the <reading>can</reading> (<jp>かん</jp>). You don't have the energy to cook and your arms are all loose so it doesn't even matter if you weren't moving so slowly. So just lay there, eating slowly from a can.
Context 1-EN: That waitress’ movements were really slow so she was fired.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのウエイトレスは動きが緩慢なので首にしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>treatment</kanji> of your <kanji>boundary</kanji> of your neighborhood is something you should be concerned about, because it's your <vocabulary>environment</vocabulary> and if you don't take care of it, who will?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can’t blame your environment for your own unhappiness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分の不幸を境遇のせいにするんじゃない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: The maple leaves started to change color too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>楓の葉も色づいてきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>finish</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to finish something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to end something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning you finish something, like a long day at work!

You need to differentiate this from <jp>終わる</jp>, which is when something just ends on its own. <jp>終える</jp> is about when you make something end. Remember it like this: Canadians always end their sentences with "eh" <jp>え</jp>, right? Well that's how you know they're ending their sentence. Just listen for the "eh," eh?
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You finally finished your school project. "Oh, A!" (<jp>おえ</jp>) you say to yourself, as though you can grade your own project.
Context 1-EN: I want to finish work and leave the office by five.
Context 1-JP: <jp>五時には仕事を終えて会社を出たい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: As soon as the princess finished the cake, she had some tea.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王女はケーキを食べ終えるとすぐに、お茶を飲んだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Most fish spend their entire life in water.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ほとんどの魚は水中で一生を終える。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>strict</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>strict</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The most <vocabulary>strict</vocabulary> creature in Japan is the <reading>key bee</reading> (<jp>きび</jp>). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!
Context 1-EN: Many people write harsh comments on the internet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>インターネットでは厳しいコメントを書く人が多い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know <jp>手洗い</jp>, right? This is like that, but way more polite sounding. The meaning is still the same though: <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the <jp>御</jp> is <jp>お</jp>, the rest is <jp>てあらい</jp>, even though the <jp>い</jp> isn't showing on the end. It gets pushed into the <jp>洗い</jp>.
Context 1-EN: How long before we have to be back to the bus from the bathroom? There is a long line, so I’m worried I’ll be late.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何時までに御手洗からバスに戻らなくてはいけませんか？行列ができているので、遅れないか心配してるんですが。</jp>

Meaning: To Rehash,To Bring Up Again,To Drag Up,To Reheat
Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>steam</kanji> something to <kanji>return</kanji> it to its previously warm state. This is when you go <vocabulary>to reheat</vocabulary> something. But we usually use it to talk about bringing something up again and again in conversations or arguments. That's why it means <vocabulary>to rehash</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bring up again</vocabulary>. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>蒸れる</jp> and <jp>返す</jp>. Combine this knowledge to reheat your memories.
Context 1-EN: There you go again. Girls always bring up old issues. I don’t want to deal with that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>またかよ。女はすぐ昔の話を蒸し返すよな。やってられないわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>beat</kanji> makes you want to <kanji>dance</kanji>. It's the <vocabulary>inspiration</vocabulary> you need to dance. The beat gives you <vocabulary>encouragement</vocabulary> to dance all night long. And without such a rockin' beat you would have lame dance moves.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That coach is good at encouraging player morale.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの監督は、選手たちの士気を鼓舞するのがうまい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>use</kanji>d for <kanji>medicine</kanji> is <vocabulary>medicinal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I worry about acne, so I tend to use medicinal soap to wash my face.
Context 1-JP: <jp>にきびが気になるので、薬用の石けんで顔をあらうようにしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Does this pharmacy have medicinal lip moisturizers?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この薬局に、薬用リップクリームはおいていますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a horrible cough, so is it okay for me to take medicated cough drops while I’m pregnant?
Context 3-JP: <jp>咳がひどいんですが、妊娠中に薬用せき止めドロップを服用しても大丈夫でしょうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>embrace</kanji> and a <kanji>hug</kanji> are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to <vocabulary>embrace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hug</vocabulary> people!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>抱</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who gives the best <vocabulary>hug</vocabulary>s in the world? Harry <reading>Hou</reading>dini (<jp>ほう</jp>)! He knows what it's like to be hugged too tightly because he's always in straight jackets. So his hugs are nice and gentle. Just the way you like them!
Context 1-EN: The scene in that movie where the two leading actors exchanged a sweet embrace was so beautiful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その映画の、主役の二人が甘い抱擁を交わすシーンがとても美しかったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>valuable</kanji> and <kanji>heavy</kanji> is extremely <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary> and probably even more <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> than your less heavy things.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <jp>重</jp> though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Keep things <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary> to you very close, because the evil Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<jp>ちょう</jp>) will come and steal it away if you don't. She'll take every <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> you have and destroy them.
Context 1-EN: Thank you for your valuable opinions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>貴重なご意見を有難うございます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>inherit</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to inherit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You not only inherit one fortune, but <reading>two</reading>! You're lucky both sides of your family "accidentally" died at the same time. <reading>TWO</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>) fortunes! TWO! HAHAHAHA. Also, you can think of it like the <jp>つ</jp> of <jp>次</jp>, because you are the "next" successor when you inherit something.
Context 1-EN: The oldest son usually becomes the head of a family in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、通常は長男が一家の跡を継ぎます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fake</kanji> and the verb vocab version is similar, it means <vocabulary>to lie</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cheat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Someone tries <vocabulary>to lie</vocabulary> to you. You can't believe it. <reading>It's wha</reading>t (<jp>いつわ</jp>)??? You can't believe it.
Context 1-EN: I heard "silence is a virtue" in Japan, so I pretended that I was incapable of speech while I was there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では「言わぬが花」だと聞いたので、日本にいる間中自分は口がきけないと偽りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>blind</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blind spot</vocabulary>. Be careful to watch your blind spots when you're driving.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The criminal hit a blind spot in the investigation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>犯人は捜査の盲点を突いてきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>daring</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>dare to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>daringly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're about to <vocabulary>daringly</vocabulary> jump off a cliff and you shout, "<reading>AAAHHH</reading> (<jp>あ</jp>)!" to get your courage up! You always have to yell AAHH before you dare to do daring things!
Context 1-EN: I only dared to say something so intense because it was to you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなただからこそ、敢えて厳しいことを言わせてもらったんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>intestines</kanji> are called the <vocabulary>large intestine</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>colon</vocabulary>. It's where your poop goes and comes from!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They found large intestine cancer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大腸がんが見つかりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Your future consists of <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji>. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very <vocabulary>frantic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>desperate</vocabulary>. 

Another translation for this word is simply <vocabulary>certain death</vocabulary>, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though <jp>必</jp> (<jp>ひつ</jp>) gets shortened to <jp>ひっ</jp>. In your <vocabulary>desperate</vocabulary> situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the <jp>つ</jp> only to find a smaller <jp>っ</jp> blocking your way. It is certain death.
Context 1-EN: Even if I try desperately, it might still be futile.
Context 1-JP: <jp>必死にがんばっても、どうにもならないこともある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that my grandfather went to the war front prepared to die.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのそ父は、必死のかくごでせんじょうに向かったそうです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Captain, I really need to return to Mars. I left my iPhone there," he said desperately.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「隊長、私はどうしても火星に戻る必要があるんです。アイフォンを忘れてしまったのです。」彼は必死に頼んだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Negligent,To Neglect,To Shirk,To Be Off One's Guard
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>neglect</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be negligent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to neglect</vocabulary> something.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you always seem <vocabulary>to be negligent</vocabulary> to your kids you'll end up with this situation. It's winter and your kid comes home from school covered in snow and sneezing. "<reading>Oh, coat</reading>... (<jp>おこた</jp>)" you say. You didn't give them a coat when they went out today. Maybe if you weren't so negligent that wouldn't have happened.
Context 1-EN: I am responsible for this failure of neglecting to check it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この失敗は確認を怠った私の責任です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fault</kanji> and a <kanji>failure</kanji>, all in one. This must have been one big <vocabulary>failure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary> you've made.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>失</jp> gets shortened, though. Don't make that <jp>失敗</jp>.
Context 1-EN: When this player failed to bunt, this other player was caught stealing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こっちの選手はバントを失敗したと思ったら、今度はこっちの選手がとうるいに失敗したんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think failure is still better than doing nothing at all and then regretting that you didn't even try.
Context 2-JP: <jp>失敗して後かいする方が、何もせずに後かいするよりマシだと思うんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: To be honest, this movie you made is a flop. However, you can’t let it get you down just because you failed once. Someone said that success is the ability to go from one failure to another with no loss of enthusiasm, right?
Context 3-JP: <jp>正直言って、君が作ったこの映画は失敗作だね。でも、一度失敗したからといって、くよくよしてちゃ駄目だよ。誰かも、「成功とは、失敗から失敗へと熱意を失うことなく進んでいける能力である」って言ってただろ？</jp>

Meaning: To Tie Up,To Fasten,To Tie Together,To Bind
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fasten</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fasten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie together</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You are fastening up the <reading>coocoo</reading> (<jp>くく</jp>) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.
Context 1-EN: Why did you enclose this sentence in brackets?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてこの文章を括弧で括ったんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You climb the <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> and see adorable little <reading>To</reading>kyo <reading>ge</reading>ckos (<jp>とうげ</jp>) climbing all over the place. They're climbing with you now!
Context 1-EN: Legends says, if you fall off this peak you’ll only have three years left to live.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この峠で転ぶと、三年だけしか生きられないという言い伝えがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grip</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary> someone. You really need them. You are soooo <reading>needy</reading> (<jp>にぎ</jp>). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say <reading><jp>にぎ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Since you make rice balls by pressing rice, it's called "onigiri."
Context 1-JP: <jp>おにぎりは、ご飯を握って作るので「お握り」と呼ばれています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>this month</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There's an important test this month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今月は大切なテストがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please do this by the tenth of this month.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今月の十日までにやってください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'll be in Seattle this month.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今月は、シアトル市にいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have the <kanji>leadership</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> it means you have a lot of <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary> to go after the things you want. And you'll be able to lead others because of it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Despite his youth, my son lacks ambition.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの息子は、若いのに覇気が無い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone built from a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>pattern</kanji> has a <vocabulary>small build</vocabulary>. I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The short old woman did her shopping alone in the store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その店では、一人の小柄なおばあさんが買い物をしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Embrace</kanji> your duty to <kanji>defend</kanji> your country and prepare for its <vocabulary>protection</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>defense</vocabulary>. You love your country, so you'll do what you have to in order to <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> its defense.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why did you speak up to protect him?
Context 1-JP: <jp>君はどうして彼を擁護するような発言をしたんだい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Time to <kanji>overcome</kanji> the <kanji>clothes</kanji> of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a <vocabulary>conquest</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m slowly getting over my homesickness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>徐々にホームシックを克服していってます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you keep <kanji>exhibit</kanji>ing the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to <kanji>rot</kanji> and sound <vocabulary>cliched</vocabulary> to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get <vocabulary>stale</vocabulary>, do you?!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for <jp>ふ</jp> becoming <jp>ぷ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I can’t think of anything but cliched lines.
Context 1-JP: <jp>陳腐な台詞しか思い浮かびません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means that it just happens, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be born</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

You know another word that means "to be born" (生まれる), and they both have the same reading!
Context 1-EN: Our baby was born.
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんが産まれたよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard the puppies will be born soon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もうすぐ子犬が産まれるそうだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi was already able to talk within hours of being born.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、産まれて数時間ですでに話すことができた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, but wait! It's not an adjective, it's just a noun (tricky, tricky). The kanji means <kanji>grief</kanji>, so this word means <vocabulary>grief</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>distress</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned <jp>憂える</jp>. Remember that and you'll remember this!
Context 1-EN: She looked this way with a sorrowful expression on her face.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は、憂いを帯びた顔でこちらを見ていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you can <kanji>teach</kanji> <kanji>hunting</kanji> then you must be a really accomplished <vocabulary>hunter</vocabulary> yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My uncle is a hunter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の叔父は猟師です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Let the <kanji>wind</kanji> in from the window above your <kanji>bath</kanji> so the water is cool enough for you to take a <vocabulary>bath</vocabulary>! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. This isn't the same on'yomi reading you learned for <jp>風</jp>, though. It's a little different: <jp>ふ</jp>. If you're taking a <kanji>bath</kanji> you'd be a <reading>foo</reading>l (<jp>ふ</jp>) to bring food in there. Drop the <jp>う</jp> or you'll end up as soup!
Context 1-EN: I want to slowly soak in the bath.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ゆっくりお風呂に浸かりたいなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To do an <kanji>embrace</kanji> is <vocabulary>to have</vocabulary> that person or animal in your arms. You hug it and then run away with it. It's yours now.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: The favorite for the championship is the genius batter Tofugu Academy has.
Context 1-JP: <jp>優勝候補は、天才バッターを擁するトフグ学園です。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Pierced,To Get Pricked,To Be Stabbed
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, meaning that the piercing just happens, without emphasis on what makes it happen. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be pierced</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get pricked</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be stabbed</vocabulary>. This is a tricky one because the English translations often end up being transitive, but in Japanese we always use this with the particle <jp>に</jp>, not <jp>を</jp>, so it's intransitive.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <jp>刺す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Be careful to not get pricked by a thorn.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トゲが刺さらないように気をつけてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Those words felt like a knife in my heart.
Context 3-JP: <jp>それは心にグサッと刺さる言葉だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Provisions</kanji> you can <kanji>eat</kanji> are still <vocabulary>provisions</vocabulary> and sometimes called <vocabulary>rations</vocabulary>, especially when troops are eating them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There are plenty of emergency provisions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>食糧の備蓄は十分にあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This one uses the on'yomi reading, which you've learned from the kanji already!
Context 1-EN: I have nothing to do.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なにも用がない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you need me for something?
Context 3-EN: Don’t call me unless you have a reason.
Context 3-JP: <jp>用もないのにでんわしてくんじゃねーよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Not Take Seriously,To Take Lightly
Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>see</kanji> something as <kanji>sweet</kanji>, you're just looking at it like it's some little sweet kid with sweet flavoring. You are not taking it seriously, or you are taking it lightly. So sweet! That's why this word is <vocabulary>to not take seriously</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take lightly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>甘い</jp> and <jp>見る</jp>. Don't take this word lightly and you should be able to learn it no problem.
Context 1-EN: Tuck in your shirt or your client may not take you seriously.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シャツを入れないと、お客さんに甘く見られるかもしれないよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Smashed,To Be Shattered,To Break
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be smashed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be shattered</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary> (for things like waves and tension!).
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <jp>砕く</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Suddenly, the window shattered into tiny pieces.
Context 1-JP: <jp>急に窓ガラスが粉々に砕けた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like sitting on the beach and watching the waves break on the shore..
Context 2-JP: <jp>海辺に座って、波が砕けるのを見るのが好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I felt like the tension in the air finally broke, the party was almost over.
Context 3-JP: <jp>緊張した雰囲気がやっと砕けたと思ったんだけど、パーティはすぐに終わっちゃったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Someone left some <vocabulary>evidence</vocabulary> behind at the crime scene. You pick it up, it's <reading>a kashi</reading> (<jp>あかし</jp>) bar. It has genetic evidence on it, because the criminal was eating it at the crime scene.
Context 1-EN: As proof of our friendship, I'll give you this Mt. Fuji keychain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>友情の証として、このふじ山のキーホルダーをあげます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It might not be easy to show the evidence of his innocence.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あいつの身の証を立てるのはそうかん単なことじゃないかもしれない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your parents tell you off, even though they don't actually want to. It's proof of their love.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君の両親だって本当は叱りたくないけど、叱っているんだよ。愛の証だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pour</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pour</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are going <vocabulary>to pour</vocabulary> some <reading>sauce</reading> (<jp>そそ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Did you pour milk in my coke by any chance?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしかして、わたしのコーラに牛にゅう注いだ？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is pouring all of his energy into supporting AKB48 this year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、今年はAKB48をおうえんすることに全力を注いでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Can you pour some more wine for me, please?" "Sure. Just say when." "Yes! There! That’s perfect. Thank you."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「もう少しワインを注いでいただけますか？」「もちろん。“そこまで”って言ってくださいね。」「あ、そこまで！それくらいで結構です。有難うございます。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add <vocabulary>phantom</vocabulary> to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a <reading>mob of Roshi</reading>s (<jp>まぼろし</jp>). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.
Context 1-EN: You'll be able to see apparitions if you take this drug.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この薬を飲むと、幻が見えますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After a series of ecstasy filled visions of Salmon, Fugu finally remembered she had been dead for 12 years, and he realized he was seeing an illusion.
Context 3-JP: <jp>恍惚状態の中でサーモンの幻を何度も見た後に、フグはようやく彼女が12年前に死んだことを思い出し、自分が幻を見ていたことに気づいた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>thing</kanji> that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>auspicious</kanji> is a <vocabulary>scandal</vocabulary>. Scandals are pretty much the opposite of auspicious.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The police are going to cover up our scandal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察は自分たちの不祥事を隠蔽しようとしているんだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Go Through,To Pierce,To Penetrate,To Persist,To Stick To
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pierce</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to go through</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pierce</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The best way <vocabulary>to go through</vocabulary> someone's mind or a college campus is <reading>to run nude</reading> (<jp>つらぬ</jp>). So if you really want <vocabulary>to pierce</vocabulary> someone's mind and soul remember this!
Context 1-EN: My father stuck to his beliefs until the end.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は最後まで自分の信念を貫き通しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>一番</jp> (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (<jp>目</jp>) signifies the order. So, add this to "number one" and you have the <vocabulary>first thing</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is just the vocab word <jp>一番</jp> plus the word <jp>目</jp>. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: The first thing that comes to mind after finishing this wonderful breakfast is that bacon is delicious, as we all know.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このごうかな朝食を食べ終わって、一番目のかんそうは、やっぱりベーコンはおいしい、です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please write down the name of the person you like in the first column.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一番目のらんには、すきな人の名前をかいてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "The first thing I do every morning is run five kilometers." "Big deal! I run ten!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「僕は毎朝一番目に、5キロのランニングをするんだぜ。」「大したことないよ！僕は10キロ走るよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sad</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is one that's especially <vocabulary>disastrous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tragic</vocabulary>. It's the worst kind you can imagine.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The assailant’s remaining family member’s last days were tragic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>残された加害者の家族の末路は、悲惨なものだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>win</kanji> and you have <kanji>failure</kanji>. When you are talking about both in one word, you have <vocabulary>victory or defeat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The game's outcome was decided on the morning of the day before last.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その戦いの勝敗なら、一昨日の朝決まりましたよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That one word Koichi said made the difference between victory and defeat.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのその一言が、勝敗の分かれ目になったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My parents always told me that it doesn’t matter if I win or lose, as long as I try my best, but I didn’t like that. Of course, I care very much about winning and losing. If I lose after doing my best, then there’s no point.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の両親はいつも、全力を尽くしさえすれば、勝敗は問題ではないと言っていたけれど、私はそれが好きじゃありませんでした。もちろん、私は勝敗をとても気にします。だって、ベストを尽くした後に負けるなんて、意味が無いじゃないですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fiber</kanji>s that have been <kanji>change</kanji>d from other materials are <vocabulary>synthetic fibers</vocabulary>. They aren't natural because they were something else once. Like plastic, or kittens.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I use a synthetic fiber broom for sweeping.
Context 1-JP: <jp>掃除には、化繊箒を使っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>respond</kanji> to your <kanji>recruit</kanji>ment with this <vocabulary>application</vocabulary> to try and join your group.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can get the application form at the courthouse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>応募用紙は裁判所でもらえますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some strawberries to celebrate!
Context 1-EN: Strawberries are expensive this spring.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の春は苺が高い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That grocery store sells white strawberries.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのスーパーに、白い苺が売ってるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I went strawberry picking with a werewolf.
Context 3-JP: <jp>狼男と一緒に苺狩りに行った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>take along</kanji> your <kanji>leadership</kanji> over and over, you're on a <vocabulary>winning streak</vocabulary>! You can expect <vocabulary>successive victories </vocabulary> in <vocabulary>consecutive championships</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for <jp>は</jp> becoming <jp>ぱ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Has there been a high school that’s had three successive victories at Kochien yet?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今までに甲子園を三連覇した高校はありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: <vocabulary>Five</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since numbers are an exception, this word is read using the on'yomi reading even though it's made from a single kanji all alone. Luckily for you, you learned the reading for this word when you learned the parent kanji.
Context 1-EN: Tom bought five onigiri at the convenience store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トムさんは、コンビニでおにぎりを五こかいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My friend was born on May 5th in the 55th year of Showa.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのともだちはしょうわ五十五ねん五月いつかうまれです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Once upon a time, there was a mother pig with five baby pigs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>むかしむかし、五ひきの子ぶたをうんだははぶたがいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>whittle down</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to whittle down</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: <vocabulary>To whittle down</vocabulary> or not <vocabulary>to whittle down</vocabulary>. Will have to take it on a <reading>case</reading> (<jp>けず</jp>) by case basis.
Context 1-EN: The sound of shaving down teeth is one of the most unpleasant sounds to me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>歯を削る音ってのは、私にとっては最も不快な音の一つだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>literature</vocabulary>. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What’s the significance of reading literature?
Context 1-JP: <jp>文学をよむいみとは何だろうか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was majoring in English literature in university.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは大学で、イギリス文学をせんこうしていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think Haruki Murakami's work is pop literature pretending to be pure literature.
Context 3-JP: <jp>村上春樹の作品は、純文学のふりをした大衆文学だと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>afflicted</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is <vocabulary>a patient</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>medical patient</vocabulary>. They are afflicted with some disease which is why they need medical attention.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That patient clung to his dream of being a soccer player even though his left leg was paralyzed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その患者は、左足が麻痺してもなお、サッカー選手になれるという希望に固執していた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have something with <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>angle</kanji>s, what shape is that? It's a <vocabulary>triangle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please go buy triangle crackers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三角のクラッカーをかってきてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am stuck in a love triangle now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今、三角かんけいになっちゃってるんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Canadians must have been inspired by Picasso quite a bit. Square boxes, round pizzas, and triangle pizza slices are everywhere.
Context 3-JP: <jp>カナダ人はピカソにかなり刺激を受けたに違いない。四角い箱に、丸いピザ、三角のピザスライスがあちこちにある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word is almost the same as the kanji, but only half of it. It means <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary>. They're about the same shape and size as money, but you can't buy a house with them (...probably).
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You can't find your <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> anywhere. It was just there, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You search for it everywhere, then you realize... it was right there all along. Seriously? You're such a <reading>foo</reading>l, <reading>duh</reading> (<jp>ふだ</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: Please put this amulet on the inside of your front door.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このお札は、げんかんのドアの内がわにはっておいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should be careful not to show your hand.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自分の札を見せないようにした方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Jello is really disgusting. There should be a picture of a skull and crossbones on the label.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ジェロってほんとにキモい。ドクロマークの絵が描かれた札でも付けておくべきだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!
Context 1-EN: On Wednesday, meat is cheap.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水よう日は、肉がやすいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Among beef, pork, and chicken, which meat do you like the best?
Context 2-JP: <jp>牛肉とぶた肉ととり肉の中ではどれが一ばんすきですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Meat is the most important component between two slices of bread.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お肉は、二枚の食パンに挟まれる、もっとも重要な具材です。</jp>

Meaning: To Cave In,To Collapse,To Fall,To Trap
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cave in</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to cave in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to collapse</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The cave you're hanging around in is about <vocabulary>to cave in</vocabulary>! Right as you're about to get crushed you scream, "<reading>Oh CHEESE</reading> (<jp>おちい</jp>)!!" You can't swear for real or you'll go to hell when this cave in crushes you to death. And OH CHEESE felt right as your last words.
Context 1-EN: At this rate, it’s bound to collapse from the price competition.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このままでは、価格競争に陥るのがオチですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned the word <jp>枯れる</jp> which means "to wither," but this is when you are the one making a plant wither. It means <vocabulary>to let dry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to kill</vocabulary> your plants. They didn't just die on their own, you did it.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned <jp>枯れる</jp>, so you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I gave the cactus too much water and I killed it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水をやりすぎて、サボテンを枯らしてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Ready for this one? An <kanji>iron</kanji> <kanji>fence </kanji> is an <vocabulary>iron fence</vocabulary>. Don't you love it when it's straightforward?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful though, <jp>鉄</jp> is normally read as <jp>てつ</jp>, but in this case it is shortened to <jp>てっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: How do you feel about enclosing that with an iron fence?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そこに鉄柵をめぐらすのはどうでしょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have to repair the iron fence as soon as possible.
Context 2-JP: <jp>出来るだけ早く鉄柵を修理しないといけません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Look! Something's caught on the iron fence.
Context 3-JP: <jp>見て！鉄柵に何か引っかかっているよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how <jp>岐阜</jp> is "Gifu." Now make it a prefecture to make <vocabulary>Gifu prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do I have to change trains to get to Gifu prefecture?
Context 1-JP: <jp>岐阜県に行くには、電車の乗り換えが必要ですか？</jp>

Meaning: Public Behavior,Public Behaviour,Official Stance,Public Position,Public Face,Tatemae
Meaning Mnemonic: What you <kanji>build</kanji> up in <kanji>front</kanji> of other people is your public image. This is your <vocabulary>public behavior</vocabulary>, how you act around others you don't really know. This concept is surprisingly important in Japan, so you'll hear it often enough despite being such a strange concept in other places. You'll have to think of this like you're building buildings of personality in front of you. These show off who you are on the outside, but it protects what's on the inside.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like <jp>建物</jp> in that it's read as <jp>たて</jp>, which is like the word <jp>建てる</jp> even though the <jp>て</jp> isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like <jp>建てる</jp> but the <jp>て</jp> gets pushed into the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Viet is good at separating his public and private selves.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトは本音と建前を使い分けるのが上手い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our official stance is that you can't see a doctor here without a letter of reference.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しょうかいじょうが無いとここの医者にみてもらえないというのは建前です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s often said that "the contrast between one’s personal feelings and public behavior" is a characteristic unique to Japanese culture, but that exists all over the world.
Context 3-JP: <jp>よく「本音と建前」は日本独特の文化だと言われますが、実際は世界中に存在します。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Biased,To Be One Sided,To Be Partial,To Be Prejudiced
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>biased</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be biased</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be prejudiced</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You meet someone who claims <vocabulary>to be biased</vocabulary> about everything. You ask them why and they say, "I'm a <reading>cutter, yo</reading> (<jp>かたよ</jp>)! I cut everything in half and only like one of 'em. But I guess if you wanna call that biased go ahead, man." Huh okay.
Context 1-EN: One sided nutrition isn’t good for you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>栄養が偏るのは良くない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means <kanji>cut</kanji> so this means something is cut. Something breaks or snaps. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be cut</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the <jp>き</jp> portion: 

Something is <vocabulary>snap</vocabulary>ping. Turns out that something is your arm. Your arm is a <reading><jp>木</jp></reading> (<jp>き</jp>) that grew out of you one day. "What's this ki doing here?" you ask. Then it suddenly <vocabulary>break</vocabulary>s in half! "OW OW OW! My ki! It's been cut!!"
Context 1-EN: The tape was cut.
Context 1-JP: <jp>テープが切れてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I feel lonely as soon as the phone line disconnects.
Context 2-JP: <jp>でんわが切れるおとをきくとさみしくなる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a strange one, but only at first glance. You <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>house</kanji>. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means author. Think of it this way: An <vocabulary>author</vocabulary> <kanji>makes</kanji> (writes and creates works) in their <kanji>home</kanji>. Authors don't make their word magic in a corporate office!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are on'yomi readings, though <jp>さく</jp> from <jp>作</jp> gets shortened to <jp>さっ</jp>. Just be sure to remember that and you should be able to read this word just fine.
Context 1-EN: I got an autograph from an aspiring author.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あこがれの作家さんから、サインをもらいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This novelist pushed things pretty far, eh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この作家、ずいぶん思い切ったね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That best-selling author’s hobby is playing soccer.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あのベストセラー作家の趣味はサッカーだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Purify</kanji> water to <kanji>change</kanji> it from being dirty. This is called <vocabulary>purification</vocabulary>. It's important to purify water before you drink it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m designing a facility to purify radioactive water.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は、放射能汚染水を浄化する施設を設計しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wither</kanji>ed <kanji>tree</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dead tree</vocabulary> and it's got really <vocabulary>dry wood</vocabulary>. Perfect for a campfire!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes you'll see it spelled <jp>枯木</jp> without the kana too. Keep your eyes open for it!
Context 1-EN: Let’s make the dead tree bloom.
Context 1-JP: <jp>枯れ木に花を咲かせましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kind of <kanji>score</kanji> that <kanji>comfort</kanji>s you is a musical <vocabulary>score</vocabulary>. The music is really relaxing. So is reading <vocabulary>sheet music</vocabulary>. You should try it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I can play the piano but I can’t read sheet music.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ピアノは弾けますが、楽譜は読めません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>cleanse</kanji>d yourself you're going to be covered in <vocabulary>uncleanliness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dirtiness</vocabulary>. Eww.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>インドでは、左手を不浄の手として、右手でご飯を食べる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Melon</kanji>s that grow in the <kanji>west</kanji> are round and striped and green and wait a second. That's a <vocabulary>watermelon</vocabulary>. I guess they come from the western part of Japan.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for <jp>西</jp> here is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

<vocabulary>Watermelon</vocabulary>s taste best after you <reading>swi</reading>ng (<jp>すい</jp>) them around. Whether you tie a rope to them or swing them on an actual swing, it mixes up the yummy watermelon insides and they end up tasting the best this way. So always remember to swing your watermelon before you crack it open.
Context 1-EN: Speaking of summer, it’s a watermelon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夏といえば西瓜ですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You want to <kanji>lock</kanji> this criminal's <kanji>hand</kanji>s up so he won't go punching anymore grandpas. You need some <vocabulary>handcuffs</vocabulary> to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. You know them both, so this shouldn't be too hard to remember!

Context 1-JP: <jp>犯人と間違われて手錠を掛けられたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>yellow</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is just the color <vocabulary>yellow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

Context 2-EN: An American crow is well known for the beauty of its yellow wings.

Meaning: To Demolish,To Break,To Pull Down,To Crumble
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>crumble</kanji>, so what happens when you crumble something? You are going <vocabulary>to demolish</vocabulary> it. You are going <vocabulary>to break it</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the crumbling / demolishing because someone's going to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you for what you've done here today.
Reading Mnemonic: You are Zeus, and you demolish everything in your path. Your friend Hercules watches and is all like "That's <reading>coo' Zeus</reading> (<jp>くず</jp>), that's so cool."

Context 1-JP: <jp>「1ドル札を崩してもらえませんか？」「ええっと…25セント硬貨が2枚と10セント硬貨が5枚あります。これでよろしいですか？」「はい。有難うございます。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned the word <jp>沸く</jp> which means "to boil" or "to grow hot" but this is when you are the one heating the water. It still means <vocabulary>to boil</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to heat</vocabulary>. But remember that you're the one who is doing the heating.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned <jp>沸く</jp>, so you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I ran the bath for you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お風呂を沸かしておきましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>米国</jp> is "America." Well, more of that again. With <jp>米</jp> representing "America" you can combine that with <jp>兵</jp> (<kanji>soldier</kanji>) to have yourself a <vocabulary>US soldier</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>American soldier</vocabulary>.
