Context 1-JP: <jp>この辺りは治安も悪くないけど、あの辺りは治安が良くないからね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet's boss was arrested for disturbing the peace.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトの親分は、治安ぼうがいでたいほされた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The other day I saw Koichi, drunk, boastfully telling people that he's actually Superman and he's the one who keeps the peace around here.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こないだ、酔っ払ったコウイチが、「俺は実はスーパーマンなんだ。この辺りの治安を守っているのはこの俺様なんだ」って豪語していたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>perfect</kanji> way to <kanji>tie</kanji> up a research paper is with a <vocabulary>conclusion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This novel will be concluded in the next edition.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この小説は、次号で完結する予定です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was about to ask a question, but I ended up coming up with the conclusion by myself.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しつ問しようと思ってたけど、勝手に自こ完結しちゃったんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This manga hasn’t been completed yet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この漫画はまだ完結していません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>subscription</kanji> has been <kanji>read</kanji>. Each magazine that comes in you read. This is your <vocabulary>subscription</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The on'yomi for <jp>読</jp> (<jp>どく</jp>) is the same as the reading in <jp>読者</jp>. In case you forgot, think about how you just got a subscription to <reading>dock</reading> (<jp>どく</jp>) magazine. It's all about docks and dock related things. How exciting.
Context 1-EN: The rumor that all American people subscribe to the Tofugu newsletter spread throughout Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全アメリカ人がTofuguのニュースレターを購読しているという噂が、日本中に広まった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>commander</kanji> that <kanji>unite</kanji>s the world is one with <vocabulary>supreme command</vocabulary>. He's better than all the other commanders who couldn't bring everyone together and now he rules over everyone.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today at school we learned about the supreme command authority of the Emperor of Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は学校で、天皇の統帥権について学びました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>inflation</kanji> of <kanji>boil</kanji>ing water means that bubbles are being inflated in there and bubbling to the top. This is called <vocabulary>boiling</vocabulary>, or if it's happening in a person it's called <vocabulary>seething</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The soup was boiling and simmering.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スープが沸騰してグツグツいってますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>moon</kanji> is <vocabulary>every month</vocabulary> (as you know from all the month-related vocab). This can also mean <vocabulary>monthly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The most common reading for this word has the on'yomi reading for <jp>毎</jp> plus the kun'yomi reading for <jp>月</jp>. That makes it <jp>まいつき</jp>. But it can be read <jp>まいげつ</jp> using both on'yomi readings too. You can use either!
Context 1-EN: There is a test at my school every month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの学こうでは、毎月テストがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Although my family wasn't rich, my parents sent a living allowance to me when I was in university.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ゆうふくないえではありませんでしたが、わたしが大学生のとき、りょうしんは毎月生かつひをしおくりしてくれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How much do you pay for rent each month?
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎月どのくらい家賃を払っていますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Slender</kanji> and <kanji>thin</kanji> things are very <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dainty</vocabulary>. They're easily broken, so you have to be careful.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I like the elegant and subtle flavors of Japanese food.
Context 1-JP: <jp>上品で繊細な味の日本食が好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do a <kanji>warship</kanji> and a <kanji>rowboat</kanji> have in common? In wartime they're both considered <vocabulary>military vessel</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The crew of the navy’s war fleet is lacking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>海軍の艦艇の乗組員が不足しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>失敗</jp> is a mistake? Well, a <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>mistake</kanji> is going to be a <vocabulary>total failure</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>huge mistake</vocabulary>. So terrible!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know <jp>失敗</jp> on its own as well.
Context 1-EN: I made the big mistake of farting during the silence.
Context 1-JP: <jp>静けさの中でおならをするという大失敗をおかしてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our idea of having Mami watch Koichi's bacon was a total failure. She ate every single piece.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マミにコウイチのベーコンを見ていてもらうというアイデアは大失敗でした。マミがコウイチのベーコンを全部食べちゃったんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In the meeting yesterday, Shark really made a huge mistake. I think he might lose his position.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日の会議で、シャークの奴大失敗しちゃったんだよ。もしかすると今のポジションから降ろされちゃうかも。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>crotch</kanji> and what's <kanji>below</kanji> it is called your <vocabulary>inseam</vocabulary>. It's that line that goes down the inside of your pants. Depending on your variety of English, you might call this your <vocabulary>inside leg</vocabulary> instead!
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun’yomi reading of both kanji. You learned また from the word 股, and you learned した from the word 下 a lonnnng time ago. If you didn't remember either of these, hang your head in shame and look at your またした!
Context 1-EN: What's the inseam of your jeans in centimeters?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのジーンズって股下何センチ？</jp>
Context 2-EN: That giant's inseam is five meters long.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの巨人の股下は5メートルもある。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm not a fan of pants that are too short.
Context 3-JP: <jp>股下が短すぎるズボンは苦手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>crotch</kanji> and the vocabulary also means <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>groin</vocabulary>. This word is a little less specific than <jp>股間</jp>, which you already learned. It can even be used to refer to the thigh, though in that case the reading is usually <jp>もも</jp> and it's mostly written in hiragana or katakana.

This can also be used for a <vocabulary>fork</vocabulary> in a road or path, which makes sense when you think about it, doesn't it?
Reading Mnemonic:
You learned the on’yomi for this kanji, but like many kanji it takes the kun’yomi when used by itself. You haven't learned the kun’yomi yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you: 

You’ve spilled something on your <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary> again (<jp>又</jp>, get it?) but your pants are so stained at this point that it doesn’t even <reading>matter</reading> (<jp>また</jp>).
Context 1-EN: There is a star-shaped mole on Koichi's crotch.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの股には星の形のホクロがある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm thinking of getting a Tofugu tattoo in my groin area.
Context 2-JP: <jp>股の辺りにトーフグのタトゥーを入れようと思っているんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After I passed through the tunnel, there was a fork in the road.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トンネルを出ると、道が二股に分かれていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>compete</kanji> in a <kanji>rowboat</kanji> is to take part in a <vocabulary>boat race</vocabulary>, also known as a <vocabulary>regatta</vocabulary>. Who are you gonna bet on?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I made a killing in the boat race.
Context 1-JP: <jp>競艇で大儲けしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>廃止</jp> is <kanji>abolition</kanji>, so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to abolish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know <jp>廃止</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: It seems that teachers are considering abolishing uniforms.
Context 1-JP: <jp>教師陣が制服を廃止するかどうか検討しているそうですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are <kanji>strong</kanji> so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then <kanji>steal</kanji> from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a <vocabulary>burglary</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>robbery</vocabulary>, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>強</jp> is all messed up. Think about how when you commit a <vocabulary>robbery</vocabulary>, you <reading>go</reading> (<jp>ごう</jp>) into someone's house, then you <reading>go</reading> to jail as well, if you're caught.
Context 1-EN: Do you want to rob a bank? It’s now or never.
Context 1-JP: <jp>銀行強盗をやってみないか？今を逃がすと一生ないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If someone <kanji>abduct</kanji>s what do they <kanji>do</kanji>? That's <vocabulary>abduction</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>kidnapping</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>taking captive</vocabulary>. This word comes up fairly frequently in Japanese newspapers, and is often used to refer to kidnappings carried out by North Korea in the seventies and eighties.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: All the kidnapping victims have returned safely.
Context 1-JP: <jp>拉致被害者全員が無事に帰ってきた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why is there no progress on the abduction issue?
Context 2-JP: <jp>拉致問題は、なぜ進まないのでしょうか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The traveler was taken captive by a gang of robbers but released a few days later.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その旅行者は強盗団に拉致されたが、数日後に放れた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We are <kanji>lack</kanji>ing and things are <kanji>scarce</kanji>. We have a <vocabulary>lack</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>scarcity</vocabulary> of resources.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How can I know if I’m deficient in Vitamin D?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビタミンDが欠乏しているかどうかはどうすれば分かりますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>look at</kanji>... just one. A little one. Just <vocabulary>a look</vocabulary>. Just <vocabulary>a glance</vocabulary>. That's all I want.

It also has another meaning! When you're talking about computers and you want to see everything in one look, you will arrange it into a nice <vocabulary>list</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>table</vocabulary>. That way you only have to look at the data one time!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m struggling to find my boss’s name on my contact list.
Context 1-JP: <jp>連絡先の一覧から中々上司の名前が見つからないんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: If you fall into a <vocabulary>pond</vocabulary>, what sound do you make? <reading>EEEEK</reading> (<jp>いけ</jp>)! Or maybe you're just afraid of ponds (I don't blame you, there are probably snakes or leeches or alligators in there) and you EEEEK when someone mentions them.
Context 1-EN: This pond is too big.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この池は大きすぎる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I dropped a bamboo arrow in the pond, God came out of it and asked me, "Did you drop this bamboo arrow or this gold arrow?" So I answered honestly, "I dropped the bamboo arrow, but I want the gold arrow, too."
Context 2-JP: <jp>池に竹の矢をおとしたら、中からかみさまがあらわれて、「おまえがおとしたのはこの竹の矢か、それともこの金の矢か。」ときかれたので、正じきに「竹の矢ですが、その金の矢もほしいです。」といった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My neighbor keeps tossing the dead birds that he shoots into my pond.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちのご近所さんは、鳥を撃ち落としては、うちの池に投げ入れる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>oppress</kanji> people and then <kanji>kill</kanji> them is an <vocabulary>atrocity</vocabulary>. It's also called a <vocabulary>massive killing</vocabulary> because that's what you're actually doing. And you're awful, why would you ever do that?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you say the Nanking Massacre is a fabrication, please explain the evidence.
Context 1-JP: <jp>南京大虐殺が捏造だったというなら、その証拠を説明してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>master</kanji> of a <kanji>fiefdom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>feudal lord</vocabulary>. We also call them <vocabulary>Daimyo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We went to visit the daimyo’s tomb.
Context 1-JP: <jp>藩主の墓に参ってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> that comes out of a <kanji>writing brush</kanji> is <vocabulary>essay</vocabulary>s. You can't paint or doodle, you have to write with it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please teach me how to write essays.
Context 1-JP: <jp>随筆の書き方を教えてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>butterfly</kanji> with another <kanji>butterfly</kanji> added to it? It's still a <vocabulary>butterfly</vocabulary>, just a really big one with... with four wings. And laser eyes? Oh well, just go with it. It's a butterfly.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.
Context 1-EN: She was a woman who was as free as a butterfly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は蝶々のように自由な女性でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When <kanji>prosperity</kanji> <kanji>wakes up</kanji> it will push through whatever it's in and create a <vocabulary>protuberance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bulge</vocabulary>. Just imagine it pushing out of the wall, trying to get out, making a bulge. So prosperous!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic for the reading of <jp>起</jp>. To get out of this bulge, you use a <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>). The key lets you get out.
Context 1-EN: The adam’s apple is also known as the throat Buddha because the bone shape looks like Buddha.
Context 1-JP: <jp>喉頭隆起は、その近くにある骨の形が仏様に似ていることから、喉仏としても知られています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>summit</kanji> and this word can mean <vocabulary>summit</vocabulary> too, but also <vocabulary>crown</vocabulary>, which goes on the summit of a person at the top of the social summit's head.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You should already know this reading from when you learned <jp>頂く</jp>. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!
Context 1-EN: If there is anything of mine that you’d like, please help yourself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>頂きものなんですが、良かったらどうぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Expose</kanji> what you want to <kanji>expose</kanji> by making an <vocabulary>announcement</vocabulary>. Then <vocabulary>show</vocabulary> the world!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>露</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're making the <vocabulary>announcement</vocabulary> from a <reading>row</reading> (<jp>ろう</jp>) boat. People will pay more attention when you're in a row boat because it's kind of weird. Especially since you're in a row boat on a stage.
Context 1-EN: Sleight of hand was performed at the birthday party.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誕生日会で、手品を披露しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>North</kanji> <kanji>latitude</kanji> is <vocabulary>north latitude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>northern latitude</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Enoshima and Greece’s Crete island are on the same northern latitude.
Context 1-JP: <jp>江ノ島とギリシャのクレタ島の北緯は同じです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>bored</kanji> all the time it makes you tired and the <vocabulary>weariness</vocabulary> you feel will show on your face.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how you learned <jp>飽きる</jp>? Well just take of the <jp>る</jp> and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!
Context 1-EN: Well, I’m fickle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私って、飽きっぽいのよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In the <kanji>old</kanji> times Japan thought one country was full of nothing but <kanji>darkness</kanji>. That country was <vocabulary>Mongolia</vocabulary>. It was mostly because when the Mongolians invaded it was always night time. So everyone just started thinking they were used to the darkness because they lived in it all the time back home.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This picture depicts the state at the time of the Mongolian invasion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この絵には、蒙古襲来の時の様子が描かれています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It will <kanji>pass through</kanji> what you <kanji>believe</kanji> and run into some <kanji>netting</kanji>. Just think about how all these communications are passing through between people, and everyone believes everything that's being said. Netting this all up (all these communications!) leaves you with a <vocabulary>communication network</vocabulary>. What fun!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The moment the clock announced the time, all the communications networks stopped.
Context 1-JP: <jp>時計が時刻を告げた瞬間、全ての通信網が途絶えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>shop</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>shop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is there a rental car shop near the airport?
Context 1-JP: <jp>空港の近くにレンタカーの店舗はありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>time</kanji> in the world you can do whatever you want <vocabulary>at any time</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If new information comes in, I'll contact you at any time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しい情報が入れば、随時ご連絡致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>commander</kanji>'s <kanji>origin</kanji> was as the <vocabulary>general of the army</vocabulary>. He stepped down, but that's where he started. Maybe he's working the system backwards...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That’s famous supreme commander, General MacArthur.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これが、あの有名な最高司令官のマッカ—サ—元帥です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you don't want your <kanji>thought</kanji>s to turn <kanji>rust colored</kanji>, you need to be <vocabulary>diligent</vocabulary> and studying, learning, and experiencing new things. Without diligence your brain and all your thoughts will get old, and stale, turning a rusty, gross color.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The skilled dyeing master diligently finished dyeing each one.
Context 1-JP: <jp>熟練の染師が、一つ一つ丹念に染め上げました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>seal in</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a <vocabulary>sealed letter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I signed the contract and put it in an envelope, but I haven’t mailed the sealed letter to them yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>契約書にサインをして封筒に入れてありますが、まだその封書を郵送していません。</jp>

Meaning: To Endure,To Keep Out,To Stave Off,To Surpass,To Outrank,To Eclipse
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>endure</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to keep out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: When I was poor I ate weeds to stave off starvation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>貧乏な時は、雑草を食べて飢えを凌いでいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you combine <jp>電気</jp> (electricity) with <jp>柵</jp> (<kanji>fence</kanji>) you have an <vocabulary>electric fence</vocabulary>. Shocking, I know.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: More and more fields are surrounded by electric fences.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電気柵を張りめぐらせる畑が増えている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My dad installed the electric fence.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お父さんが電気柵を設置してくれたんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We've installed electric fences as a countermeasure against wild boars and monkeys.
Context 3-JP: <jp>イノシシや猿への対策として、電気柵を導入した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that an <jp>お願い</jp> is a request, and that <jp>事</jp> is a "thing" or "action." So, this is a "request action," in a sense. A better way to say that is <vocabulary>one's wish</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>, because that's what you're doing when you do the action of requesting something.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the words <jp>お願い</jp> and <jp>事</jp>. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too.
Context 1-EN: I think your prayers will be answered soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの願い事は、きっとすぐにかなうと思います。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When Koichi goes to sleep he always keeps a piece of paper with his wishes written on it nearby.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはいつも、願い事を書いた紙をそばにおいてねます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Japanese people visit shrines on important occasions not only to make wishes but also to offer thanks.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本人は、人生の節目節目に、願い事だけでなく感謝の気持ちを伝えるために、神社を訪れます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you're trying to be <vocabulary>graceful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>polite</vocabulary> you have to cut certain words out of your vocabulary. The number one being <reading>sh*t</reading> (<jp>しと</jp>). You can't say you need to "go take a sh*t" during an international conference or a fancy dinner! You need to be modest and not use that word, geez.
Context 1-EN: Even now there are many men who like modest women.
Context 1-JP: <jp>未だに淑やかな女性が好きな男性は多い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sell</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to sell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be sold</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read it! It's the same reading as <jp>売る</jp> where you're trying to sell some <reading>U</reading>ni (<jp>う</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: This game will definitely sell well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このゲーム、ぜったい売れるだろ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'd say, if you put up the thousand yen bill for online auction, it would easily sell for five hundred yen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その千円札、五百円でネットオークションにかけたら、よゆうで売れるっしょ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I will teach you how to write novels that sell.
Context 3-JP: <jp>売れる小説の書き方を教えてあげよう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A miner works with such <kanji>sincerity</kanji> that her arms and legs start turning <kanji>rust colored</kanji> from <vocabulary>working earnestly</vocabulary>. All the clay and rocks she's putting her <vocabulary>effort</vocabulary> into digging are turning her the same color. That color is how you know someone works with serious <vocabulary>diligence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Grandma worked earnestly and raised the tomatoes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お婆ちゃんが丹誠込めて育てたトマトだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> and <kanji>love</kanji> all in the same package. Well, that is <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When I'm in love, I'm usually way too into them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>恋愛したら、相手に対していつも愛情を感じすぎてしまうんだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My kid has been reading romance novels all the time lately.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの子は、最近恋愛小説ばかり読んでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Parting from someone you love is always painfully bittersweet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>恋愛での別れ際は、切なくて甘酸っぱい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same, but instead of just meaning <kanji>again</kanji> it also means <vocabulary>furthermore</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>moreover</vocabulary>. This is one of those good paragraph-starting essay words!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit different from what you learned with the kanji, though. Just think about how <vocabulary>again</vocabulary> he dropped the <reading><jp>皿</jp></reading> (<jp>さら</jp>). Wow, what a screw up. Again and again.
Context 1-EN: After studying abroad you need to continue speaking to native speakers to further improve your English.
Context 1-JP: <jp>留学後、更に英語を上達させるには、ネイティブスピーカーと喋り続ける必要があります。</jp>

Meaning: Expert,Professional,Specialist,Woman Of The Red Light District
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mysterious</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is really really good at what they do. So good that they aren't exactly sure what is it they do, but you know they're definitely an <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary> at whatever it is.
Reading Mnemonic:
This reading for this word is mysteriously an exception (sorry). So here's a mnemonic to help:

If you're such an <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary> you should be able to tell what anything is if someone asks you. Even this <reading>crow toe</reading> (<jp>くろうと</jp>). Crow toes are pretty hard to recognize, unless you're a <vocabulary>professional</vocabulary> crow guy. But I guess you are, huh?
Context 1-EN: My hobby is to try to differentiate between professionals and amateurs in the "water trade."
Context 1-JP: <jp>水商売の玄人と素人を見分けるのが趣味です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the word <jp>渦</jp> meaning "whirlpool" and <jp>巻く</jp> meaning "to roll." A rolling whirlpool is still a <vocabulary>whirlpool</vocabulary>, just a really violent one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>渦</jp> and <jp>巻く</jp>. <jp>巻く</jp> becomes <jp>巻き</jp> and you just add <jp>渦</jp> to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.
Context 1-EN: Why are mosquito coils in a whirlpool shape?
Context 1-JP: <jp>蚊取り線香はどうして渦巻き状になっているんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prolong</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to prolong</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Do you mind if I go <vocabulary>to prolong</vocabulary> things? The answer? "<reading>No</reading> (<jp>の</jp>), I don't mind."
Context 1-EN: I want to enlarge this photo to put it on the wall.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この写真を延ばして壁に飾りたいなと思ってるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>巻く</jp> means "to roll?" Well the thing you roll up around your <kanji>collar</kanji> is a <vocabulary>scarf</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The girl wrapped in the pink scarf is my little sister.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ピンクの襟巻きを巻いているのが私の妹です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shift</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be shifted</vocabulary>. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really <reading>ru</reading>de (<jp>る</jp>) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>移す</jp>, so use that to remember this!
Context 1-EN: I don’t like Korean barbecue because the smell gets on your clothes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>臭いが服に移るから、焼肉は好きじゃないの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Rank</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> is the <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you get first place, I'll make you karaage every day for a week.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一位になったら、一週間毎日からあげを作ってあげる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My kid won first place in a piano competition.
Context 2-JP: <jp>子供がピアノコンクールで一位をとりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mom! I really aced that test! I ranked at the top of my class!
Context 3-JP: <jp>お母さん！僕、あのテストで滅茶苦茶良い点をとったんだよ！なんとクラスで一位だったんだ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main shop</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>head office</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I always buy baby things at the main baby shop.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ベビー用品は、いつも赤ちゃん本舗で買います。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Lacking,To Not Be Present,To Get Chipped
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>lack</kanji>, and this verb has several meanings related to that. It can mean <vocabulary>to be lacking</vocabulary>, like "imagination is really lacking in this movie." It can also mean <vocabulary>to not be present</vocabulary>, like when you realize your Japanese teacher is missing. When talking about something like a tea cup or your teeth, it can mean <vocabulary>to get chipped</vocabulary>. I guess if you chip a teapot it is lacking in...perfection?
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Something is lacking... it's a <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only that car wasn't missing, this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because that car's not present.
Context 1-EN: I fell off my bike and chipped my front teeth.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自てん車でこけて、前ばが欠けてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That plan is lacking in reliability.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その予定は確実性に欠けています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I lack the willpower to stop watching Sailor Moon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私には、セーラームーンを見るのを止めるための強い意志が欠けている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>slap</kanji> is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is <vocabulary>sumo wrestling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's <reading><jp>すもう</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Do you want to drink some beer and watch sumo wrestling tonight?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今夜ビールを飲みながら相撲を見るってのはどうだい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
<kanji>Humbly</kanji> <kanji>receive</kanji> something and you'll be <vocabulary>humbly receiving</vocabulary> it. Or <vocabulary>humbly eating</vocabulary> it if they gave you food and not a puppy or something inedible. It can also mean <vocabulary>humbly having</vocabulary>. The theme here is humility!

This is usually formal when written in kanji and used together with a verb like <jp>する</jp>. It can also be used alone to make very casual requests. In casual requests, it's still written in kanji in novels and other creative writing, but is generally written in hiragana anywhere else.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because <jp>たい</jp> becomes <jp>だい</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: We received a call from the client a little while ago.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先ほど、先方からお電話を頂戴しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Well then, I shall eat it gratefully, without hesitation.
Context 3-EN: Mom, let me have this ring when I grow up, won't you?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ママのこの指輪、大きくなったら私に頂戴ね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>縫う</jp> means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your <kanji>eye</kanji> is if you see a <vocabulary>seam</vocabulary>. If your eyes can't spot the <vocabulary>stitch</vocabulary>es, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>縫う</jp> and <jp>目</jp>. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the <jp>う</jp> to <jp>い</jp> and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled <jp>縫い目</jp> too. They're exactly the same!
Context 1-EN: I sewed it myself, so the stitches are crooked.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分で縫ったので縫い目がガタガタなんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tolerance</kanji>, so the verb version is what happens when you're a really tolerant person. You're able <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to feel at home</vocabulary> because nothing really gets to you.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You want <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary> so you go down to old <reading>coots ro</reading>ad (<jp>くつろ</jp>). It's a road with a bunch of old coots who don't bother nobody. They just kinda sit around and complain. That's where you like to relax. Something about being surrounded by a bunch of old coots on old coots road makes you feel at home.
Context 1-EN: I relaxed like it was my own home.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まるで自分の家のように寛いでいました。</jp>

Meaning: Hard To Deal With,Weak Point,Poor At,Not Very Good At,Bad At
Meaning Mnemonic: A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words <jp>苦い</jp> (bitter) and <jp>手</jp> (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely <vocabulary>hard to deal with</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is that of <jp>苦い</jp> (<jp>にがい</jp>) plus regular old <jp>手</jp> (<jp>て</jp>). Remember, this is your bitter person, the person who's "hard to deal with." So, it uses the strange <jp>にがい</jp> reading.
Context 1-EN: Silence is hard to deal with.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちんもくが苦手です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "What is your weak point, Koichi?" "I'm not good at singing."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「コウイチが苦手なことって何ですか？」「ぼくは歌が苦手です。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: You and I used to be inseparable, but you know, now it’s like… things are different. Honestly, I feel uncomfortable with you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺とお前は昔は切っても切れない仲だっただろ。でもさ、 ほら、今は昔とは違うというか何というか、えっと…正直いって、お前のこと苦手なんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>foolish</kanji> and <kanji>stupid</kanji> person will make lots of <vocabulary>idle complaint</vocabulary>s. You really don't like being around them because they <vocabulary>grumble</vocabulary> about how nothing is good enough all the time. But they really just don't get it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you only talk of idle complaints, nothing will change.
Context 1-JP: <jp>愚痴ばかり言っても、何も変わらないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>detailed</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Things that are <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary>... how about that plan you made to perform that <reading>coup, what</reading> (<jp>くわ</jp>)?? You're doing a coup?
Context 1-EN: You are quite the expert on mackerel sushi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ずい分シメサバについて詳しいんですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm sorry, but I'm not an expert when it comes to guns, so it would be better if I didn't touch them.
Context 2-JP: <jp>すみませんが、私はじゅうについて詳しくないので下手に触らない方がいいと思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Oh, by the way, did you hear they’re getting married?" "Wow! Really? Tell me everything."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「おお、そういえば、あいつら結婚するって聞いた？」「おお、マジかよ？ 詳しく教えてくれよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. <kanji>Mochi</kanji> is <vocabulary>mochi</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the meaning, you should be able to read this too. After all, <vocabulary>mochi</vocabulary> is <reading>mochi</reading> (<jp>もち</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: When eating mochi, all of my relatives put mayonnaise on it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の親戚はみんな餅にマヨネーズをかけて食べます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: His suitcase was filled with nothing but mochi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>彼のスーツケースには餅しか入ってなかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I ordered the mochi and green tea set.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お餅と緑茶のセットを頼みました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left side</vocabulary>. Simple as that.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab <jp>左</jp> and add it to <jp>側</jp> to have yourself <reading><jp>ひだりがわ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Everybody stands on the left side on this escalator I guess.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このエスカレーターでは、みんな左側に立っていますね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They drive on the left in Japan the same as they do in England.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本は、イギリスと同じで、車は左側通行ですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When sleeping, I prefer to lie down on my left side.
Context 3-JP: <jp>寝る時は、左側を下にして横になる方が好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>wolf </kanji> is a <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary>. This word is less common than <jp>狼男</jp>, but it's used more and more thanks to the card game of the same name!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for <jp>狼</jp> (wolf) yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that, as well as which on'yomi to use for <jp>人</jp>:

There's a <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary> in front of you wearing  <reading>jean</reading>s and eating <reading>roe</reading> (<jp>じんろう</jp>). This is typical behavior for werewolves, as I'm sure you know.
Context 1-EN: Have you ever seen a werewolf?
Context 1-JP: <jp>人狼を見たことがありますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The truth is, the teacher of this class is a werewolf.
Context 2-JP: <jp>実は、このクラスの先生は人狼なんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The game "Werewolf" is a party game in which you distinguish between friends and a liar through conversation.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「人狼」ゲームは、味方かウソつきかを会話で見分けるパーティーゲームです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You really want to eat food that's in neat <vocabulary>shape</vocabulary>s, so you decide to use a <reading>cutter</reading> (<jp>かた</jp>) on your <reading>chee</reading>se (<jp>ち</jp>) to make it a new shape. Square cheese is so boring. After you cut it up you have mouse shaped cheese! It just tastes better like that.
Context 1-EN: I spoke with my wife and we decided to go with this shape, because we value substance over form.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つまとそうだんして、形より内ようをおもんじたけっか、この形にきめました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: With this, I could somehow manage to keep up appearances.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これでなんとか形がつきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, do you want to rub my butt-shaped belly?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねえ、私の、お尻の形をしたお腹、撫でたい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>oppress</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to oppress</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to persecute</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The best way <vocabulary>to oppress</vocabulary> someone is to make it so they can't use the <reading>sh*tter</reading> (<jp>しいた</jp>). Just imagine any kind of oppressive monarch from history. They know your weakness. They know you need to poop at some point. What would it be like 48 hours from now if you didn't have a place to poop. If you didn't have your "sh*tter."

To help you to remember that there's an <jp>い</jp> in there, think about an <reading>eagle</reading>, as we often do for <jp>い</jp>. This eagle represents "American Freedom." If you had this freedom you'd be pooping all you want and nobody would take your sh*tter away from you.
Context 1-EN: That man always oppressed his wife and children.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの男は、妻と子供をずっと虐げてきたのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you can do <kanji>nothing</kanji> within <kanji>reason</kanji>, then what you're trying to do is <vocabulary>unreasonable</vocabulary> and probably downright <vocabulary>impossible</vocabulary>. If you still try, you're probably just <vocabulary>overdoing</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
Context 1-EN: Koichi said that garlic is a cure for constipation, but I'd say curing constipation with garlic is impossible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはニンニクは便ぴを治す薬だって言ってたけど、ニンニクで便ぴを治すのは無理でしょ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even though Koichi makes unreasonable demands, the Tofugu team manages to meet them by overworking themselves.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチが無理なん題をふっかけても、トーフグチームは無理してなんとかやってのける。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s impossible to lick your own elbow.
Context 3-JP: <jp>自分の肘を舐めるのは無理です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>discerning</kanji> is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are <vocabulary>common sense</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was relieved that you guys have common sense.
Context 1-JP: <jp>常識のある人たちばかりで、安心しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I took a common knowledge test, but my results were terrible.
Context 2-JP: <jp>常識テストを受けてみたが、結果はさんざんだった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How about putting common sense aside and thinking outside the box for a second?
Context 3-JP: <jp>常識は脇に置いて、少しだけ既存の考えに囚われずに考えてみませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's <vocabulary>high school</vocabulary>, when most people stop growing taller.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It only takes 10 minutes to get to the high school if you drive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>高校まで、車で行けば十分ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What kind of food do you guys usually have for lunch in high school?
Context 2-JP: <jp>高校ではいつも、おひるにどんなものを食べていますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I didn’t start talking until I went to high school. Now I can’t shut up.
Context 3-JP: <jp>高校に行って初めて話をし始めたんです。そして、今は、話を止めることができません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>この</jp> means "this" so <jp>この辺</jp> just means <vocabulary>this area</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji <jp>辺</jp> so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.
Context 1-EN: There aren’t many people around here, so it’s quiet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この辺は、人が少ないのでしずかです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>この辺に、スタバはありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: You have to be careful about what you say around here. People on this side of town will spit in your face just for whistling.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この辺では、言葉に気をつけた方がいいぜ。町のこちら側に住んでいるやつらは、口笛を吹いただけでも顔に唾をぶっかけてきやがるからな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>container</kanji>s that <kanji>soldier</kanji>s use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their <vocabulary>arms</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>weapons</vocabulary>. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We discussed whether using arms was right or wrong.
Context 1-JP: <jp>兵器使用の是非について語り合いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I used to work at a chemical weapons laboratory.
Context 2-JP: <jp>化学兵器の研究室で働いていたことがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We received an email from a Tofugu user about the movement of the location of the nuclear weapons.
Context 3-JP: <jp>核兵器の所在地の移動に関するEメールが、とあるTofuguユーザーから送られてきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>縛る</jp> means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's <kanji>neck</kanji> then it's called <vocabulary>hanging</vocabulary>. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be <vocabulary>death by hanging</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>縛る</jp> and <jp>首</jp>. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the <jp>る</jp> to <jp>り</jp> and it's pretty simple!
Context 1-EN: In the Edo period, there was a punishment called death by hanging.
Context 1-JP: <jp>江戸時代には縛り首という刑罰があった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attack</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary> me or something? <reading>Oh so</reading> scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."
Context 1-EN: I was literally caught with my pants down by a sudden, severe attack from a stomach ache.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺は文字通りズボンを下げたところで、突然の激しい腹痛に襲われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When things are <vocabulary>sparse</vocabulary>, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your <reading>ma</reading>ma would <reading>baa</reading> (<jp>まば</jp>) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.
Context 1-EN: It’s bustling during the day, but at night pedestrian traffic is sparse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昼間は賑やかですが、夜になると人通りも疎らになります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Throw your <kanji>family crest</kanji> into the <kanji>wave</kanji>s and you'll make lots of <vocabulary>ripple</vocabulary>s. There will probably also be <vocabulary>repercussions</vocabulary> with your family because those things are important and you really shouldn't be tossing them into the sea's waves.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The cabinet minister’s careless remark created a huge stir.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大臣の不用意な発言が波紋を呼んだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fake</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is <vocabulary>fake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>counterfeit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.
Context 1-EN: That guy bragged about his fake Gucci wallet to me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの男、俺に偽物のグッチの財布を自慢してきたんだぜ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you go to Itaewon, you can buy fake branded goods.
Context 2-JP: <jp>イテウォンに行けばブランド物の偽物が買えますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We have recently received information that a fake Koichi is living in downtown Portland.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近、ポートランドのダウンタウンにコウイチの偽物が住んでいるという情報をキャッチしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is simply a <vocabulary>black person</vocabulary>, kind of like how a <jp>白人</jp> is a "white person," but a different  color.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can’t understand how there are still people who discriminate against black people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なぜ未だに黒人をさべつする人がいるのか、りかいできません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm black, he's white. What's wrong with that?
Context 2-JP: <jp>おれは黒人であいつは白人だけど、それがどうしたの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Peanut butter was invented by a black person named George Washington Carver.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ピーナッツバターは、ジョージ・ワシントン・カーヴァーという名の黒人によって発明された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>power</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> you are <vocabulary>powerless</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You also can know that <jp>力</jp> uses its <jp>りょく</jp> reading because when you tried to pick up a tiny <reading>rock</reading> (<jp>りょく</jp>) you couldn't, because you were powerless.
Context 1-EN: That made me realize how tiny and powerless I am.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分がどれだけちっぽけで無力な存ざいであるかを思い知らされました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got a Yu-Gi-Oh! trading card called "Proof of Powerlessness."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「無力の証明」というゆうぎ王カードを手に入れました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The police were powerless to do anything about the stalker and in the end she was killed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>警察はそのストーカーに対して無力で何をすることもできず、結局彼女は殺されてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tea</kanji> supply is down to <kanji>nothing</kanji>??? That's <vocabulary>absurd</vocabulary>! For Americans, I imagine this word would be "<jp>無コーヒー</jp>" instead. Get it?? If you're a caffeine addict this word will make total sense.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It's absurd to cross such a busy road without a pedestrian crossing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんなに車がビュンビュン通っていて横だん歩道もないのに、向こう側へわたるなんて、無茶だよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet was drinking excessive amounts of awamori.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは無茶なりょうのあわもりを飲んでいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He made the rash decision to try and swim in a pool filled with curry sauce.
Context 3-JP: <jp>カレーソースでいっぱいのプールで泳ごうなんて、彼も無茶な決定をしたものだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is which year? It is <vocabulary>this year</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
With the first reading (the more common one), the <jp>こん</jp> of <jp>今</jp> is actually just <jp>こ</jp>. This gets shortened sometimes, so look out for it. Also, the <jp>年</jp> is the kun'yomi reading for some reason. It's a total mystery why this is. Perhaps the ancient aliens know, but I do not. You're going to have to remember this exception with that brain of yours and rely on the SRS to bestow this knowledge upon you.

The second reading, which is less common but still common enough, makes more sense. It is <jp>こんねん</jp> and just follows the jukugo patterns.
Context 1-EN: Where is your family going to go on winter vacation this year, Yamashita?
Context 1-JP: <jp>山下さんのかぞくは、今年の冬休みはどこに行きますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The coming-of-age ceremony in Okinawa went wild again this year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>おきなわのせい人しきは今年も大あれだった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As soon as I got used to writing 2013 as the date for this year, 2014 arrived.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ようやく今年の年を2013年と書くことを覚えたところで、年が2014年に変わった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>family crest</kanji> on your <kanji>finger</kanji>? That's just your <vocabulary>fingerprint</vocabulary>. It can be used to identify you, so it's pretty much the same as your own personal family crest.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The fingerprints on the doorknob were completely wiped off.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ドアノブの指紋を綺麗に拭き取った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Nurse</kanji> and <kanji>raise</kanji> your baby by <vocabulary>nursing</vocabulary>. Milk helps babies grow up big and strong.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The method of nursing infants is changing greatly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>乳児哺育の方法は大きく変化しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Neglect</kanji> someone so much that you remove yourself from their inner circle and live <kanji>outside</kanji> of their life and it's called <vocabulary>estrangement</vocabulary>. You might never see them again. But that's okay with you, your relationship is too weird to fix now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I had constantly felt alienated in school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校ではずっと疎外感を感じていました。</jp>
